APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

August 15th, 1946

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Cross Lake St. Joseph's Indian Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child:
English name: Thérèse Hastings
Age: 10
Name of Band: God's Lake Band
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: No. 128
Father's full name and No.: Alfred Hastings No. 128
Mother's full name and No.: Juliette Okimaw No. 128
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: Roman Catholic
Does applicant speak English?: No
Previously attended: R.C.S.D.Y.

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

Note—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Agent

Note—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

Please find enclosed Applications for Admission to the Cross Lake St Joseph's R.C. Indian Residential School.

Kindly inform me of your decision with regard to the admission of the children in question.

E.B. Goodman
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 3, 1946.

Mr. E.B. Goodman, Indian Agent, Norway House, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of September 16th and also your letters of September 20th and 25th, the Department approves the admission of the under-mentioned children to the Gross Lake Indian Residential School, providing that the admission of these pupils are not in excess of the number allowed:

Henry Trout, Robert Maxwell Chubb,
Therese Hastings, Francois Chubb,
Maggie Chubb, Jonas Yellowback,
Alexander Ross, Jimima Ross,
Effie Okiman, Joseph A. Hamilton,
Muriel Burge, Thomas A. Trout
Marie(Mary) Seratch Dorothy Thomas
Andrew McKay Rosalie Flett
Adelaide B. Miswagon.

The majority of the children's parents are both living and it is possible that most of the children, if not all, should attend the new school at Gross Lake about which you are being advised.

When submitting applications, the original copy only is required by this office, therefore, the duplicates are being returned.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. Waite,

Norway House, Manitoba.

We have received an enquiry from Reverend Gilbert C. Johnson, United Church Mission, Norway House, which reads as follows:

"I would also appreciate information concerning the admission of Milton Queskekapow to the Jack River Branch of the Catholic Residential School. I have inquired at the local Indian office and they have no record of his admission. I would appreciate your forwarding me a copy of his admission presuming this is available. He was admitted on Oct. 1, 1948."

Our records show that application form for this boy was forwarded to us under cover of a letter from Acting Superintendent Hughes, dated November 8th, 1943, requesting his admission to the Cross Lake Residential School. The reason given was that "home life of this boy is not good and his attendance at day school is poor, owing to the fact that his parents take him away from the Reserve when going hunting or to the fishing grounds".

The application form stated that the boy's religion was Roman Catholic and was signed by his father. Please let me have your comments.

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST

December 28, 1949.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your letter of September 29th last, your file 577-10 (El).

I have today interviewed Rev. Father Chamberland, Principal of the Jack River School, in connection with the admission of Milton Queskekapow to that establishment. Father Chamberland informed me that he had received repeated requests from the boy's parents to have him admitted to the Roman Catholic Church. These requests were made upon the parents' own volition as they appeared anxious to have the boy a regular attendant at the school and were completely agreeable to having him baptized in the Roman Catholic faith.

I trust this information will enable you to dispose of the matter.

Yours truly,

J. D. Minnis,
Supt. of Indian Agency.

Norway House Band #676.

(3) Joe Allan Harper,
Island Lake Band #244.

The aforesaid is for your information and approval please.

Mr. J.D. Minnis,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Norway House, Manitoba.

Re: Cross Lake R.C. Indian Residential School. Your File A-A (123)

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant, the Department approves the admission of Joe Allan Harper and Henry Lawrence Miswagan to the above school.

We have noted your remarks regarding Nancy-Jane Balfour and Elisabeth Collon. You should obtain a written statement from Father Chamberland with regard to his reasons for submitting applications for their admission to the Cross Lake School, in view of your statement that the Agency records have them listed as adherents of the United Church of Canada.

If the parents have joined the Catholic Church, the date of their admission to that Church should be stated. You should also point out to Father Chamberland that in the case of children whose religious affiliations are doubtful, all the facts should be placed before the Department through your office before such children are admitted to the Cross Lake Residential School.

I feel certain that he will co-operate with us in the manner just mentioned, as it has been a long standing rule with the Department that the procedure outlined in the preceding paragraph must be followed.

As one copy of the application forms is all that is required by us, the duplicates are being returned for your file.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education

Norway House, Jan.27,1950

Mr. Neary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have been notified by Mr. Minnis, Indian Agent, that you required more information about the admissions into the St. Joseph Ind. Res. School of Elizabeth Colon and Nancy Jane Balfour. I am glad to explain these cases.

Re: Elizabeth Colon

The child was admitted into our Residential School on account of the persisting wish of her parents to have her Catholic and educated in our school. She had been attending our day-school for three years. I can say emphatically that in no way whatsoever were her parents or herself solicited by any one of the school staff in this regard. On the contrary, I had refused to take her in the Res.School for two years before. This last fall, as her parents were insisting again, I thought it was fair to grant their demand. The child has been admitted into the Church and is now R.Catholic according to the wishes of the parents.

Re: Nancy Jane Balfour

The same statement applies to Nancy Jane Balfour. I had delayed the admission of this child to have more certitude about the parents' real intentions. As themselves persisted and as the mother had freely decided a year ago to join the R.C.Church, I did not hesitate to admit this girl into the Church and into the Res.School.

I hope these informations will be satisfactory,

Yours very truly,

Albert Chamberland, O.M.I.

The main point at issue, aside from denominational arguments, is the question "why are these children boarders?"

They live close enough to be attending as day school pupils. As you are aware, all United Church children now have to be sent to Portage or Brandon Residential Schools. They have been agitating strongly for the re-erection of the Norway House Residential School and such instances as this will only make our position here more difficult.

Re: Nancy Jane Balfour & Elizabeth Colon,
Your letter March 7/49, file 577-10 (E).

In reply to yours as m/n - Investigation discloses that the reasons the m/n children are attending the Boarding school are mainly economic. The parents of Nancy Jane Balfour are resident in this settlement only about half the year, being engaged in fishing and trapping activities in areas remote from Norway House. At the moment of writing, the parents of Elizabeth Colon are in winnipegosis, Man., where they have been most of the winter, I am informed, and, as the father and mother work at various fish-camps around Lake winnipegosis, it would be most difficult for them to take the child along.

I have discussed the matter of admissions to residential school with both Father Chamberland at Jack River and Father Trudeau at Cross Lake, especially where children of other faiths are concerned, and I do not anticipate any re-occurrence of a situation such as we are now dealing with. Both have agreed to submit applications for admission to Department through this office before admitting the child or children.

Mr. Neary points out (in his letter of Jan. 13th to me) that the above procedure has been a long-standing rule of the Department. However, as this procedure was not followed by Father Chamberland in the case under discussion, (applications being received by the writer late in December, while children were admitted at opening of term) it might be helpful if Department were to circularize principals of the

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Jack River Indian School

This institution has become a significant outpost of the Cross Lake Residential School and its existence is used to support a demand for replacing the United Church Indian Residential School at Norway House. The late Mr. Superintendent Goodman intended to review the necessity of providing residential facilities for a number of the children who have been admitted as boarders. He maintained that the previous Superintendent had been unnecessarily generous in his recommendations for admission. As the Department is now encouraging the day division organization in residential schools, Mr. Superintendent Minnis might be requested to undertake a study of the situation.

I get the impression that the teaching staff is better than that of the parent institution at Cross Lake, and I suggest an inquiry whether this condition will continue. It seems to me that the parent institution ought to be better staffed.

The scattering of pupils through the grades suggests that some transfers of pupils might be made to the parent institution thus reducing the number of grades taught and releasing a much needed teacher for duty elsewhere. Mr. Inspector Moffat stresses the fact that the classroom...
is congested and lacks good lighting and ventilation.

It is notable that there has been considerable correspondence on file 577-10 regarding admission of Norway House children to a residential school which they formerly attended as day pupils. There is a letter on file 577-10 from Mr. Superintendent Minnis in which he suggests that residential school Principals be requested to adhere more strictly to the Department's wishes in the matter of admission procedure.

Dear Mr. Minnis:

I acknowledge yours of April 5th about the Applications for Admission to Residential School of Marion Menow and Emily Menow. (File 123/25-2-577)

I regret not to have followed the procedure you wanted me to follow. I did not understand you when the other cases were talked about. For the present Admissions it would have been very convenient to submit them to you and I would have done so with pleasure if I had realized it was your desire.

In the past, I have usually sent the Applications to the Principal of Cross Lake School. I have no doubt that it has been the ruling of the Department to have the Applications submitted to the Superintendent before admitting a child to a Residential School, and I understand it is more regular. The fact is that it was not frequently done and I don't remember that we have been requested to do so. I have looked over the past correspondence I had with the Department about this subject and I have found no mention of this ruling. I state this to have you understand why I did not realize just what you meant.

For future Applications, I can assure you that I will do my best to comply with the requirements of the Department in this matter. However, I can foresee cases where this way of doing will be very embarrassing if not completely impossible. Parents very often decide to put their children in the school just when they are about to leave for their camps or in such circumstances. The greatest difficulty arises from the medical examination. Quite often we have to wait quite awhile before the children are examined; the doctor or the technician are away, the weather is not permitting etc ... It is not so simple as one might think. Practically the children must be in the school. In any case, I would like you or the other officers of the Department to feel free to give your approval or refusal even if already the child is in the school. We do so at our own risks.
Re: Marion Menow

She is an illegitimate child, adopted by her grandparents: Mr & Mrs J Charles Menow. Her mother is married with David Ross of Grand Rapids. The reasons given by them when they asked to put her in school was their old age (both are 70 and over), the actual state of health of J. Charles. Under such conditions they felt that they could not keep this child properly.

Re: Emily Menow

Twice this winter I have been asked by Johnnie Menow, her grand-father and guardian, to take this girl in our school. I could not give him a favorable answer until a few children from Cross Lake School would be discharged.

She was received in the Catholic Church at her entry in the school. Her admission was not the reason but the occasion to join the Church. It had been their intention to have her Catholic prior to their demand to put her in a Residential School. But she had to be instructed first. I don't think that it is surprising as all the Menows at the exception of a few, are Catholics and among these most of them will eventually join the Catholic Church.

This child is ten years old and had just a few days of school. Johnnie and his family, under ordinary circumstances, are away from the reserve the greatest part of the year: from October to January and from March to the middle of May on his trap line, from June to August at the Landing for fishing.

Again I apologize to have given you this trouble. I hope that I have answered to all you wanted to know.

Yours very truly,

(signed) A. Chamberland, OMI

Further to my letter of April 5/50 enclosing quarterly return of Cross Lake Indian residential school for period ending March 31/50, I am advised by Father G.M. Trudeau that application for admission of Muriel Sinclair to the institution is being held pending the doctor's examination.

Father Trudeau further advised me that this procedure is almost always followed at Cross Lake. The child is admitted almost invariably prior to both the doctor's examination and the superintendent's approval of admission application. About the only exceptions to this procedure occurs when the doctor is able to examine children during the summer on the various reserves, when it is known definitely that these children will enter residential school in September.

In view of the difficulties inherent in the transportation field in this part of the country, it would seem that, in the past at least, departmental regulations concerning applications for admission to Cross Lake school have been relaxed somewhat, for good reason, as otherwise, a long period of time might elapse before a child's admission to school could be approved.

I would appreciate your views on the permissibility of this relaxed procedure insofar as this school is concerned.

Regarding the application for the admission of the following pupils to the Cross Lake R.C. School, the following report is submitted:

Mary Ann Okimaw
Louis Watt
Victoria Osborne
Job Ross
Ananias Ross

Mary Ann Okimaw. The parents of this child are on their trap-line in the vicinity of God's River. There is no actual record of the location of their camp and it would be a useless trip to try and find them. They may return to the Mine at Christmas.

Mr. Gibson, the United Church Minister, was interviewed, and he stated that the father, Henry Okimaw is Protestant, married into a Roman Catholic family. The children would be educated in a Roman Catholic School. This statement was corroborated by Rev. Fr. Rivard.

Louis Watt. This family is on their trapline located between God's Lake and Norway House. Will not return to God's Lake until open water, sometime in June.

Rev. H.Gibson claims Watt the father of the above boy married a Roman Catholic woman. He made application for one girl to be admitted to Brandon Residential School two years ago, but as nothing further was heard concerning the application, the girl and her sisters were admitted to Cross Lake last year and the family, with the exception of the male parent, is now Roman Catholic. This statement was also corroborated by Rev. Fr. Rivard.

Victoria Osborne. The family is trapping at Grassi Narrows. If trapping is good, the family will not return until June or open water. If trapping is poor, then the family will return for the fishing after Christmas.

Rev. Gibson, in this case claims that the man is United Church married into a Roman Catholic family, and the wife and family are Roman Catholic. Statement corroborated by Rev. Fr. Rivard.

Job and Ananias Ross. Father Simon Ross. In this case the father is United Church and the woman believed to be Roman Catholic. Rev. H.Gibson claims this is a mixed family, but the two above noted boys were baptised in the Roman Catholic Church and should attend the Roman Catholic School. This case also was corroborated by Rev. Fr. Rivard. The Ross camp is 20 miles west of Grassi Narrows near Norway House. This family may return to the reserve for Christmas. Again, this depends on the trapping; they did not return to the reserve last year until open water.

Mr. Gibson claims he has a close watch on the pupils going to Cross Lake School and would report if there was any injustice. Fr. Rivard claims that there are enough Roman Catholic families on the reserve without encroaching on other preserves.

R.C.

I am reasonably satisfied that the children at Cross Lake School from God's Lake Reserve were baptised in that faith. I feel that the Superintendent has obtained his information from the Family Record, which would show religion of the parents. In most cases the father collects the treaty and the record would show his religion, which in the cases above would be incorrect. There is a tendency on God's Lake Reserve among some of the Protestant family's to give one or two children to the Roman Catholic Church, and the Family Record to be correct should show the religion of every child.

I attach hereto applications for admission to Cross Lake Indian Residential School in respect to the following children:

Sarah Osborne - Born 5 Nov. 1936.
James Osborne - Born 9 Dec. 1939.
Murray Osborne - Born 1942.
Joseph Osborne - Born 15 July 1945.

These children are the sons and daughter of Thomas and Priscilla Osborne, No. 656 Norway House Band. The father has been confined to Sanatorium for the past three years, and the children have been at Norway House in care of their mother. About the end of January the attached applications were submitted to this office along with a note from the mother approving their adoption of the Roman Catholic faith and their entry to residential school. At that time, I advised Father Kerbin of the local R.C. Mission that I was not prepared to approve the applications until written consent had been received from their father. This has now been secured by the clergyman, and is attached.

While waiting this approval from the father, I discussed the matter with Rev. K. McLeod of the local United Church Mission, as this family is shown in our records to be of that church affiliation. Rev. McLeod stated that the family has never shown any interest in church attendance, and that he would not protest their adoption of the R.C. faith nor their entry to Cross Lake School.

Since the father entered sanatorium, their mother Priscilla has been leading an immoral life. She has had certainly one, and possibly two children fathered by other than her legal husband since his departure to Man. Last fall she appeared in court on charges of disturbance of the peace, found guilty and fined.

(over, please)
Dept.: (c)

It was strongly suspected that she was indulging in considerable home-brewing and drinking, but evidence was insufficient to support such a charge. However, a young man found under the influence of liquor at her home received a three month sentence at the time.

Joseph, Murray and James Osborne were in sporadic attendance at Rossville H.C. Day School this term. After repeated warnings given the mother, I was forced to suspend Family Allowance payments in respect of these children for reason of continued poor attendance, which action was taken in December of 1950.

This woman is employed at Norway House Hospital, and has also been receiving assistance under T.B.Rehab Vote on account of her husband's hospitalization. This aid has now been suspended. I have no doubt that some expediency on her part was concerned in the conversion of her children and their application to enter Residential School; However, I feel that the environment these children were exposed to at home was of the worst, and that they will be immeasurably better off at Residential School. I have since received a letter from the father in which he deplores the life he hears his wife is leading and evinces his satisfaction at their entry into the Residential School.

With the above facts in mind, I must overlook completely the childrens' hypothetical United Church affiliation, and unreservedly approve their applications for admission to Cross Lake R. C. Residential school as attached, in which action I trust you will concur.

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent, Indian agency.

Mr. J.D. Minnis,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Norway House, Man.,

With reference to your application for admission for Titus Robinson to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School, it is noted that this boy's parents are living and that he has previously attended the Roman Catholic Day School for three years.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
July 15, 1952.

Mr. J.D. Minnis,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Norway House, N.W.T.

With reference to the June Quarterly Return for the Cross Lake Indian Residential School, you are advised that the Principal has claimed grant for pupils # 279 and 291 and indicated in the Remarks Column that these children were in the Norway House Hospital during the quarter. However, he has neglected to indicate the dates on which these children were admitted to hospital and later returned to school if they did return.

In order to avoid delaying the payment of the per capita grant for this quarter, we are disallowing any grant for the two children.

Please advise the Principal in this regard instructing him that he may claim this grant for these children on the September Quarterly Return with the necessary explanation of the dates when these children left the residence and later returned.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
17th July, 1952

Mr. J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent of Indian Agency
Norway House, Man.

Dear Mr. Minnis:

I received only today your letter of June the 30th regarding the admission of Titus Robinson to our Residential School.

One of the main reasons for the parents of Titus Robinson to put him in the school is that the father has a large family and on account of health conditions is having a hard time to provide for the needs of the whole family.

Many times also the child had to miss school as the father would need him to help him on his trap line. Also when the father would be away with the canoe the child could not attempt to come to school. As the parents wanted to give him a better education to their boy and seeing they could not do so by keeping him home to attend only day school they decide to put him in the Residential School.

These are the reasons which made me accept the boy in our Residential School.

Yours very truly,

G. E. Trudeau, O. M. I.
Principal
Your 577-10 (E6) of June 13th, 1952, Res Titus Robinson.

With reference to your letter as above noted, please find attached a copy of a letter received from Father Trudeau at Cross Lake explanatory to the reasons for admission of this boy to Cross Lake Indian Residential School. I trust you will find the Principal's reasons sufficient, and I can certainly vouch for the fact that it is extremely difficult for the children from this portion of the Reserve to attend the Day School regularly. They live across the bay from the Day School, are often unable to travel on account of weather conditions and as pointed out by Father Trudeau, when the family canoe is being used for other purposes, it is impossible for the child to get to Day School.

I trust the reasons given will enable you to approve admission of this boy to Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent Indian Agency,

Re: Application for Admission to Cross Lake Indian Residential School, George Muskego, #604 Cross Lake

Please find enclosed application as above noted. Question of this child's admission to Residential School was discussed by the writer with the boy's father, Thomas Muskego, and with the Principal of the School.

My reasons for approving this application are the nomadic existence led by this child's family and the distance he lives from any Roman Catholic Day School—2½ miles across the water. For the short periods during which the family are in the settlement, school attendance is difficult. The father is a War Veteran and a good trapper, and is very anxious for his son to secure at least a little bit of education, which, under the family's circumstances, he can only secure through attendance at Residential School. The boy, now age 13, has only about a Grade 2 or 3 standing by reason of his broken schooling.

Although I am reluctant to approving admission of children of his age, under ordinary circumstances, I feel that, in this case, if the boy is to receive any education at all, he should attend Residential School, and Department approval of his admission is requested.

J. D. Minnis,
Superintendent Indian Agency,

THRESHER -
As per instructions received from the Department, Brother Ménard made inquiries concerning a moderately priced thresher which might suit the needs of the School. He has fixed his choice on one manufactured by Doré and Son of Laprairie, Que. The order sheets herein inclosed give a description of the machine. The price is $528.00 delivered at Winnipeg.

The Légard Company of Quebec, Que. offered for sale a smaller thresher at the price of $548.00 delivered also at Winnipeg, but the machine was not as highly recommended by users as the other was.

As the transportation of the thresher will take quite a long time, it might be well to place the order as soon as possible.

BINDER - FAN MILL -
Bought from the John Deere Plow Company, Winnipeg. Invoice to hand. Brother Ménard saw the Binder and found it to be light and easy to operate.

He forgot to order twine for the binder. Would the Department order the same for about 25 acres.

Potato DIGGER -
The School needs a potato digger. About 1,000 bushels of potatoes are going to be sown this year. The digging up of the potato crop has always been done under great difficulties. It must be done inside of a couple of days, for there is almost continuous rain in the fall. In some cases the potatoes could not be left to dry on the field; they had to be taken to the house, spread on the floor to dry, and then carted to the root-house. This work occupied about two weeks. With a machine, the potatoes might be dug up on the morning of a clear day; they would dry up on the field in the afternoon and they might be picked up in the evening and be carted directly to the root-house.

Per J.A. Lajeunesse, CM.I.

Description:
- **FRAME:** Made with two castings of a good lasting machine in the shape of arches twice as high and longer than usual with end trusses made by heavy drawn bars and bolts.
- **CYLINDER:** Of well-proved type, cylinders are large and heavy, plated with iron well secured to the bar with brass rivets at its ends, fitted with four drums driven by pinions, etc., and so arranged that they work but once each revolution.
- **TURBINITE:"** Are heavy, well secured to the bars with brass rivets at their ends. They run on cast iron bearings, which can be easily removed when they become worn.
- **CONVEYORS:** Nothing better; made of steel bars with 5" grate plates fastened to them and driven by vanes, brass shafts and gears; where no chain or trash can prevent grain from going into the throat, etc., the conveyors will discharge grain evenly and quickly.
- **STRAW DESK:** Well made. A long grate is right at back of desk. The grain flows from the desk through a chute lined with deep grooves so that the straw can block the free passage of the grain and thus be thrown to the side.
- **EXTRACTION:** Two well turned coppers of 44" x 12", with cutts in the extreme ends, so that their diameter changes as the grain flows toward the extractors; this makes smooth running and less wear.

Memorandum:

DR. STONE

With reference to your inquiry regarding the cattle at the Residential Schools in Manitoba I enclose, for your information, a report on the herd at each of the Residential Schools in that Province.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Reports of Principals of Manitoba Residential Schools regarding action taken to prevent tuberculosis infection from milk.

BIRTLE: We are milking 15 cows at the present time. We have them tested every year in the month of May. I have been Principal for four years and five months and during that time we have had no reactors. In the summer of 1936 I had all tested for Bang's disease and here also we found no reactors. We do not purchase any milk.

BRANDON: A new herd of pure bred dual purpose Shorthorns was started in the fall of 1930. Every animal purchased was T. B. tested. In 1933 we received our accredited herd certificate and fortunately have retained it constantly ever since. The last annual test is dated May 18, 1937. We have 56 females in the herd, about 20 milking at one time. We also maintain annually the blood test for Bang's disease. We do not purchase any milk.

CROSS LAKE: We have at present time seven milking cows. None of them was tested for bovine tuberculosis. They appear healthy and we have no signs of such disease amongst them. We are not purchasing milk and the school herd does not mix with any other animal from outside.

ELKHORN: The number of milking cows at the present time is 30. The herd is tested regularly by Government veterinarians from Brandon. The last occasion being the first week in November, 1937 when Mr. McConnell, who made the tests, pronounced the herd to be free from bovine T. B. Since November 1, 1936 it has not been necessary to purchase any milk from outside sources for use at this school. Should this at any time become necessary we should certainly secure it from T. B. free herds.

FORT ALEXANDER: Our herd was tested last summer (1937) at which test one cow we had bought from Pine Falls was found to react and was killed the same day. The herd was re-tested last fall (1937) and found in good order. At present we have 14 milking cows 10 of which were purchased before the last test. We do not need to buy any milk.

NORWAY HOUSE: We have eleven milking cows. To my knowledge they have never been tested for bovine tuberculosis. Because they have not been tested and therefore we cannot be sure they are free from disease we scald all the milk and cream we use, both for table use and butter. We do not purchase milk from any other source.

PINE CREEK: We have altogether 16 milking cows, 9 of which are giving milk at present. Our cows are tested regularly twice a year by Dr. Caldwell, from Dauphin, Manitoba. The last test, made in November 1937, proved to be satisfactory. We do not purchase any milk. Our cows supply all the milk necessary.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE: Have a herd of registered Jersey cows from fully accredited herds. They are tested annually. The last test was last summer and no reactors. There are 17 cows in the herd. We are situated in a T. B. free area.

SANDY BAY: At the present time we are milking 10 cows. They have never been tested for T. B. and I cannot say if they are free or not from T. B. So far I have never bought milk to be used in the school.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Margaret Jane Bee, Pupil No. 3176, of the St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at Cross Lake, Man., who died at the Cross Lake School (place) on May 29, 1942.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

September 14th 1942.

William MILLER, Tr. Ind. Child - Cross Lake, Man.
Death of - by Drowning.

1. On Aug. 10th 1942 I was informed by Dr. R.S.G. Corrigan of Norway House, that he had received a report from Rev. Fr. G.H. Trudeau, OMJ of Cross Lake, that one William Miller, and Treaty Indian student of St. Joseph R.C. School at Cross Lake, had drowned at Cross Lake the day previously (Sun.Aug.9th.) Dr. CORRIGAN who is a Coroner, informed me that he had satisfied himself that death was accidental, that an inquest was unnecessary, that he had signed the necessary papers and permitted burial of the body.

2. In view of the fact that the writer hereof, was preoccupied with other matters (Treaty escort), and it was obvious from the Doctor's remarks that there would be no pressing need for police investigation, the matter was held over pending our next patrol to Cross Lake, which was anticipated to be the end of August. This patrol however, did not materialize till Sept 11th-13th.

First.

3. On 12-9-42 whilst in Cross Lake the matter was investigated. It appears that William MILLER, Treaty Indian child aged nine years, attending St. Joseph's Residential School at Cross Lake, went bathing too soon after eating his dinner, and was drowned, at approximately 12.45 p.m. on Sun.Aug.8th. The body was recovered at 1.15 p.m. and artificial respiration was applied for some two and a half hours by competent members of the school staff, without result.

4. The following statements were taken. There were two other witnesses from whom I should have taken statements but they were not available. These were Stanley HAMILTON, Tr. Ind., and Michel SCATCH Tr. Ind., the latter a 16 year old boy, who was the first to arrive on the scene and went into the water to try to get out the MILLER Child, HAMILTON arriving a few moments later and also trying to recover the boy.

5. Statement of Lydia MCKAY, Indian girl aged 16, of Cross Lake, Manitoba.

"On a Sunday in August, I think it was the ninth, I was picking berries and eating them, over at the Mission, with three other girls. We were near the water and I saw about four small boys swimming near the sawmill. One of them was William MILLER. I could see that William had got into deep water, and I saw him struggle and his head go down. None of the other small boys who were there were near William, they had stayed in shallow water. Us girls went down to the water, but William was too far out for us to reach him. So I ran up the hill from the water and saw a man passing and told him the boy was drowning. That was Stanley Hamilton."

(Continued)
Re: William MILLER Tyendinaga Lake, Man.
Death of - By Drowning.

(Statement of Lydia McKay, cont.)

He went down and tried to get William out of the water. Before this though another big boy, Nicholas SCATCH had heard us calling for help and he came right there and tried to get William out but he could not do so. I did not go to the Mission, but one of the people had heard us calling and sent for the Father. I was still there when the men got William's body from the water. I do not know why he should drown, but I do know that he had got too far out into deep water, for such a small boy, and there was no one close to him."

Witnessed.

(sgd) 'Lydia McKay'

(R.A.Kirk, Cpl., RCMP)

Statement of Rev. Fr. G.E. Trudeau O.M.I. of St. Joseph's Mission, Cross Lake, Manitoba:

On Sunday August 9th about 12:45 p.m., an Indian woman informed me that a small boy was drowning near our sawmill. I went to the place by canoe, with Father DANIEL, Brother MENARD and others, and two other canoes came along. Approximately 1:15 p.m., the body of one William MILLER, aged approx. 9 years, a student at St. Joseph's School was recovered from the water by the searching group. Immediately artificial respiration was applied continuously for two hours and a half by myself and Sister Francoise Therese R.N., at the end of which time the child was adjudged dead by the sister. In my opinion the child's death was due to accidental drowning, possibly caused by swimming too soon after his dinner."

(sgd) 'G.E. Trudeau O.M.I.'

Statement of Sister Francoise Therese R.N., Nursing Sister of St. Joseph's School, Cross Lake, Manitoba:

On Sun., Aug. 9th at 12:45 p.m., Father Trudeau sent me a message requesting my presence as a boy had been drowned, and I went as requested. I was present about 1:15 p.m., when the body of William MILLER was found, was recovered from the lake. In company with Father Trudeau I applied artificial respiration to William Miller, which was applied for two hours and a half, long before which I knew that William Miller was dead and could not be recovered. In my opinion death was due solely to drowning caused by swimming too soon after his dinner."

(sgd) Sr. Marie Francoise Therese R.N.

With regard to the last sentence of each of the two preceding statements, the students at the School begin their dinner about 11:30 a.m., finishing somewhat after 12 noon. The boy was drowned at 12:45. Father Trudeau informed me that Sister St. Maximin overheard some of the boys discussing swimming after dinner. She told them that they must not swim after dinner. It is not known however, if the MILLER lad was amongst those so warned.

In view of the contents of these statements this file will be considered concluded.

(Signed) R.A.Kirk, Cpl.

Sir,

I was at the Mackay Indian Boarding School in the Pas
agency, on the 26th of June last, shortly after Mr. A.E. Wilson of
Elkhorn had sent the list to the Principal of what supplies,
material, furniture was available for other schools. The
Principal was asked to note on the list what he would like to have
sent him and return to Mr. Wilson.

I would like to point out that this school is in need of
everything they are marking off the list sent them. When this
school was started they did not get the usual quantity of new
furniture that is furnished to a school of this class. At least a
carload of old furniture came from the old Battleford School, old
dining room tables which are now falling to pieces, old benches for
the pupils to sit on, and old beds which are being repaired almost
daily. There is a lot of good furniture at Elkhorn and I,
assisted the Archdeacon and the Matron in marking off on the list
what would be suitable for the Mackay School. Things are much
better at this school than at my last visit and my report on same
will reach you in a few days.

Dear Archdeacon Snowdon,

In 1919 the Elkhorn industrial school at Elkhorn, Man., which had been conducted by this Department for a number of years, was closed and the property transferred to the Soldiers Settlement Board to be used as a training centre for ex-service men. I am now advised by the Board that they do not wish to utilize the property any longer in connection with their work, and that they desire to re-transfer it to the Department. When transferred to the Board the buildings and equipment in connection therewith were in splendid condition, and in view of the lack of facilities for the training of Church of England children in Manitoba and Saskatchewan, it occurred to me that it might be well for the Church to undertake the management of a school at this point, it being understood that the Department would be responsible for the upkeep of the plant.

MEMORANDUM OF THE SPECIAL COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF THE REV.W.J.SOUTHAM AND THE FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C. APPOINTED BY THE INDIAN AND ESKIMO COMMISSION TO EXAMINE THE CONDITION OF THE BUILDINGS AND PROPERTY OF THE ELKHORN INDIAN SCHOOL.

Your Committee begs to report as follows:

1. That they left Winnipeg on Thursday, May 26th, at 3.25 p.m. and reached Elkhorn the same day at 9.30 p.m. Before leaving Winnipeg they secured from the Synod Office a copy of the Report on the Elkhorn Industrial School prepared by the special committee appointed by the Synod of Rupert's Land for the purpose, dated April 15th, 1918, and carefully examined this on the way.

2. On arriving at Elkhorn they were met by the Rev.O.L. Jull, Rector of St. Mark's Parish, and Mr. Brotherhood, Manager of the Elkhorn Branch of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, and with these gentlemen an informal conference was held the same evening.

3. On Friday morning, May 27th, accompanied by Mr. Jull and Mr. Brotherhood, who kindly placed himself and his car at the service of the Committee, they proceeded to the School Grounds and carefully examined every building in connection with the Institution.

This consists of the original building 32' x 113', built in 1897; to which a three story addition 33' x 44' was made in 1913. It is made of white brick resting on a stone foundation and is for the accommodation of the staff and pupils. It contains the following rooms and equipment

1. Lavatory for boys
2. Boiler room where there is one good boiler but disconnected
3. Shower baths and locker for boys
4. Lavatory for girls
5. Shower baths and locker for girls

7. Engine room, with two tanks holding 5,000 gallons each and a small leader engine, out of order and too small for the purpose.

3. Dispensary (1)

7. Dormitory at N. end for boys but used as play room for girls. This room has a metallic ceiling.

A frame building 24' x 36', with a verandah on the S. side. It contains 7 rooms with full basement underneath, which contains soft water tank. This was leaking and flooded the surrounding area. The heating is done by stoves. Telephone wire has been laid on.

- Carpenter's shop

12. **GRANARY**
   This is a frame building 28' x 32'. It is in good condition.

   This is a frame building 18' x 30' in good condition except the roof which needs some repairs. In this building is stored twenty hole Massey Harris Seeder, practically new, which belongs to the Soldier's Settlement Board, and was offered for sale a few months ago for $150.00.

   This is a small wooden structure standing on the extreme Western side of the school grounds.

**REAL ESTATE**

So far as your committee were able to ascertain the area of the land belonging to the School at present is approximately 320 acres (but the exact extent remains to be ascertained from either the Synod of Rupert's Land or the Land Titles Authorities.)

This area comprises the S.W. ¼ sec. 4 and S.E.¼ Sec. 5, Township 12, Range 26, situated in the town of Elkhorn and immediately adjoining the C.P.R. station.

The buildings stand on the first of these two divisions and about 300 yds. from the railway depot.
CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS

1. THE MAIN BUILDING

Re Buildings, speaking generally your Committee found the buildings in fairly good condition but before any attempt is made to re-open the Schools as a Church institution the following repairs should be made:

1. Walls kalsomined or painted.
2. Plumbing thoroughly examined and put in order.
3. Pupils' stairs re-treaded.
4. Connect spare boiler with heating system.
5. Have an additional tank to supply hot water.
6. Get more powerful engine to drive machinery in laundry and to pump water.
7. Fire extinguishing hose examined and when necessary replaced.
8. Plastering attended to in one room.
9. Range in kitchen, new lids and fire brick.
10. Pantry, more cupboard room.
11. Metallic roof and railing to be repaired.
12. Paint all woodwork and stain softwood floors.
13. New lighting system to be installed, such as Delco or Jenco, with wires laid on to all important buildings and light and power building mentioned above to be adapted to this purpose.
14. Woodwork outside to be painted.
15. Cement stairs to take the place of those now on N. and S. sides of building.

REPAIRS TO PRINCIPAL'S RESIDENCE

Paint the kitchen.

FARMER'S HOUSE

Put in hot air furnace.
Kalsomine walls and repair soft water tank.

CARPENTER'S HOUSE

Put in hot air furnace.
Repair the chimney.
Kalsomine the walls.

BARN

Repair inside walls.

IMPLEMENT SHED

Repairs to roof.

GYMNASIUM

Roof, floors and partitions repaired and painted. It will then be a serviceable building.
SEPTIC TANK

Tank examined and the carry-eff placed under ground.

Most of the buildings need paint outside.

SCHOOL FARM

Complete fencing of the School Farm and acquire an extra half section of land.

In addition to the foregoing requirements it will be obvious to the Commission that complete furnishings and equipment will be necessary, the nature and extent of which will depend on the type of School to be established.

While your Committee feel that having completed their survey as set forth above and that the making of definite recommendations was not expected of them, they beg, however, to present to the Commission the following suggestions for their consideration:

1. In view of the splendid buildings already in existence and the nature of the land which seems well adapted for farming purposes, it would be well to have the School reopened as an Agricultural and Industrial Institution wherein practical subjects would be taught, such as farming, gardening and care of stock, carpentry etc., for the boys, and home economics for the girls.

2. That as the School is not situated on or near any Indian Reserve, a distinct and definite understanding should be required from the Indian Department to supply the pupils, using the power vested in them according to the Amended Indian Act.

Dear Canon Gould:

I am in receipt of your letter of December 23rd, with reference to the re-opening of the Elkhorn Industrial School.

Your third proviso requires careful consideration. The capacity of the school might be placed at 100, and we must decide upon the districts from which our pupilage might be drawn.

If we were to accept the responsibility of keeping the school full, we must of course expect the close cooperation of your Board and the district missionaries. There is no reason why we should not transport pupils from some distance to this school, and I propose to prepare a statement of the number of children of school age in the agencies which might be called upon to supply the pupils. I will submit this list for your attention.

I do not think the school could be a success if it were used as a centre of secondary education. I doubt very much whether we could get the support of the Anglican Boarding schools to a policy which would take the older pupils away from them. I should like to open this school with the good will of the Indians whose children will be expected to attend, and while we have control through our statutes, I do not wish to use any methods that might be interpreted as harsh in putting it into operation as it might defeat the best ends we have in view.

MEMORANDUM

Acting Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the attached correspondence regarding the proposed re-opening of the Elkhorn Industrial School under the auspices of the Anglican Church authorities, I beg to say that the arrangement between the Department and Canon Gould, of Toronto, concerning the future of this school has not yet been completed. Until a definite understanding has been reached we are not in a position to go ahead with the alterations and repairs to the plant and equipment of this school.

The sum of $6,000 was provided in our Main Estimates for the present fiscal year for furnishings and repairs to the building. We have on file from Commissioner Graham a statement of the repairs that would be required to place the buildings in good condition.

Rev. Canon Gould requested, besides placing the building in good condition, that additional land be secured for agricultural operations, also that the Department undertake to supply the number of pupils needed to maintain the school in operation at the full capacity of its accommodation, and further that should the number of pupils in residence at any time fall short of the full capacity of the institution, then the Department is to be responsible for the difference in the amount of the total per capita grant as between the capacity of the institution and the actual number of pupils in residence. He also requested that the school be carried on as a centre of "secondary" education to which the brighter pupils from other residential schools could be transferred for more advanced training.

The Department does not desire to accept the responsibility of recruiting and keeping the school full, also, we are doubtful of the success if it were used as a centre of secondary education.

In the meantime, in order that the cultivated land should not be allowed to become overgrown with weeds, Mr. Commissioner Graham has leased the school farm to Mr. Earl S. Dixon, of Elkhorn, for this season on the basis of two-thirds of the proceeds of the crop sales being retained by him and the remaining one-third paid to the Department. The Commissioner also suggested to lease to Mr. Dixon the pasture land in the vicinity of the school for this season at a nominal rental, the amount of which has not yet been agreed upon. The Commissioner has suggested that we be good enough to bear this lease in mind when any arrangements are being made with the Church authorities in regard to the re-opening of the school.

Until a complete understanding is arrived at between the Department and the Church authorities regarding the above mentioned matters, we are not in a position to take any action towards having the necessary repairs carried out, or the school re-opened.

Mr. Scott:

Canon Gould has secured the sanction of the M.S.C.C. to the re-opening of the Elkhorn Industrial School, on certain conditions.

The first condition might mean that Canon Gould expects the Department to pay for the 100 pupils, whether or not that number are in residence.

The second condition suggests that the Department cooperate closely in the matter of recruiting. If this means other than active assistance on our part, we would be in danger of having other institutions call on us for the same help.

The third condition, that we put the institution in repair and arrange for electric light, is quite reasonable. Inspector Murison, in November, last, estimated the cost of the work at $4103. This includes electric lighting. Funds for this work are on deposit in Regina to the amount of $4018, as on the 31st ultimo.

The fourth condition mentioned by Canon Gould is that the school be re-opened on May first, 1923. I cannot agree that this is the best date for the recruiting of pupils. The experience of most principals is that Indian parents are more easily convinced of the advisability of educating their children as soon as possible and as clothing and food are more difficult to provide. I would suggest that staff be appointed as from May first and that their duties consist of supervising the farming operations, the repairs to the building and active recruiting. I am of the opinion that 4 or 5 men and women, including the new principal, should be on the Indian reserves during the summer of 1923, giving particular attention to the Prince Albert and Battleford areas in Saskatchewan; the Fairfield, Pemuis, Brokenhead and Black River reserves in Manitoba; and the Lac Seul district in Ontario.

In answer to Canon Gould's suggestion that the land be worked this autumn, we might inform him that the farm is leased for this year and that summer-fallowing is being done on certain fields that are not being cropped.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re Elkhorn Industrial School

I am sending a copy of your letter dated Sept. 28th to the Rev. Dr. Westgate, with the request that our Indian and Eskimo Commission shall take up the matters requiring attention at an early date.

I am leaving this evening for England en route to India and the Far East, otherwise I should like to have had some further personal conversation with you concerning the precise meaning of the phrase used in your letter "The onus of the responsibility will have to rest on the Church Authorities".

I understood at the time that the reason why the Department closed the Elkhorn Industrial School was on account of the fact that its cost of maintenance worked out at $225 per capita; a per capita cost which the Department felt could not be justified. Under these circumstances it is most desirable that no possible ground of misunderstanding regarding the basis upon which the Institution will be re-opened, should be left undetermined.

The Rev. Dr. Westgate, Secretary of our Indian and Eskimo Commission, will be Acting General Secretary of the Society during my absence. He is now absent on a visit to the Lac La Ronge School, on his return he will
I have no doubt, make an early opportunity of waiting upon you at the Department with a view to making such further precise and definite arrangements as may be necessary.

Your statement that the land at the School has been leased does not mean, I trust, that it has passed out of immediate control. The School authorities would have to be in possession of the land for some weeks at least before the date of the re-opening of the school in order that the necessary agricultural operations might be under way, cattle purchased, etc., etc., against the date of re-opening.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the needs at the Elkhorn Industrial School in connection with its re-opening during the present year. The Department is pleased to have the list of equipment that is required; and I have to inform you that the regulations of the Purchasing Commission are such that care will have to be exercised when authority is being given in this connection. Certain repairs can, of course, be undertaken by day labour, under the supervision of an officer of the school. Further, the principal appointed by your Board will receive in his own authority to purchase, after obtaining competitive prices, the equipment, seed and stock that can be secured to advantage, locally. Classroom, dining-room and dormitory equipment will be purchased, after securing competitive prices and a minute number from the Purchasing Commission. This Department will give the necessary authority, if funds can be found for the purpose, when the securing of each lot of equipment is timely.

In the interim, I would be pleased if you would offer the Department definite information as to your plans in connection with the re-opening. Is it proposed to engage a staff, whose duties during the ensuing summer could be supervising the renovating and equipping for the school? Furthermore, would it be advisable to arrange for the purchase of the equipment, live stock and seed necessary for the farm, in the early spring? The purchase of the staff furniture, agricultural implements, live stock, seed grain, kitchen equipment, etc., should be made by the principal and a department representative.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of Feb. 22, No. 116823-1, in connection with the re-opening of the Elkhorn School, I beg to inform you that a definite recommendation has just gone forward from our Commission to the General Secretary of our Society in Toronto, to the effect that the Rev. Fred Eley, curate of All Saints' Church, Montreal, be nominated to your Department for appointment to the Principalship of this institution, and I have no doubt that you will hear from our General Secretary in this connection within the very near future. Should Mr. Eley receive the appointment it is the desire of our Commission that he should proceed to the School at the earliest opportunity, so as to superintend any repairs which the Department will undertake, all arrangements in connection with the farming operations, and assist in the recruiting and receiving of children for enrolment. It is therefore, a matter of great urgency that the man who is at present occupying the Principal's residence, should be given notice to vacate that building, and that the necessary repairs and renovations preparatory to its being occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Eley, should be undertaken in the immediate future.

In response to your request for an outline of the plan of procedure which our Society contemplates following in connection with the appointment of a staff, and the re-opening of this Institution, I beg to state that these will be as follows:-

1. Engagement of a Farmer. Mr. J. Murray Shaw, who was the Farm Instructor at the Blackfoot School and gave every satisfaction, has already been engaged in this capacity, and was placed on salary from the 1st of February. Mr. Shaw is not only thoroughly reliable, but thoroughly competent, and our Society engaged him as being one of the best men they could procure to advise them in all matters pertaining to equipment, such as implements, live-stock, feed, seed grain, etc., which will be required for the farming operations. As prices are liable to
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

advance as spring approaches, our Society beg to recommend that steps be taken at the earliest date possible for the purchase of the farming equipment, live-stock, and seed-grain, mentioned in my letter of February 9. As Mr. Shaw will probably be a much better judge of these things than the Principal or any other man our Society could appoint for the purpose, I beg to suggest in view of this fact, that he be given permission to act on behalf of the Principal, along with your representative in purchasing all the agricultural implements, live-stock, seed-grain, fodder, etc., which will be required for the beginning of the farming operations.

2. The appointment of a Principal. The Principal should reach the School by April 1, if possible, and certainly not later than the 1st of May. His immediate duty would consist of superintending all the repairs to the buildings, and in furnishing our Commission with requisitions for all supplies necessary, as well as reports on the progress of repairs, etc.

3. The appointment of a Vice-Principal, and other members of the staff would follow as they are required until the staff was completed. During the summer months, and after the Vice-Principal has been appointed, the Principal would be free to travel through different centres and bring in the children, and it is hoped that everything would be in readiness for the opening of the School on October 1.

Mr. Scott:

If it is your intention to proceed with the re-opening of the Elkhorn Industrial School, I would be pleased to have your sanction for the following action. As you are aware, we have over $4,000 in a special account, and there is in the main estimates an item of $3,000 in this connection:

1. To instruct Mr. Commissioner Graham to have the lessee, Mr. Dixon, vacate the principal's residence and the farm. Mr. Dixon's lease expired at the end of the last harvest season.

2. To instruct Mr. Graham to have our inspector proceed to Elkhorn and, in conjunction with a Mr. Shaw, who is at present occupying the farmer's house and who has been appointed, temporarily, by the M. S. C. C. to the position of farmer, to purchase, after securing competitive prices, seed grain, feed, certain live stock and some agricultural implements. This equipment is detailed hereunder, and will cost in the neighborhood of $2,600.

3. To instruct our inspector to see that the principal's residence is in fair state of repair, so that it can be occupied at an early date by the new principal.

4. To authorize our representative, in conjunction with the Rev. Principal, to engage a carpenter and plumber and other labour that may be necessary to go over the main and other buildings.

5. To ascertain what equipment Mr. Commissioner Graham has in the Regina storehouse, that would be suitable for the re-opening of the institution.

6. To purchase, after securing minute numbers from the Purchasing Commission, such other furniture and equipment as is necessary to the proper conduct of the school.

7. To assist the M. S. C. C. and their local representatives, financially and otherwise, in their recruiting campaign.

8. To make some provision for the initial expenses of the members of the staff on duty at the school, before classroom activities commence.

The action indicated above can be taken when timely, and as the activity develops.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th inst. (No. 116823-1), in reply to mine of the 27th ult., with reference to the funds in the hands of Mr. W. M. Graham, Indian Commissioner, resulting from the sales at the closing of the Elkhorn Industrial School. In that letter you state that the intention was to use these funds for the purchase of necessary equipment at the re-opening of the Elkhorn school, by doing which the appropriation for Indian education would be supplemented.

This proposed method of supplementing your vote is entirely at variance with the principle of parliamentary control over expenditure and with the provisions of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act. Section 2 of that Act defines the term "Public moneys". Section 25 of the same Act directs that all public moneys, from whatever source of revenue derived, shall be paid to the credit of the Receiver General; Section 41 directs that the Auditor General shall see that no cheque issues for the payment of any public money for which there is no direct parliamentary appropriation.

These provisions of the Act form, in my opinion, an insurmountable difficulty against the proposed use of the funds in question, which should be deposited forthwith to the credit of the Receiver General as Casual Revenue.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Edwards:

The Department, in conjunction with the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, is re-opening the Elkhorn Industrial School, in Manitoba. This institution has been closed for some years, and as the number of children in this vicinity is limited, I have made arrangements for the reception of 40 orphan, destitute and any other Protestant Indian children that are available in the Lac Seul and contiguous areas.

You will please keep these facts in mind during the next two months and make out a list of the names, ages and localities of the children that could be taken or recruited for Elkhorn. Early in September an officer of the school, acting under our instructions, will report to you for assistance in locating and gathering these children for their journey, ensemble, to the school.

It is understood that only Protestant children will be recruited, and I would like you to give preference to those who are either orphan or destitute. You may assure parents, guardians and others that the Elkhorn Industrial School is splendidly situated on the main line of the C. P. R. and every opportunity will be given the children to receive an academic and vocational training that will fit them for lives of usefulness. It has occurred to me that you have a splendid opportunity to prepare lists of available applicants during the treaty payments.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I visited the Elk Horn Indian Residential School on the 16th of July and was much impressed by the splendid condition of the main building and the principal's residence. There has been a complete renovation and a replacement wherever necessary and these two buildings are practically as good as new. The management has done commendable work in putting the school grounds in shape and working the farm. I was considerably deceived by the nature of the soil on the school farm and, upon making enquiry, I learned that it was extremely doubtful if any of the neighbouring properties would be of value. I learned that the M. S. C. G. had requested the Department to purchase a half section from a Colonel MacKee. Mr. Menzies, the farm instructor of the school, does not consider the land suitable and not worth more than $10 an acre.

The building is well equipped and the only requirement brought to my attention was a hotel size hand power mangle for the laundry. I purpose assisting their boys' activity by supplying a snare drum and 5 bugles.

I was impressed with the Rev. Mr. Riley's ability and his interest in the work. His staff appears to be but fair. The assistant, Mr. Dawson, has great possibilities but is evidently not satisfied with the work.

I intend to protest to Dr. Westgate concerning the M. S. C. G. lettering on equipment that has been purchased from Parliamentary appropriation and will suggest the name of the school instead. The outbuildings are scattered and are in only fair condition. The drill hall is in poor condition.

I knew very little about stock but was not impressed with the cattle that had been purchased for the school. They were producing very little milk per head at the time of my visit.

Supt. of Indian Education.

There are experiences which live in the memory, and become a source of constant inspiration. Such an experience was mine when I visited the Anglican Indian Residential School at Elkhorn to attend the confirmation of 65 of its scholars, 35 boys and 30 girls. As we drove down the Main Drive to the residence of the Principal, the Rev. Fred Riley, we noted the tidy shipshape appearance of the grounds and buildings. Across the front entrance of the School was a banner with the words "WELCOME TO OUR BISHOP," and we could see by the faces of some of the children we passed that they meant it, and were all agog with excitement over the visit of their Bishop, and the coming Confirmation. At the supper hour we saw all the children, 127 of them, and very bright happy children they seemed to be as they marched in to their light cheery dining-room to the tune of "Onward Christian Soldiers." In the grace which was sung, and in the responsive service after supper, which was led by the Principal, they showed by their hearty response that they not only knew the service, but thoroughly enjoyed it. The Bishop spoke to them for a few minutes on Ascension Day and its message, and the close attention and eager response to his questions gave ample proof of an intelligence and an alertness of mind which would do credit to any body of children in Canada.

A splendid discipline prevailed, a discipline evidently based on loyalty to the School, and affection for the Principal and his staff, for there was an entire absence of fear and nervousness on the part of the scholars, every face was radiant with smiles and happiness. The Confirmation Service was held in the Parish Church, and the whole school was present, filling the entire body of the Church. The Rector of the Parish, Rev. J.E. Finch, conducted Evensong and the Rev. S.R. Hammond read the Lessons, and the hearty manner in which the congregation sang the responses and joined in the service would put to shame our average congregations.

Then the Confirmation Service. The Bishop spoke to the candidates from the last verse of Psalm 106: "Through God we shall do great acts," and they listened with rapt attention as he spoke to them in simple eloquent words of the mystery of Confirmation, and the possibilities of a life which possessed the consecratedness of Confirmation, and the Living Presence of the Holy Spirit. When the Rev. Principal presented the confirmees there was no question in the minds of any as to whether they were duly purposed, there was abundant proof in their earnest demeanour, and in the spiritual atmosphere which prevailed during the whole of the service, a thoroughly sound spiritual preparation. It was a most impressive and inspiring sight, those long lines of Indian Children as with earnest serious faces they came...
forward to receive the gift of the Holy Spirit in the laying on of hands. It was a service full of promise, a wonderful tribute to the work of Rev. Klay and those associated with him, and a striking commentary on the words of the text "Through God we shall do great acts".

The following morning we were shown over the School, and its various buildings. Everywhere there was the utmost cleanliness. Every room was bright and cheerful, and as comfortable as one could make it. The dormitories well lighted and aired, with the beds covered with the red and white counterpanes. The School-room with every facility for efficient work; the power-house, kitchen, store-rooms, everywhere evidence of careful businesslike management, and a keen eye for details.

A drive around the farm and an early lunch at the School brought to a close a most enjoyable visit. The Rev. Principal and Mrs. Klay were the souls of hospitality, and we left the town of Elkhorn feeling that the Canadian Church should know more of the wonderful work which under God's grace is being accomplished in the School by Rev. Klay and his staff. Let us not cease to pray for them that this work may continue to receive the abundant blessing of God.

S. R. H.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to inform you that I visited the Elkhorn Residential School on the 28th ultimo and noted conditions in a general way at this institution. I went through the school building from the basement to the top floor and found it clean and tidy throughout. I was particularly pleased with the basement. Last year there was rather a sour smell in the dairy; this has been eliminated and the air is pure and fresh throughout the building. The dormitories are kept well aired, and there was no disagreeable smell in any part of the building. The Principal informed me that they had no difficulty in keeping the building warm and comfortable during the severe winter months. I took particular notice of the condition of the boys' and girls' toilets throughout the building, and noted that they were kept in a clean condition. The inside toilets are being used regularly. I visited the septic tank which appears to be functioning in a satisfactory manner, as there is no disagreeable odour from the point where the fluid is discharged. The washrooms in the basement are small, and there has been practically no provision made for inside recreation rooms for the girls.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
There are now 129 pupils in the school, and they presented a cleanly appearance and were well clothed. There were four who were being kept in the infirmary on account of their physical condition. Dr. Johnson of Elkhorn looks after the health of the children at this institution and the Principal tells me he is giving very good satisfaction, being very thorough in connection with his work.

I visited the children's dining-room during their noon meal hour and noted the food they were getting. Their meal consisted of meat, potatoes, beans, a milk pudding and good bread. They appeared to have all they wanted to eat and I considered that they presented a well-nourished appearance. They had eleven cows milking at the time of my visit and the Farmer informed me that these cows were giving 22 gallons of milk per day. This would provide a little over a pint per head for the pupilage including the staff, but I may say that they do not get the full benefit of this milk as I found that they were making about 30 lbs. of butter a week, and a great deal of the milk given to the children is separated milk, which has not much food value.

**STAFF**

The staff at this school at the present time appear to be getting along very harmoniously. There have been a number of changes made recently. Miss Hart, the boys' supervisor, has been replaced by Miss Reed, and Mrs. Duncan who was cook has been replaced by Mrs. Hall. Mr. Harris succeeded Mr. Minnielly as Farming Instructor and Mr. W. A. Harrison succeeded Mr. Tate as engineer.
I gathered that previous to the making of these changes there was a lack of harmony and co-operation and a great deal of back-biting amongst the staff, which had a bad effect on the work. I regret to report that the Principal and his wife spoke very strongly regarding the attitude taken by Nurse Colvin when she visited the school last winter.

Mr. Eley complains that she sided with the malcontents and interfered in matters which were not her concern at all, and it had the effect, not only of disturbing the harmony but set a bad example to the children by criticising the Principal of the school in their presence. Mr. Eley, as I said before, spoke very strongly, and said that while he would welcome the visits of any nurse which might be sent, he did not want Nurse Colvin to be permitted to return to the school. There were certain charges made by this Nurse in her report of last February, regarding the treatment of the children by Miss Hart, the boys' supervisor. As Miss Hart is no longer at the school I consider this matter closed. I found the discipline at the school very good, and saw or heard nothing which would lead me to think that the children were not receiving kindly and sympathetic treatment.

With reference to the statement made by the Nurse, that children were sent to the dormitories at supper time for three weeks with only dry bread to eat and nothing to drink, as a punishment for laughing at table, the Principal said that this was a deliberate mis-statement of facts. He stated that in some instances children were sent to the dormitories as a punishment for infraction of discipline, but in all such cases their meals were taken to them
in the dormitories; they were not deprived of their food. He stated that he attempted to explain this matter to Nurse Colvin and she would not believe him. He considered her attitude towards him in connection with this matter as insulting.

The foregoing will show you the feeling towards the Nurse at this school. I was, of course, only able to hear one side of the story, as the other parties affected by the report are no longer there and I feel it my duty to let you know the situation as it was presented to me. I may say, however, that I heard enough while at the school to convince me that the situation was an impossible one, and it is my opinion that the Nurse showed a lack of tact in permitting such a situation to arise in connection with her visit. It appears to me that she took upon herself responsibilities that she should have passed on to the Doctor, and to the Principal of the school. For example, I noticed a list of 67 children posted up in the dispensary for whom she had ordered tonics. It seems to me that instead of taking this action she should have referred these cases to the Doctor for attention. In any event it is wrong, and not conducive to getting results to have such a spirit of antagonism existing between officers of the Department.

STOCK

I may say that I found the stock in good condition. The cows have a much healthier and better cared for appearance than they presented at the time of my visit about a year ago.
The Farming Instructor is a married man and is living in the farm house. He appears to be a very energetic worker and the Principal is greatly pleased with him. They have the following acreage seeded to crop this year:

- 75 acres Crops
- 23 " Barley
- 10 " Corn
- 3 " Sunflowers
- 11 " Potatoes
- 5 " Garden

This leaves 30 acres of land for summerfallow.

Their farm land is badly infested with noxious weeds, particularly twitch grass, which is a very difficult weed to eradicate. In my opinion they should have at least one-third of their cultivated land in summerfallow until they get it cleaned up.

I may say in conclusion that the appearance of the premises at this institution indicate that the Principal is taking an interest in his work. I noted an improvement in the whole appearance of the place since my last visit. Owing to the place having been neglected for so long it will take a little time to get it into first class condition.
