Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, concerning complaints by parents of pupils of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. A thorough investigation into conditions at this school was made by Mr. Inspector Murison two months ago. I am satisfied that the stories that have been brought to your ears are in the main ill-founded. As you are aware, it is quite common for Indian parents, who do not wish their children to remain at a residential school, to do everything possible to delay their return after the expiration of the holiday period.

Mr. Inspector Murison was specifically requested to enquire into discipline, diet and health conditions and I am pleased to state that he found the building clean, tidy and comfortable throughout. The pupils were clean and well clothed and their diet very satisfactory. He reports that the medical officer is painstaking in his efforts; that the present staff are working as a unit; that the discipline is very good and that he believes the children are receiving kindly and sympathetic treatment.

I am satisfied that it is in the best interests of the children of your agency, who are on leave from the Elkhorn School, to return promptly at the end of their summer leave. I should be grateful if you would bend every energy to this end. Some months ago there was difficulty at the school, largely due to lack of harmony among the members of the staff. Changes in the personnel have eliminated this trouble, which was indirectly creating considerable dissatisfaction on the part of the pupils themselves.

You should inform Indian parents that the Department is carefully supervising the conditions at the Elkhorn School; that we believe them to be very satisfactory and that their children must be returned.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that I visited the Elkhorn Industrial School, for the purpose of investigating certain charges made against the Principal, by Indian Agent Ogilvie of the Portage la Prairie Agency. I felt that I would like to go down to the school personally, in order that I might see for myself just how things were, and I must say that I was agreeably surprised. The whole school building, from basement to garret, I found in immaculate condition. I visited the dormitories and found good comfortable beds, with plenty of blankets and sheets on each bed, and the bedding was clean. The Matron informed me that the flannelette sheets are changed once every two weeks, which I think is quite often enough. I tested the waterworks in each dormitory and found them in splendid shape. The windows were all down and the dormitories well ventilated. On making inquiry I was told that these windows are kept open continuously except when there is a pouring rain or heavy snow. I examined the clothing supply and found it to be abundant, in fact I would say enough to equip a school with double the number of pupils. The underclothing of the boys and girls is changed regularly, and each child has a bath once a week. I next visited the dispensary and found it in the very best of shape. A complete record is kept of what has been given to each child in the way of drugs, and the result. The dining-room was in perfect order; stables and floor were shining, and the kitchen was all that could be desired. The engine room and boiler room were like the engine room of a ship.

I then visited the pumping, sewage and lighting plant in a separate building, where I found everything in splendid shape. The stables were also in good order. The roots have been harvested and I am told the school will have about 1800 bushels of potatoes, a large quantity of carrots - sufficient for their use during the winter, and over 2000 cabbages. The driveway leading up to the school was in excellent shape, and is just such a driveway as one would expect to see at a well-kept, well-run institution.

The school have thirteen Holstein cows, which were giving about twelve gallons of milk per day at the time of my visit. This, of course, is not sufficient. They also have five horses, four sows and 25 chickens.

The field crop consists of 2500 bushels oats and barley. Their summerfallow has given them a lot of trouble, as it is polluted with twitch grass. The land has been plowed twice and disced four or five times and it is just a mass of twitch grass roots. It will take a lot of work and time to eradicate this weed.

I examined all the children in the school, and with two exceptions I never saw a healthier lot. One boy has a slight enlargement of the neck, and the other a small swelling behind the ear. Both these cases are being attended to by the Doctor. I went into the question of food supply, and I find that it appears to be ample, although it might be well to increase the milk supply and add a little more meat. In this the Doctor agrees with me, but he will not admit that they are underfed, and I quite agree with him. My recommendation is that they do not use separated milk for the children, but give them the whole milk, and instead of twelve gallons a day they should have twenty. When this is supplied, conditions would be ideal. I saw the children at their evening meal, which consisted of three thick slices of bread spread with pure lard, a bowl of hot soup, stewed prunes, and tea with sugar and milk, - rather a fair meal, I would say. They were not restricted to the quantity of bread mentioned, but could have more if they asked for it. The tables are supervised by two members of the staff, who remain with the children during the meal. In the mornings they receive oatmeal porridge with sugar and milk or syrup, bread with lard or jam and tea. Before leaving the school I made it a point to see the Doctor, and he informs me that in his opinion the children are well fed, but that it might be well to have a little more milk, and also a little added to the beef supply. I have requested the Principal to add a little more meat to the menu, and to see that the children get whole milk instead of separated milk.

I have before me your letter of September 8th., containing an excerpt from Mr. Ogletree's letter of August 11th, in which he states that the parents will not consent to any children returning to Elkton. It seems to me that if the parents thought they could keep their children at home from school they would not be above trying to trump up excuses for the purpose, especially if the Agent encourages them in this by believing everything they tell him, without endeavoring to obtain the true facts of the case. His recommendation that the children should be allowed to remain at home on their reserves for a year until matters are improved is absurd. This school is as well conducted as any school we have in the province. The Agent says that he does not think the Department can blame these parents very much for not sending their children back to Elkton. I blame the parents very much, and I do not think they had very much encouragement from the Agent to send them back. On the 10th. of August last, Mr. Ogletree wrote to Mr. Eley, complaining of certain children who had returned home from the school suffering from T.B. glands. Amongst others he mentioned Peter Moar. This boy had not been in school for over a year, as he did not return from holidays in 1925. Another case was that of Mary Ann Moar, whom the Principal states is not and
never has been enrolled at Elkhorn School. Helen and Mary Ahmo are also mentioned as being ill as a result of treatment received at Elkhorn school, neither of whom are or ever were enrolled there. I do not think the Department need go much further into Agent Ogletree's statements. There is no justification for his remarks at all. The lack of his going in and making complaints about children returning home sick from the school, who have never been there, is sufficient proof to me that he does not know very much about the subject he is dealing with. I think Agent Ogletree should be severely censured for sending in such unfounded and damaging reports on this school. You know as well as I do that any person who wants to listen to the complaints of the Indians and agree with them can make a great deal of trouble, and I believe that is what has been done in this case.

My recommendation is that the Department supply this school with four additional horses, as they have only five at the present time, which number is not sufficient for their needs. I would also ask that they be given four more cows, which owns. I think the Department should insist on the school being filled to a capacity of 120 pupils without delay, as I feel sure the children who are attending this school are getting as good a training as they would get anywhere in the West. I found a well balanced staff here. The female members, from the cook to the matron, were all dressed in white uniforms, such as are worn by nurses. The Farming Instructor knows his business, and judging from the condition in which I found the engines and machinery in general, I would say the engineer is well qualified. The Principal has no Assistant, as the man who was filling this position was recently transferred to Alberta. I hope no time will be lost in providing him with an Assistant, as he will have too much to do with the full number of children in the school. At the time of my visit there were 69 children in residence.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

2. With respect to the charges made by the Indians, I beg to make the following statements:
   1. These sick cases were direct result of these pupils being sent to the School. This is obviously impossible, as tubercular diseases are of slow growth and development, and, while T.B. in some form is present in all these children it usually manifests itself in an active form at ages varying from 12 to 18 years. In addition to this fact when these children were brought in their general health etc., was so poor, that there was serious discussion as to the advisability of keeping them here, since when every effort was made to improve their health.
   2. These children were not clothed properly. These children were living in such poverty and dirt that they had no clothing fit to stand the rough cold journey. Therefore, before they could come into the school we were obliged to send them a supply of warm clothing, which they wore to come in to the school. In spite of this they arrived in a filthy condition, infested with head lice and other vermin. Upon leaving here this summer for holidays, every child was provided with a bountiful lunch, a complete outfit of clean clothing and a kit-bag (bearing pupil's name, number, and the name of the school) containing an additional supply of clothing. List of outfit is attached to this statement.
   3. The children got bad treatment while sick. The medical care of the children is in the hands of the Medical Officer appointed by the Department of Indian Affairs, and under him, the Matron and Supervisors carry out every recommendation and order for the care of sick children. The dispensary work is regulated and supervised by the Medical Officer, and the treatment given the children is exactly what they would receive at the General Hospital in Winnipeg or any other large hospital. It is in every way superior to that given to white children in attendance at ordinary Boarding Schools. This I know from personal experience. In cases where a special diet is advised, everything is done, in our power, to follow it out.
   4. Children had to work too hard and were compelled to play in the cold and snow. The children are not overworked in any way, and if at any time a child seems tired, the person in charge of that department arranges a change. At no time are the children compelled to play out in the cold and snow. On the contrary, the supervisors have to exercise vigilance to prevent the children from playing out in unsuitable conditions.

In reference to the statement that seven out of the eleven children examined should be in hospital, I can only repeat that these children were all seen by the M.O. before leaving here. As a matter of fact all the Indian children are suffering to a greater or less extent from syphilis or tuberculosis in some form, and should, therefore, be undergoing hospital treatment. Unfortunately, in some cases the evil was too deep-seated, and developed in spite of the best care.

I have no hesitation in saying that I, with the rest of the staff, have looked after these children physically, mentally and morally as very few white children are looked after. Therefore, on their behalf I take great exception to the statements made by this or any Indian Agent in this respect. The hours of supervision are practically eighteen hours a day, so the last duty at night is a trip through the dormitories, etc., to make sure that all is well.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

With reference to your letter of the 29th inst. re Mr. Wheeldon, I beg to inform you that upon hearing from him a statement endorsed by Dr. Johnson will be sent forward without delay, as per your instructions.

Last June certain rumours were in circulation, which, I feel certain we can trace back to Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree of Portage la Prairie. Undoubtedly he is doing his best, in his way, to secure a new Principal for the Elkhorn School, and behind all this, I feel, is Mr. Minnelli who is, Form Instructor in Mr. Ogletree's Agency.

When interviewing Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham last week, he kindly read a copy of letter received from Ottawa, written by Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree, in which was stated the fact that he, as Indian Agent, would not return the children from his agency to the Elkhorn School until a new Principal was appointed. Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham also read me his reply, in which he stated that a year ago when his Inspector visited Elkhorn, things were in a flourishing condition; but he would not commit himself at present as to whether conditions were right or wrong now. But he was of the opinion that it was not a new Principal they required, but a new Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, as he had often stated before. Confidentially, the Commissioner also told me that Indian Agent Ogletree gave him more trouble than all his other Agents put together. The Commissioner stated he would come down with his Inspector before very long and investigate things at the School then he would write Ottawa. Hence one reason for my not getting into Winnipeg this week.

Mr. Wheeldon, as you no doubt know, is teacher at Sandy Bay, Indian School. Councillor J. G. Shorting (Indian) whom you sent down last week to inspect the School, is also from Sandy Bay, the same Reserve. I believe that his impressions of the School were entirely favourable, as he seemed exceedingly pleased with everything here. Therefore, he should be a help to Mr. Wheeldon at this time.

Dr. C. W. Johnston, who is the Medical Officer appointed by the Dept. for this School, has been outside of his professional visits, a frequent visitor at all times of the night and day. Therefore, he has seen the children under all conditions, sickness, work, and play. We have on several occasions discussed matters such as: food, clothing, sanitation, recreation. Several times he has brought visiting Doctors and Specialists to inspect the School and their comments have always been highly favourable. After consulting him with Dr. Johnston this morning about this matter, he gave me his double assurance that he would both sign statements and testify as to general conditions and health.

I herewith enclose a copy of letter dated August 10th, from Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree, also have attached notes on letter which may be of assistance to you. You will also find list of clothing, etc., which each boy and girl had in their kit-bag when leaving.

Sir:-

I beg to submit the following information with regard to the difficulty I have had with Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree of Portage la Prairie regarding the returning of children after Holidays from his Agency to this School, also his failure to carry out the Department's instructions with regard to the sending of five children of Mrs. Alfred Hourie of the Fairford Reserve to this School.

On August 12th, 1925 the said Indian Agent wrote to me and in a letter mentioned that the parents were dissatisfied with things at Elkhorn. He also made the statement that "if half the stories they tell me are true I do not blame these people for refusing to have their children returned to school". And by the tone of the letter one would take it that he did not intend to have them returned. Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree visited the school on a previous occasion and certainly was in a position to advise and tell the people the conditions at Elkhorn himself. It seems to me that he is given to listening to any story that may come along which has absolutely no foundation.

After reporting to the said Indian Agent on November 3rd, 1925 the request made by Chief Woodhouse of the Fairford Band with reference to the admitting of the Hourie children to Elkhorn, I received a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree on November 20th, 1925 stating that he had received instructions from Ottawa to return all children who had not returned from Holidays also the five of Mrs. Alfred Hourie of Fairford. This latter has never been carried out and when taking the matter up again I received a letter from you, Sir, as the Indian Commissioner, on March 15th, 1926 advising me that the agent at Portage la Prairie had been written to by the Department at Ottawa directing him to give this matter immediate attention. Since that time I have heard nothing further, but the children have not been brought to the School.

On March 22nd, 1926 I wrote Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree again upon receiving a letter from the Lord Bishop of Brandon telling me of four children living at Shoal River who should be sent to the Elkhorn School. This information I passed on in the letter mentioned above to the Indian Agent asking him to be good enough to look into the matter and advise me. In reply, received a letter dated March 25th, 1926 from Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree stating that it would be better to wait until June and bring the children down after Treaty Payments. Moreover, he invited me in this letter to accompany him on the trip to Shoal River for Treaty Payments. However, for some unknown reason he wrote me on April 28th, 1926 to the effect that his plans had changed but if he decided to go to Shoal River later he would let me know. Since that date I have heard nothing in regard to his trip or the children.

Upon receiving instructions from the Department at Ottawa regarding Holidays for the Summer of 1926 I wrote to each Indian Agent giving them the said information, and also gave word for word the paragraph with reference to the fact that children were not allowed to go home unless special protection was made for the safeguard of their return at the expiring of their holidays, to the school.
Moreover, in spite of this Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree sent word through others ordering the returning of most of the children from his Agency. As I did not have Transportation Requisitions on hand at the time word was sent back to the Indian Agent to this effect. The following Sunday morning during Divine Service he called up the School by Long Distance. The Matron answered the telephone and I am told by Miss Lindsay that Mr. Ogletree was decidedly rude to her. Tickets were then wired by the Indian Agent to Elkhorn and the children went home for their holidays.

You will understand, Sir, on account of the geographical situation of this school, the difficulties of obtaining children etc. to fill the School. When we have the co-operation of Indian Agents and Missionaries one does not mind but if an Indian Agent like Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree is allowed to take such a stand it seems to me that he is seriously hindering not only the work of this School but the Great Work of The Department in the education of Indians.

I am, Sir, putting the best years of my life into this work on account of the early years spent on the Indian Reserves and conditions witnessed there. I am fully of the opinion that children in residence in such a school as this are certainly given a chance in life, if they wish to make use of it later on, a chance they would never have living on an Indian Reserve.

I shall be most grateful and appreciate it very much, Sir, if you will kindly give me advice upon such a matter stated. Thanking you for your kindness and interest in the past.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Fred Eley.
Principal.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to your letter of the 9th September No. 106-0-1 and subsequent correspondence, with reference to the difficulty in getting the children to return to the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, and the suggestion of Indian Agent Ogletree that an investigation be held into the manner in which the children are treated at that institution, I beg to inform you that I again visited the Elkhorn school last week for a few hours, and while there I examined the children and have nothing to say further than what was said to you in my letter of the 8th October last. I think that the Principal is doing good work, but he is laboring under many disadvantages. I am quite sure that Mr. Ogletree, the Indian Agent at Portage, from which agency a great many of the children come, is of very little assistance to him, and Mr. Eley's work is made more difficult on that account.

Mr. Ogletree is holding down a good position at Portage la Prairie, and a great deal could be done there if we had the right kind of an Agent. He is most disagreeable with everybody and he is not aggressive. I have no faith in his ability to carry out any important instructions, and it seems too bad that this man should stand in the way of the progress of the Indians. The Swan Lake reserve in the Portage Agency has made most outstanding progress in the last four years; it has come up from nothing to be one of the most progressive reserves in the country, and the Government should be proud of it. At Long Plain there has also been progress. This is attributable to the fact that the Inspectors and the Instructors are carrying it on almost independently of the Agent.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have returned from making a visit to the Elkhorn Indian Residential School and I was greatly pleased with all that I saw there. Mr. Eley is very energetic and has the place in good shape, and one of the most wonderful gardens I ever saw, about five acres in all. In addition to this he has ten acres of potatoes, 75 acres oats, 25 acres barley, and 30 acres of summerfallow. The work on the summerfallow was well done.

Mr. Eley has made arrangements with a farmer who owns 300 acres of hay land to cut and stack all the hay on this 300 acres, the school to get two-thirds of the quantity. In order that he might do this in short order and secure the hay I have taken it upon myself to authorize him to purchase another mowing machine, as it would be impossible to carry on this work with one machine in view of the large quantity of hay that will be put up, and also other pressing work. Ordinarily one machine would have done, but this is a great opportunity to secure hay and the extra machine is badly needed.

The children, some forty in number, who were at the school at the time of my visit were all in good health. The milk supply is quite adequate, and I am glad to report this because we have always had trouble here through not having a sufficient quantity of milk for the number of children, and this difficulty has now been overcome.

Dear Mr. Scott,

You will I am sure understand just what it all means to me giving up the work here, in the which I have been engaged since 1890, and parting with my girls and boys whom I have become so much attached to; but circumstances have been such as to bring this about and our school of which we have all been so proud has now practically passed out of existence much to our deep regret.

I do so trust, however, that the pupils who have gone out from here will make good use of the training they have received and will succeed in the various occupations of life they may enter and so reflect credit on themselves and their Alma Mater.

In regard to myself, I may say that for several years past I have felt the strain of Institution Life and the heavy responsibilities connected with it and as you know I have also had family sorrows to bear all of which have helped to bring about a very much run-down condition of health.

Dr. Goodwin, under whose treatment I have been for sometime past says, that, I am quite broken down in health and that it is absolutely necessary that I have a complete rest for a protracted period, and he has given me a certificate of health to this effect, a copy of which is herewith enclosed.

I feel the need of a complete change and rest for a good long period; but It would be impossible for me to consider

Duncan C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa.
consider having this, unless the Department would kindly grant me an extended leave of absence on salary.

After I have settled up my affairs here I will have little left, and it would be out of the question for me to think of taking the rest I need, unless I were on salary and had the means to provide for the expense I would be under while away and the support of those who are dependent on me.

I should feel most grateful to the Department, if a year's leave of absence on salary were granted to me, and I trust, owing to the condition of my health, the long service I have had and the sudden termination of what I had so hoped would have been my life's work, that, my request will receive your kindly consideration.

I don't know just how long it may take to get everything packed up at the school and shipped away, if this should be the wish of the Department; but, I should be glad to be allowed to remain in our present home until July next, as this would allow of my children completing this school term and give me the time I want to go over the correspondence, returns, documents, etc., which have accumulated during the past 28 years and which will not again be required.

Dear Mr. Scott:

In my letter of the 15th inst., I thanked you for your exceedingly kind letter of the 11th inst., and said that I would reply to it more fully within the course of a few days. It was a great relief to me to receive your letter and I deeply appreciate the kindly consideration you have shown both for Miss Vidal and myself.

It is very difficult for me to know, just at the present time, what is really the best thing for me to do or what plans to make for the future, as so much depends on you and what you may consider advisable in my case.

For instance my Mother, who is very frail and in declining health, is very desirous that I should move out to B.C., with my family, and be near her during the closing years of her life. This is also what all the members of my family who are living there wish; but, more particularly since this school, which was established by my late Father, is now closed.

I should very much like to move out to B.C. after my work is finished here, but, more particularly for the Winter as I feel that the change and rest out there would be most beneficial not only to myself but also to Miss Vidal and the family. This would, however, necessitate heavy expenses in moving and as we would have no home to go to it would also mean renting a house which with the additional high cost of living would make it most difficult for me to manage on my present salary.

As regards continuing in the Service. Dear Mr Scott:

After receiving your kind letter of the 5th inst., I communicated with my Mother and relatives in B.C. and have since received word to the effect that it would be most unwise of me to go to the expense of moving my family and Miss Vidal out to the Coast without the assurance of some employment in the Service after my extended leave of absence should have expired. It would now appear that the only alternative is for myself, family and Miss Vidal to remain in our present home as long as you will kindly allow us to do so, and for me to get out and around as much as possible and in this way obtain the change and rest I so much need.

Memorandum:

Mr. Lynton,
Private Secretary to Honourable Dr. Tolmie,
Minister of Agriculture.

I have pleasure in giving you the facts regarding the claims of Mr. A.E. Wilson, formerly an officer of this Department, Principal of the Elkhorn Industrial school.

When this school was closed we endeavoured to accommodate Mr. Wilson with another position, but he found it impossible to accept anything that we could offer him, and he decided to take the year's leave of absence that we offered him in trying to obtain other employment, when he moved to Victoria, B.C.

When we were endeavouring to give him employment in the Department, it was suggested that he should be appointed clerk at the Blackfoot Agency with headquarters at Gleichen. I mention this now in order that you may understand the reason for one of the claims that he has made.

Mr. Wilson claims that his health was so impaired that he could not take proper advantage of the year's leave of absence, and in fact failed to establish himself as he had hoped.

In the first place, if I remember correctly, he asked for an additional year's leave of absence, but when I was in Victoria in 1920, he decided to claim from the Government $1,300, which he had spent in prizes and like disbursements when he was principal of the school, and this he supported by a statutory declaration. He also wished to be paid his travelling expenses from Elkhorn to Gleichen and sent in his account therefor. These were the principal claims he made.
I discussed the claims with the Minister, but he could not see his way clear to put an amount in the Estimates. This would be necessary. I was always willing to take this action, although I felt that we would be treating Mr. Wilson with great consideration by asking Parliament to recognize the claims. I thought it was preferable to put them before the Minister in this form than in the form of an additional year's leave of absence, which would also have required a vote of the House. There has been very generous sympathy for Mr. Wilson, and the Minister was not in any sense hostile to the claims but found it difficult to find reasons to support them.

I should be very glad, if Doctor Tolmie wishes, to take the matter up again with him and Sir James Loughhead, and to present the case in as favourable a light as possible. Unfortunately, Mr. Wilson's claim, supported by affidavits, has been mislaid, and as yet I have not been able to find it.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

With reference to the papers attached hereto, consisting of a claim made on behalf of Mr. A.E. Wilson by the Rev. E.A.P. Chadwick, of Victoria, B.C., I beg to report as follows:

Mr. A.E. Wilson was for many years the principal of an Indian industrial school at Elkhorn, Man. This school was the only institution conducted wholly by the Government. All our other residential schools are conducted by the denominations interested in them with the financial aid from the Government, but the Churches contribute generously towards the support of these schools. The cost of conducting this single Government institution was very much higher than the per capita grants paid to denominational schools and was, therefore, a constant mark for invidious comparisons. As it was difficult to get pupils for the school we decided to close it.

We endeavoured to find a place for Mr. Wilson in our service, but failed in that, as he did not find it possible to take a clerical position, and was not fitted either by temperament or experience for the position of Indian Agent.

Under these circumstances, we gave him a full year's leave of absence with pay, with the hope that he would establish himself and be successful. Unfortunately, it seems that this has not been the case, and he has applied to the Department for further consideration and assistance.

When I was in Victoria in 1920 I had several interviews with him. I think I may say that he preferred that his
claim should take the form of an additional year's leave with full pay, but as I pointed out that that was difficult to grant now that he had completely severed his connection with the service, he submitted the claim for $1,300.00, consisting of small amounts which he had spent in the interest of the school during the term of his principalship. This was supported by statutory declarations. He also wished to have his travelling expenses paid from Elkhorn, Man., to Gleichen, Alberta, and sent in an account therefor. Unfortunately these papers were mislaid and cannot at present be traced.

Mr. Wilson has had several influential men support his claim, and I am personally sympathetic with it, and have always so expressed myself to the Ministers who were dealing with it; although I must say that favourable treatment of the claim would be a remarkable precedent.

I am sending herewith copies of letter which I wrote to Chief Inspector Dittohurn, of Victoria, on June 25, 1921; a memorandum which I made for Mr. Lynton, Hon. Dr. S.F. Tolmie's Private Secretary, on November 9, 1921; and a letter which I wrote to the Hon. Dr. S.F. Tolmie on November 17, 1921.

I present the facts of the case somewhat in detail, as I see from Rev. Mr. Chadwick's letter that he thinks the action of the Government, (I presume he means the Department) most extraordinary, and that there was absolutely no reason for the treatment Mr. Wilson received. Mr. Wilson was fairly and considerately treated by both the Department and the Government.

It will be observed from my letter of November 17, 1921, that the matter was to be further considered by the Hon. Sir James Lougheed and the Government, and that I was to lay the matter before the Minister in due course. I am quite willing to do that now, and then it may be decided whether an item or items may be placed in the Estimates for the special purpose of relieving Mr. Wilson.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to the claim advanced by Mr. A. M. Wilson, late of the Elkhorn School, I thought it best to advise you that I am of the opinion that unless something is done in trying to meet his request you will not get much peace. As you, no doubt, are aware, some time ago he enlisted the sympathies of a number of prominent people in the city of Victoria and had the Rev. Mr. Chadwick write to the Honorable Arthur Meighen and Sir James Lougheed, the late Premier and Superintendent General of Indian Affairs respectively, advancing reasons why some compensation should be given to Wilson. This resulted in a letter from Hon. Dr. Tolmie, then the Minister of Agriculture, stating that the Government intended to ask Parliament to provide in the Estimates a sufficient amount to cover the claim, and everything appeared to be rosy for Mr. Wilson. I understand, however, that the new Government are not favourably disposed to doing anything in the way of carrying out the promises of the late Government in this particular case and Mr. Wilson and his friends have got very busy lately and had further letters written to the "powers that be." I thought it best to give you this information. I had an interview recently with Rev. Mr. Chadwick, who asked me if I could not do something in the matter but I absolutely refused, stating that it was a question entirely outside of my jurisdiction and that I did not care to take any official action in the matter nor did I care to express any opinion as to the merits or demerits of the case. To you, however, I may say officially that it may be possible that Mr. Wilson's claim has never been viewed from the standpoint of his being so long tied up in the Indian work in the Prairie Provinces and then being retired and as there were no commercial opportunities in the immediate vicinity of his field of activities it was necessary for him
to come to the Coast to try to recuperate his health and to establish himself in order that he might make a living. This naturally must have taken a considerable portion of the year's salary which he was paid on retirement and as the work in which he had been employed for so many years was so different from commercial life it would necessarily take him some time before he could settle himself down to meet the public and talk business. I may say that he is very far removed from being an up-to-date insurance agent so far. Possibly viewing the case from this angle might be sufficient to warrant a reconsideration in his favour. I may say that Mr. Wilson nor his friends do not know that I am writing this letter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. King,

I feel that I should again address you regarding the case of Mr. A.R. Wilson of Victoria, late Superintendent of the Indian School at Elk Horn. The reason for my doing so is that I had the honour recently of a most encouraging interview with Mr. Scott, Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs, when he was in Victoria.

Mr. Scott knows very thoroughly the details of the case, and is sympathetic towards Mr. Wilson.

I need not weary you at this time with all the reasons why Mr. Wilson should receive your best consideration, but I do feel that after nearly thirty years of service, and service of a most efficient and patriotic kind, as is attested by men and women of the highest standing in Canada, Mr. Wilson should receive a worthy financial recognition.

I feel that if you insisted that justice be rendered in this case it would have the required "punch" to bring it to pass.

So I plead with you to advise that either one of two things be done—

(1) A pension be granted for the amount he would have been entitled to if he had not been practically ejected, and remained till age for retirement, which would have been very soon.

(2) A special money grant of $2200.00 to pay or compensate for the unexpected and emergent expenses he was put to at the time of his retirement. (I know that he received some compensation at the time, but it proved to be altogether inadequate, and his necessary outlay in getting a house &c would in all conscience require far more than he received.

Mr. Wilson is in dire need at the present time, the blow has been too great for him, and it would only be a matter of human justice for him to receive what I now ask for him.

With many thoughts of the old times, and with continued wishes for your future success,

I remain Your sincerely,

F.A.P. Chadwick.

P.S. May I suggest that you convey this to Mr. King and Mr. W.R. Moirther will respond, etc?

MEMORANDUM RE LANDS AT THE ELKHORN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

In 1891, the Department purchased from the Rev. E. F. Wilson, for the purposes of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, Lots 4 to 11, in Block 2, and Lots 1 to 8 in Block 3, Plan 2939, town of Birtle. (Abstract of Title entered under #14.) The purchase price was $1,546.64. This was the site of the first school which was burned in 1895. Before rebuilding, it was decided to secure a better site.

On October 6, 1898, an Order in Council set apart Sec. 35, T. 11, R. 29, W.P., for the purposes of the Indian Industrial School at Elkhorn. This section had been relinquished by the C. P. R. for this purpose - the consideration being other lands. It was in error that this section was set aside for the Indian School. It was acquired for a trade with Mr. Wilcox, who owned land which was suitable. P. O. 2914, of December 30, 1898, rescinded the earlier O. C. and set apart, under Sec. 31, of the Dominion Lands Act.

(a) The S.W. ¼ of Sec. 4, and the S.E. ¼ of Sec. 5, T. 12, R. 28, W.P., excepting 4-1/5 acres in Sec. 5, which comprised the C. P. R. right of way.

(b) Lots 1, 2 and 3, in Block H. and all of Blocks K. & L., in the town of Birtle.

The certificates of Title for the parcels in A. and the deed for the parcels in B. were forwarded to the Interior Department with No. 116823 of October 31, 1898 (Interior Dept. File 178746). The parcels mentioned in A. had been owned by W. J. Wilcox, who had given a patent, by the Interior Department, to Section 35, which had been inadvertently set apart. The town lots mentioned in B., which are the actual site of the school buildings, were a free gift from the town of Birtle or the C. P. R., or both, account of the location of the Indian School at Birtle. These town lots were deeded on July 7, 1897, to the Federal Crown and were included when the Department of the Interior set apart lands for the school. It later developed that there had been a misunderstanding regarding the trade with Wilcox, and a Mr. Cushing, who acted for him, having pointed this out, received a special payment of $604.50 in lieu of the fact that the original town lots, which were purchased from Wilson in 1891, were not deeded to his client.

Order in Council of May 5, 1904, approved of a trade between the C. P. R. and the Department, whereby the N.W. ¼ of L.S. 14 of the N.W. ¼ of Sec. 35, T. 11, R. 28, W.P. (50 acres) was given to the Department for the purposes of the Elkhorn School, for a consideration of $150, and for 4.28 acres in the S.W. ¼ of Sec. 4, T.12, R.28, which was deeded to the C. P. R. as a gravel pit. A description of this gravel pit will be found on this file.

In 1901, it developed that the old town lots, the site of the original school, were not really required any longer. O. C. of March 23, 1906, authorized the Superintendent General to dispose of these lots. They were advertised for sale in January, 1913, and sold by auction on April 21, 1917. Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, inspected between November 20th and 22nd, 1932.

The junior room is in charge of Miss A. C. E. Field who was ill with rheumatism at the time of my visit. Miss Field is a qualified teacher, and from previous observation, I would judge that she is doing splendid work.

The senior classroom is in charge of Mr. Wm. H. Bradley who also acts as Assistant Principal. His classroom is only open during the afternoon on account of the extra duties falling on him due to the absence of Rev. Fred Eley, the Principal. The time table is so arranged that all the senior boys attend the classroom in the afternoon, and thus the half day system is carried out. In September Mr. Bradley was ill for two weeks, therefore the classroom work has been somewhat interrupted.

The children were all well dressed, clean and tidy in appearance. The discipline, both in the classrooms and around the building, was good and the children are well mannered. At present there are 95 pupils in residence, and these, with the 6 absentees, bring the total up to 101. Mr. Bradley informed me that they could accommodate 120 pupils.

The kitchen is supervised by Miss Plant, and the food appeared well prepared. The food served

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

November 22nd
November 22nd was as follows:

Breakfast - Porridge with milk & sugar, Bread with syrup; Tea & cocoa for the small children.

Lunch - Vegetable soup, bread, tea, milk, and milk pudding (rice).

Dinner - Beans, bread & jam, tea & cocoa

The children were in good health and according to the chart of weights all, with the exception of one or two, show fair gains. The food served was wholesome and well prepared, but, as noted by the menu, vegetables or meat do not play a large part.

The laundry work is supervised by Miss Shaw. The laundry is well equipped. Monday is used as wash day, and Tuesday and Wednesday for ironing. The balance of the week Miss Shaw spends in the sewing room teaching the girls to mend, etc. A few new clothes are made, but most of the children's clothes are provided by the church societies and arrive ready to wear. This arrangement is a great help to the Principal, but does not give the girls much opportunity to learn sewing, and this is one side of their training which should be stressed.

The dairy and bakery is supervised by Miss Smith. In this department the girls do most of the work, and as a result, are good bread-makers. Small bakes and buns are made from time to time, but bread required for the children is made in large quantities and mixed by a power mixer. Bread is made four times a week, each of the three mixings, 100 lbs. of flour is used; the fourth baking on Saturdays requires 200 lbs. The bread seen was of
seen was of good quality and wholesome. At present the milk is all used for the children and baking, but later, when the cows begin to freshen, butter-making will again be carried on.

The boys' supervisor is Miss Harvey. She has charge of their dormitories and playroom. I found these to be tidy, well aired, and clean. The toilets were all in good condition, and both tube clean. Some of the mattresses are in poor condition - in fact, a number have been replaced by the use of cotton ticks filled with straw.

The girls are supervised by Miss Topping, and she is apparently rendering good service. The girls' dormitories were in good condition, and all wash basins and toilets in working order.

The fire escape door in the senior girls' dormitory was locked, but the other doors were unlocked. In my last report dated November 28th, 1931, I recommended that these doors be wired and attached to the fire alarm. This would safeguard anyone opening the door to enter or leave, unknown to the staff, and would do away with the locks. I still think this precaution should be taken. The light switches for the dormitories have been changed as recommended, and are a great improvement. I had two fire drills while at the school, one during the day and one during the night. The children got along well and were out in less than four minutes. The engineer, Mr. Caniff, keeps all the fire equipment in good condition, and extinguishers and axes can be found on each floor. The fire alarm bells appear too small, and when the laundry and pump are operating, it is difficult to hear the alarm throughout the basement. Larger bells should be installed.
installed or an additional one placed in the laundry. The engineer is capable of doing this work and only the material would be required.

The Matron, Miss C. L. Gibson, is a graduate nurse, and appears a capable woman for the position. Miss Gibson is a new appointment since my last visit.

The garden did not yield well, and by Christmas they will have very few vegetables except potatoes. The potato crop was also light, and the supply will hardly last until spring.

The farm crops were poor, but they are fortunate in having sufficient rough feed.

The cattle are in fair condition, and within the next few months several cows will freshen. The cattle stabled number about 20 head. In addition to this stock, they have 11 horses and about 16 pigs. At present no poultry is kept.

The interruptions in the classroom work, due to sickness, is very unfortunate, and, in cases of prolonged sickness, a substitute teacher should be provided.

The Principal, Rev. Fred Eley, had not returned from England, where he has been spending some weeks in the hopes of regaining better health. Mr. Bradley, the Acting Principal, I believe, is doing good work and, during the absence of the Principal, has handled the situation well.

Yours very truly,

ELKHORN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
(Diocese of Brandon)
ELKHORN - MANITOBA

School Crest
WHERE IS IT?

The Elkhorn Indian Residential School is located on the main line of the C.P.R. It is about ¼ mile from the village of Elkhorn and 197 miles west of Winnipeg.

The School property, which belongs to the Dominion Government, consists of the main building, three residences, barns, implement sheds, granaries and other outbuildings that go to make up a well-equipped school and farm.

In addition there are 320 acres of arable land. The quarter section on which the buildings stand includes a large vegetable garden and pasture for cattle and horses.

The School rents a further 480 acres of land adjoining the Federal property and most of this is under cultivation.

WHAT IS ITS HISTORY?

The history of the Elkhorn Indian School has three distinct chapters.

The first chapter started in 1885 when the Rev. E. F. Wilson, founder and principal of the Indian Home at Sault Ste. Marie, took a journey through the North West and was impressed with the needs for a school similar to the one he had already established.

On his return to Ontario he endeavored to raise funds to bring such benefits to the Indians of the plains.

Unsuccessful at first, he resolved to make a last effort. He issued a pamphlet setting forth the need and stating that if anyone would give $1,000.00 to make a beginning he would go forward in faith and leave the rest with God.

This pamphlet fell into the hands of Mr. Rowsowell of Elkhorn, who offered the $1,000.00 required. This gift was supplemented by others and the Dominion Government then came forward with a grant.

The new home was opened on June 10th, 1888, with four pupils and one teacher. These four children stood the new and unusual life for twelve days and then all ran away together!

Others arrived, however, and on August 6th, 1889, the home was formally opened by Archbishop Macray and given its name, "Washakada Indian Home," out of compliment to Mr. Rowsowell, whose Indian name was "Washakada," meaning "all that is good."

In 1892, Mr. A. E. Wilson, son of the founder, was appointed and the success of the school was assured.

The School was at this time situated in the village itself and pupils came to it from reserves as far distant as the Blackfoot and Blood. Many came from pagan homes and accepted Christian baptism while
under tuition. Bootmaking, printing, tailoring, carpentering, tinsmithing and harness making were taught by trade instructors. Some of these instructors were resident at the School and others were local tradesmen who accepted Indian boys as apprentices.

In 1895 a destructive fire consumed most of the buildings. Within three days, however, the work was resumed in other rented premises in the village.

The second chapter opened when the Government decided to erect a new and substantial pile of buildings on the present site, which would make more extensive farming operations possible.

1897 saw the new plant occupied and under the efficient work of Mr. Wilson, who gave his best years to the Indian, the School held a leading place among the institutions of its kind.

In 1918, the Federal Department made a change of policy, which, unfortunately, resulted in the closing of the Elkhorn Indian Home after three decades of splendid service.

The third chapter started in 1923, when it was decided to make extensive alterations and additions to the School which had been vacant and neglected.

The Rev. F. Eley acted as Principal during the difficult period of reconstruction and in January, 1923, the first new pupils were admitted. The School was reopened under the administration of the Indian Residential School Commission of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

Mr. Eley, who gave ten years of constant service, won for the School a reputation for efficiency and discipline.

The present Principal was appointed in August, 1933.

WHERE DO THE CHILDREN COME FROM?

The Elkhorn School is unique in that although a school for Indians it is not located near to any Indian reserves.

The nearest Reserve is at Griswold, over fifty miles away, whence come the Sioux Indians—a non-treaty band—originally refugees from the United States, seeking sanctuary in Canada.

In addition to the Sioux there are Crees, Ojibway and Saulteaux children coming from Fairford, Lake St. Martin, Little Saskatchewan, Scantebury, Peguis, Fort Alexander and the many reserves north of The Pas, reaching up to York Factory and Port Nelson on the Hudson Bay, 1,000 miles away.

January 1st, 1935, saw 155 pupils in residence, ranging in ages from four years to seventeen years, and coming from about sixteen different reserves.

WHAT ARE THEY TAUGHT?

In the schoolrooms the curriculum of the Provincial Department of Education is followed and the Provincial Inspector makes regular visits, as in the White schools.

There are at present two classrooms and the children attend school on one half day each day. The Grades go up to and include Grade VII. One girl is doing her Grade XI. at the High School in town.

The Junior Class Room

The many bench trades taught in Mr. Wilson's time, forty years ago, are no longer on the curriculum, but more emphasis is put on farming, gardening and kindred occupations.

Sawing Wood
During the half day out of classrooms the boys work on the School farm under the direction of the Farm Instructor. While the senior boys handle the farm, others work in the garden or care for the herd of 35 Holstein cattle and attend to the horse barns, piggery, etc. Rough carpentering, engineering, painting and incidental work is done as occasion demands.

The girls put 2,000 garments through the Laundry every week, about half of these being repaired in the Sewing Room under the direction of the Sempstress.

Butter making is taught in the Dairy and more than 700 loaves are baked every week in the School Bakery.

In addition, the boys milk the cows, assist in the Dairy and Laundry. They wash dishes, lay tables, make beds, scrub and sweep.
General cooking is done in the main kitchen and the girls perform other necessary duties of housekeeping in various parts of the building.

The success of the children in the classroom and practical arts is illustrated by the fact that at the Regina, Brandon and Elkhorn Fairs in 1934, the results achieved were as follows:

- Sewing—54 entries: 34 prizes.
- Cooking—5 entries: 2 prizes.
- School Work—36 entries: 15 prizes.

A School Council, consisting of six senior pupils, assists the Principal in some of the tasks of School government. This Council consists of two captains and four councillors elected from the boys' and girls' sides of the school. These chosen leaders exercise a limited measure of authority and so are trained in initiative.

Thus, the School objective is not merely a schoolroom education but a many sided development, which will enable the graduates to take their places in life as industrious and efficient members of society, able to do many practical things reasonably well.

WHAT ARE THEIR RELAXATIONS?

The School lantern gives entertainment and occasionally a movie picture show is provided. The usual social evenings and a "visiting" night once a week gives opportunity for boy-girl contacts under proper supervision. A club night in cold weather and a radio, presented by an ex-member of the staff, fills in a pleasant evening.

The girls have a branch of the Woman's Auxiliary and some belong to a Glee Club.

In Winter, there are two skating rinks—one for the boys and another for the girls. Hockey teams play with the White boys in the village and the Indian boys have gained an excellent name for good sportsmanship.
In Summer, football is played and baseball is played by both boys and girls. Basketball is provided for the girls.

The School has a cadet corps and a gymnastic team.

A daily treatment is given for Trachoma. Frequent doses of cod liver oil and Parrish's food help those who need it. A carefully balanced diet in the dining room is provided and a monthly weighing of every child tells its story of progress. So little is the larger room of the School hospital used that it has been turned into a dormitory for the babies.

The girls have drill and hikes in the summer and all children unable to go home for their holidays have a happy time at picnics and other such treats.

WHAT IS DONE FOR THEIR HEALTH?

A resident nurse with a well-equipped dispensary cares for the sick, while the School doctor lives only a few hundred yards away.

WHAT IS DONE FOR THEIR RELIGIOUS LIFE?

As the School crest indicates, Religion is at the heart of all that is done.

Religion is the key stone of the bridge between the old life and the new.

No matter how well-formed and laid the stones of health, farm and classroom training may be, the passage of the pupil from admission to graduation cannot be safely accomplished unless the key stone of the bridge is well and truly laid.

So Religion is at the centre of all the work. Christ is in the kitchen and at the plough, as He is in the Chapel.

Every day is The Lord's Day. Rising bedside prayers, dining room prayers at breakfast and supper, grace before and after meals, retiring bedside prayers—all these emphasize the place of prayer in the daily Christian life.

Every Sunday morning at 7:15, and on Saints' Days there is Holy Communion in the School Chapel. These are voluntary services and always well-attended.
There is a daily Bible reading and religious instruction is given in the classrooms. Sunday School lessons are taught by the staff and in 1934, thirty-two children received certificates for success in the examinations set by the General Board of Religious Education.

Confirmation Class, 1934

The Sunday services inculcate the habit of public worship and the closing minutes of the graduating pupil’s life in the School are spent at the Altar, as the Principal prays a blessing.

Then the graduate goes out to battle against the wiles of the Devil, so often seeking his or her undoing on the Reserve.
WHAT OF THE GRADUATES' FUTURE?

How the graduate meets the future depends largely on how he has been prepared during the years at Residential School. How he measures up to the strange contrast of Reserve life depends on how deeply the Christ life has been seen and lived while at School.

Too often going back to the Reserve means "going back" in more ways than one. Will the reader pray for the graduate pupils?

Character is made by the impact of personality upon personality. In the Residential School character must be made by the impact of the White man's character upon that of the Indian.

Dear Reader! Will you pray that the workers in our Residential Schools may live so near the Great Personality that our Indians may find Him Whom to know is Life Eternal!

THE SCHOOL PRAYER

O Almighty God, grant Thy blessing, we beseech Thee, to the Elkhorn Residential School and its activities; bless the Missionary Society and its endeavour; the Missionaries and all Christian Workers: the pupils and their witness; prosper with Thy favour all our undertakings, especially our efforts to make this institution a light to all Thy children. Forgive our failures, kindle our love and unite us closely in the service of Thy Kingdom, through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.
ELKHORN, MANITOBA, May 1st, 1935

(Principal)
The conditions noted in my 1933 report still prevail, the large enrolment (146 at time of inspection) making it necessary to relay classes in both rooms. This means that each pupil is receiving only from two and a half to three hours daily instruction in the classroom. This is not such a serious matter for the older girls who receive valuable training in the performance of household duties under supervision nor for the older boys EXCEPT during the summer months when they also may be usefully employed on the farm. But the latter during the winter months and the younger children throughout the year lose much through lack of suitable activities and spend too much time in which they are not profitably employed. In my opinion, the addition of another classroom and teacher would do away with much of this loss, permit a more efficient organization of the work of the school and make possible much better results.

During my inspection, I looked over the unused power building. While this would not make an ideal classroom, it might with the removal of the machinery and some alterations be made to serve as such for a time. The upper storey might also be fitted up to carry on in a small way some work in manual training.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that owing to the condition of his wife's health, the Rev. Canon S. J. Wickens, B.A., B.D., has resigned from the Principalship of our Elkhorn School and is leaving at the end of the current month of October to take charge of a parish in the suburbs of the City of Victoria, B.C.

As Canon Wickens made a valuable contribution to Indian educational work during his tenure of the Principalship of this School, our Commission sincerely regret the circumstances which have made it necessary for him to retire, for the time being, from the Indian Residential School service. The members are very glad, however, to be able to report that they have secured the services of the Rev. Arthur E. Minchin, B.A., as Canon Wickens' successor, from the 1st November next. As Mr. Minchin is quite well known to your Department, having filled for some time the position of Principal of the Mackay School near the Pas, Manitoba, it does not appear to me to be necessary to furnish you with a detailed statement of his qualifications. His knowledge of the Indian people, and his very keen interest which he takes in the general welfare of their children, along with the experience he has already had as Principal of an Indian Residential School, appear to our Commission to fully justify his appointment.

As the appointment to a Principalship such as the one before us, can only be made by your Department, on the recommendation of our Society, I am sending a copy of this letter to our General Secretary, and you will no doubt hear direct from him in the matter in due course. In the meantime arrangements have been made for Mr. Minchin to take charge of the School at the date specified in the capacity of Acting Principal, and I shall be glad to know if this arrangement has the approval of your Department.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

The Department of Education wishes to acknowledge with sincere appreciation, the cooperation of your schools in sending to us art materials for the Manitoba Art Exhibit sent recently to the Exhibition of Children's Art in Wellington, New Zealand.

In approximately one hundred school districts, different schools forwarded contributions for this exhibit. The Honorable, the Minister of Education examined the exhibit before it was mailed to New Zealand and expressed pleasure at the quality of the work.

Careful selection was made of the specimens in order to choose for shipment the best work from different types of schools, in city, suburban or rural communities. Much material has been retained at the Department and it has been suggested that a Manitoba Art Exhibit some time next year, be arranged for the school year.

In cases where a special request was sent to the Department for return of materials, these will go forward to you in the near future, or when the New Zealand Exhibit comes back next winter.

The work from Indian Schools was arranged as a special unit in the total display and comprised a prominent part of the exhibit. One of the teachers of Art who assisted the Department of Education in assembling the Manitoba exhibit commented very favorably on the excellent work done by some of the pupils in Indian Schools. A quotation from his report follows:

"One of the bright spots is the contribution from Indian Schools. One must congratulate the staffs for their discrimination in encouraging the pursuit of native designs characteristic of their charges. One would regret any attempt to substitute the insanity of much of our design expression for that of the splendid school of native creations. The salvation of the Indian does not lie in inducing him to think along our decorative channels but in carrying on the sense of beauty portrayed in his traditional crafts."

The cooperation of your Church in this gesture of Empire goodwill is gratefully acknowledged.

Yours most sincerely,

(Sgd) Harold G. Etter,
Superintendent of Education.

Our Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission in Winnipeg, after very careful consideration have recommended that the Rev. C. N. Middleton, B.A., Principal of the Residential School at Wabasca, be appointed in succession to the Rev. Canon A. E. Minchin as Principal of the School at Elkhorn.

The Rev. C. N. Middleton was born in Calgary, Alberta, on July 29, 1912. He graduated in Arts from St. John's College, Winnipeg in 1934; was ordained Deacon in May 1936 and advanced to the Priesthood in May 1937. He was incumbent of the parish of Morden, Manitoba, prior to being appointed Principal of the Wabasca school in August 1938. His services as Principal of the Wabasca school and as missionary to the Indians in that district have been satisfactory both to the Commission and the Bishop of Athabasca in whose Diocese the school is located.

I am accordingly forwarding to the Indian Affairs Branch the recommendation of our Commission and am writing on behalf of the Executive Committee to recommend that the Rev. C. N. Middleton be appointed Principal of the Elkhorn School in succession to the Rev. Canon A. E. Minchin.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have just received your letter of the 4th inst., #106-0-1, requesting information regarding the date when the Rev. G. N. Middleton will be able to take charge of the Elkhorn School, and beg to state, in reply, that it is fully expected he will be able to reach Elkhorn sometime during the current month of May.

I may state for your information that when Mr. Middleton wrote to me last month, requesting instruction as to the date he should leave Wabasso, he was authorized to do so as soon as he considered the road safe for him to take his wife and children over the ninety odd miles between the school and Slave Lake on the railway. As Mrs. Middleton had not been enjoying good health, and as their children are quite young, our Commission did not feel justified in asking them to make the journey during what is known in the Northland as the break-up season. As soon as he reaches Elkhorn I will advise you of that fact.

While writing, I may also say that, until an ordained man has been secured for the Principalship of the Wabasso School, Mr. C. E. Barnes, the Farm Instructor, will take charge of that school in the capacity of Acting Principal. Memorandum:

- Mr. Hoey -

While at The Pas a delegation of Indians waited on me to air their grievances in connection with the Elkhorn School. The spokesman for the Indians was Cornelius Eignell. He reported that a delegation of Indians of which he was one attended at the Elkhorn School to check up on complaints made by their children as to conditions obtaining there.

The Indians claim to have found conditions in the school very unsatisfactory and report in particular:

The downstairs toilet in the boys' playroom was plugged and a condition of indescribable filth exists.

The upstairs toilet in the girls' dormitory was also out of order and the girls compelled to bail it out with pails.

The beds in the girls' quarters were in a dilapidated condition tied together with the girls' stockings, strings and any other contrivance that would keep them together.

The clothing and shoes the children were asked to wear were in a deplorable condition and I asked Mr. Lovell to send you the samples that were presented for my examination.

They reported that there was no butter and no bread on the table an enquiry elicited the information that the lack of butter was a punishment handed out to the students because they would not squeal on a boy who had stolen a pound of lard to assist in making a rabbit stew which formed the piece de resistance at a feast they held in the bush utilizing rabbits snared by some of the boys. They also complained that no vegetables had been served for weeks but the School Principal showed them an order that he had that day placed for fresh vegetables.

Over
The delegation also complained that in a dormitory of 30 or 40 boys there were only two towels made available to them.

They also complained that the school was improperly heated and the youngsters locked themselves in the clothes closets because they were the only places that were comfortable.

Mr. Cornelius Bignell who was the spokesman for the group said that they were afraid to press their complaints very strongly to the Principal as they were sure that he would take it out on the youngsters as soon as they left. Mr. Bignell is a very quiet-spoken, rational sort of person who confessed that their complaints to the Principal were made with a great deal of restraint as they felt that it was the duty of the Department rather than that of the Indians to see that the conditions in the School were remedied. He made the statement that while it was admitted that living conditions in an Indian village were not of a very high standard, they were much less crude, much less insanitary and much more convenient than their children enjoyed in the Elkhorn School. I am sorry that I overlooked discussing this matter with Inspector Hamilton when I saw him later in Winnipeg. You, however, have his report.

This memorandum is only designed to place the text of the Indian complaint before you. The Indian presentation to me was made in an entirely rational way; nobody was abused and the delegation was so restrained in their language that I was very much impressed with their sincerity. If half of what they report is true a surprise inspection of the School should be made.

Re Elkhorn School

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am given to understand that an official inspection of this school was recently carried out and I have reason to anticipate that the report will not be altogether favourable. May I, therefore, be allowed to state a few considerations which I think should be borne in mind in regard to this particular school.

Before definitely assuming my duties under the Commission I visited Elkhorn last May. It was the first of our schools that I had seen and I must confess that in many respects I was really disappointed. The building was manifestly rundown and in need of very considerable work to repair floors, stairways and plaster walls. There was also much need of painting and decorating, particularly in the basement section. One amazing feature to me was the fact that in this large school there was absolutely no provision for recreation. The boys and girls had to use their respective washrooms for indoor play and the results can readily be imagined. With this consideration foremost in my mind I welcomed the plan already authorized by the Department of converting the large building on the grounds, formerly used for Manual Training, into three classrooms. This would allow for the two classrooms in the main building to be set apart for recreation and while this was not ideal it certainly represented a great step forward. I urged the Principal to do everything in his power to press forward with the completion of this plan during the summer months.

With a large enrollment and the handicaps mentioned above, I was not surprised to find trouble in the staff. I have learned to expect trouble when conditions become too difficult and the strain too great. Personal differences had developed under these conditions and I found serious friction existing among our workers. We took steps to correct this situation and made a number of changes, so that by the Fall we had enrolled eight new members of our staff and felt that we were facing a new school year with hope.

Unfortunately I soon learned that a new problem had developed in connection with the Principal. Mr. Middleton had done a good job at Wabasca but my personal opinion is that he had not the
necessary strength or maturity of character to handle such a large and difficult situation as that existing at Elkhorn. His domestic difficulties developed and it became evident that he was laboring under a personal strain which prevented him from concentrating upon his school duties. In an endeavour to keep in touch with the situation I have paid three visits to this particular school and have done my best to press forward the completion of the new classrooms. It was difficult to secure labour and especially skilled help such as bricklaying for the new chimney and also the installation of the furnace. The men on the school staff did considerable work in excavating a complete basement to serve as a vegetable storage, but I think they usually undertook more than they could manage and other duties suffered. I visited the school one Saturday morning towards the end of last year and was greatly disappointed to find the work almost at a standstill by reason of these factors. It was a day when the snow had melted and the grounds were so wet and muddy that the children were not allowed out. The classrooms had been scrubbed and made ready for the new week and consequently the children were milling about in the inadequate washrooms and adjoining corridors. It is easy to imagine what damage is done to walls and woodwork and plumbing under these conditions, and I felt deep sympathy for the staff in trying to cope with an impossible situation. I was again assured that the work on the new building would be pushed forward during the Christmas holiday, with every prospect of the playrooms being ready early in the New Year. A little later we gathered that Mr. Middleton would probably be resigning and I gather that he has been unable to put his plans into effect for some time now.

On receipt of some complaints about the school, our Assistant Secretary, Colonel Marmagen, paid a visit a few weeks ago. He took strong measures to see that necessary material was secured to finish the classrooms and also to install or repair plumbing that had been broken or removed. It was with deep chagrin that we heard since then at the time of the inspection one of the most necessary installations had not been made, although the new equipment had been ordered and sent to the school.

I have stated these facts to make it plain that this particular school has not been neglected but has been the object of special concern to us. I feel that the personal difficulties of the Principal have operated against efficiency and we are now bending our energies to find the strongest possible man to take hold of an admittedly difficult situation. I fear that the enrolment shows the need of this school particularly in view of the fact that the Mackay School at The Pas has never been replaced. I trust that the Department will keep in mind our reiterated request for a new school to be built on the Hudson Bay line between The Pas and Churchill. I am convinced that it is not sound to bring these bush children down to a prairie school like Elkhorn, and that they could much more helpfully be cared for in a building situated in the north. As far as Elkhorn is concerned, I cannot feel there is need for despair if we can secure the right Principal, the provision of playrooms in the building and a sufficient expenditure to repair and put it in good order.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Allenwood
Secretary.

When visiting the above school a few days ago I was delighted to find very definite improvements already effected under the leadership of Mr. Hodkinson. He is certainly handling affairs in a business-like way and seems to have secured the hearty co-operation of the staff.

I inspected the Elkhorn Indian Residential School on May 18th and wish to report as follows:

There are 134 pupils enrolled: boys - 55; and girls - 79. There are three teachers and the pupils appear to be making fair progress in their respective grades. All were neatly dressed and clean in appearance.

The dining-room has been painted and now is much brighter. The floors are hardwood, but have no filler or finish. I would recommend that these floors be treated with two coats of Tremco penetrain. It will require about five gallons to do this; but the floors will have a good finish and be much easier to keep clean.

The dormitories were well aired and clean. Two have been painted and the walls and ceiling are now bright and clean.

The new class-rooms are not in use yet, but should be ready for the fall term in September. This change will provide a nice playroom and reading-room for both the girls and boys. In digging the basement under the proposed new class-rooms provision has been made for a large root cellar. The Principal found to his disappointment that some water appeared so it will now be necessary to fill in the excavation at least one foot, after which a cement floor may be required. This cement floor will involve extra expense and he requested that the Department pay for the cement. In view of the circumstances I think this should be allowed.

The children appear well fed and attached is a copy of the menu followed. You will note the quantities used for one meal are inserted in red. The children receive all the bread they desire and I found the brown bread very wholesome. Miss Long is a graduate nurse and is the matron. She is greatly interested in the children and gives careful consideration to their food requirements.
The cattle number thirty head and a fair supply of milk is provided. The milk is served to the children to drink or on porridge or in milk puddings.

The sewing-room, laundry, kitchen and bakery are well supervised and the girls receive a good training in the work of these departments.

The farm seeding was well along and they also expect to have a large garden in addition to several acres of potatoes.

The Reverend Mr. Middleton has been at Elkhorn for less than one year. He appears greatly interested in his work and I find him willing and anxious to co-operate in every respect.

I hope funds will be made available to carry out the enclosed recommendations.
