Memorandum:

While at The Pas a delegation of Indians waited on me to air their grievances in connection with the Elkhorn School. The spokesman for the Indians was Cornelius Bignell. He reported that a delegation of Indians of which he was one attended at the Elkhorn School to check up on complaints made by their children as to conditions obtaining there.

The Indians claim to have found conditions in the School very unsatisfactory and report in particular:

The downstairs toilet in the boys' playroom was plugged and a condition of indescribable filth exists.

The upstairs toilet in the girls' dormitory was also out of order and the girls compelled to bail it out with pails.

The beds in the girls' quarters were in a dilapidated condition tied together with the girls' stockings, strings and any other contrivance that would keep them together.

The clothing and shoes the children were asked to wear were in a deplorable condition and I asked Mr. Lovell to send you the samples that were presented for my examination.

They reported that there was no butter and no bread on the table an enquiry elicited the information that the lack of butter was a punishment handed out to the students because they would not squeal on a boy who had stolen a pound of lard to assist in making a rabbit stew which formed the piece de resistance at a feast they held in the bush utilizing rabbits snared by some of the boys. They also complained that no vegetables had been served for weeks but the School Principal showed them an order that he had that day placed for fresh vegetables.

Over
The delegation also complained that in a dormitory of 30 or 40 boys there were only two towels made available to them.

They also complained that the school was improperly heated and the youngsters locked themselves in the clothes closets because they were the only places that were comfortable.

Mr. Cornelius Bignell who was the spokesman for the group said that they were afraid to press their complaints very strongly to the Principal as they were sure that he would take it out on the youngsters as soon as they left. Mr. Bignell is a very quiet-spoken, rational sort of person who confessed that their complaints to the Principal were made with a great deal of restraint as they felt that it was the duty of the Department rather than that of the Indians to see that the conditions in the School were remedied. He made the statement that while it was admitted that living conditions in an Indian village were not of a very high standard, they were much less crude, much less insanitary and much more convenient than their children enjoyed in the Elkhorn School. I am sorry that I overlooked discussing this matter with Inspector Hamilton when I saw him later in Winnipeg. You, however, have his report.

This memorandum is only designed to place the text of the Indian complaint before you. The Indian presentation to me was made in an entirely rational way, nobody was abused and the delegation was so restrained in their language that I was very much impressed with their sincerity. If half of what they report is true a surprise inspection of the School should be made.

D. J. Allan
Superintendent
Reserves & Trusts
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Canada.

RE: Elkhorn School

I was at this school on September 19th. A Principal has not yet been appointed and things generally are in a hopeless condition. The school is not being operated, it is just running. Mr. Young, the Indian Agent, had the day before rounded up four or five children who had run away and had them escorted back. The same night eight others left and these were still away, and several are girls.

The dormitories were none too clean—toilets, washbasins were dirty. The staff seemed unimpressed, even after pointing out the existing condition. A new toilet bowl is needed in the boys dormitory. A toilet bowl complete with flush tank is needed in the girl's washroom. Towels were scattered about the washroom with perhaps five or six on hooks.

The roof of the school is, I understand, covered with tin or some such metal. It leaks in various places and should be repaired. It might be advisable to have this examined by someone from the Survey's and Engineering Branch, Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, of which Mr. Gow is in charge, and a recommendation obtained. The roof on the outside classrooms also leaks and this could be examined at the same time. This roof is covered with roofing paper and tar. The school authorities have stood by all summer and fall and did nothing, while the rains soaked through and ruined the tent set used on the classroom ceiling.

I have ordered the new fire escape doors and Mr. Young will try to get a carpenter to hang them.

(Cont'd)
and at the same time make the other alterations suggested by the Fire Inspector.

I am greatly concerned about the existing conditions at this school. I am convinced the pupils should not have been allowed back until the church provided a suitable Principal and Staff. Even now I do not hesitate to say that in my opinion the school should be closed before cold weather sets in, unless the Church appoints a well qualified Principal. The man need not be a minister. An alert active business man with experience in handling a staff and knowing how to administer discipline is the requirement. A real driving force is needed and even then he will have a full time job.

If this school is left open under present management and the children continue to run away, someone will be frozen to death or killed in riding trains. I think the Department should set a date beyond which they cannot wait longer for a Principal, and that date should not be later than October 15th. There is altogether too much delay in securing a Principal whom they knew was urgently required more than 6 months ago.

I hope this matter will be taken seriously by all concerned and that I may be advised concerning the outcome.

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have to acknowledge your reference 106-0-1 of the 25th in regard to the Elkhorn School and have read with deep concern the letter from Inspector Hamilton.

I think the Inspector scarcely gives us credit for the continual efforts we have made to secure a Principal since the withdrawal of Mr. Middleton less than five months ago. We have endeavoured to secure the transfer of three of our experienced Principals but all in turn did not desire to change. We have twice been disappointed by an applicant withdrawing after the somewhat involved procedure had been followed and we were ready to suggest his appointment. My last disappointment was the information given to me by Canon Shepherd after my conversation with you. He has accepted a teaching position for the winter in Eastern Canada and is not available. I had hoped that he would have been able to go out almost immediately and take charge of the school for at least a few months.

With much of Inspector Hamilton's letter I am compelled to agree and can assure you that the state of this school has been a genuine burden to us. We have a number of excellent staff members who only require a strong lead to place the school on a satisfactory footing. Unfortunately, the Acting Principal has not been able to maintain a happy relationship with the Head Matron and Farm Instructor and thus internal dissension has led to the weakness described. I may say that a number of visits have been paid from this office and we were so confident that a new Principal would be secured that we urged the Acting Principal to secure the usual number of pupils. In view of the information about runaways I have asked our Assistant Secretary Treasurer to go to Elkhorn at once and he expects to spend a few days in a thorough review of the position. Beyond this I am asking the Rev. J.W. House of Gleichen; in whose judgment we have complete confidence, to spare a little time from his school in taking hold of the Elkhorn situation while we speed our efforts to reach a satisfactory conclusion. We are in communication with a former
member of our staff who would make an excellent Principal and if he fails us have another applicant who might be secured without too much delay. I mention these things to assure you that we do not for a moment despair of finding the right man. We could have closed the matter long since if we had not been particularly anxious about this appointment.

I shall write again as soon as Col. Marmagen returns from the school, and do not think there will be any necessity to suggest so drastic a step as closing down at this juncture.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

REPORT OF ASSISTANT SECRETARY-TREASURER RE ELKHORN SCHOOL

Referring to the letter dated 22nd September, written by Inspector Hamilton to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont. I beg to report as follows:

(1) That a Principal has not been appointed is due to the fact that the Commission has on several occasions been disappointed at the last moment. Prospective candidates have seemed interested until they have been asked to set a date upon which they will be able to take over their duties. In each case some obstacle has always arisen. The Acting Principal should be commended, not censured, for making the best of a difficult situation.

Mr. Young, the Indian Agent, of Griswold, did not "round up" the four or five children who had run away, but had been notified by telephone of their absence and as they were from his Reservation was requested to keep an eye open for them. They were apprehended on the main road between Elkhorn and Hargraves. Of the eight others who left the same night, Mr. Hamilton states that "some of them were girls". As a matter of fact all were girls, and the reason for their leaving was because three of them, who were High School pupils, considered they had been insulted by their teacher at the Public School, who said they were only Indians and not up to the standard of work required for their grade. The remainder went out of sympathy or because they had some cause of offence against the staff. They were all picked up by the Mounted Police and returned to the School inside twenty four hours. One other girl who disliked her teacher went away on the morning passenger train to her home at Griswold but returned the next day of her own accord. All are now back at the school and appear quite content. I made a point of interviewing each one of them and with one exception secured a promise that they would not run away again. The exception was one of the biggest girls in the school who comes from Hodgson and does not seem to get on with the other pupils.

(2) I visited the school unexpectedly and found the dormitories clean and swept. Toilets were clean and working properly but the wash basins needed cleaning. Partly this is due to the fact that the crop is now being harvested and many of the boys are being used until late in the fields. The great point is, however, that the plumbing is old and basins and taps should be renewed. The building was erected in 1897 and the whole of the interior is in a dilapidated condition which no amount of scrubbing or sweeping will eradicate. Shortage of man-power has also contributed largely to the difficulties of administration. In his report, Inspector Hamilton states that even after pointing out existing conditions, the staff seemed unimpressed. What he actually said to the members of the staff was that they were "indifferent". Owing to an incomplete staff every member was doing more than their fair share of work and objected to being accused of being indifferent. A new toilet bowl is being installed in the Boys' dormitory at the present time and another toilet bowl, complete with flush tank should be provided by the Department at once. In spite of my unexpected visit I found possibly five towels on the floor or forms and all the rest hanging up.

(3) The Inspector reports that he understands that the roof of the school is leaking in several places and should be repaired. This
condition has been reported to him several times during the past two years but has not been remedied. The roof of the outside classroom also leaks and this also was reported. The suggestion that someone from the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, might examine these roofs, is most timely and should have been made before this.

I further recommend that at least two extra Bath rooms be provided for both boys and girls and also than an extra toilet compartment for each be supplied.

(4) The report states that new fire escape doors and other alterations suggested by the Fire Inspector have been ordered and that Mr. Young will "try" to get a carpenter to hang them. If such difficulty is being experienced by the Indian Agent why should the School staff be expected to be more successful?

(5) Under existing conditions, I submit that everything possible is being done to carry on. The school is being administered, not just running, and as already stated the Acting Principal is doing his best under adverse conditions. He is an experienced teacher and administrator and is receiving the loyal support of the staff of twelve, nine of whom have had experience in other schools. The one exception is the Farm Instructor who has been responsible for much of the discord and insubordination and whose removal is reluctantly recommended.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) E.W. Mermagen.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have given careful thought to the contents of your letter of October 10th in regard to the Elkhorn School and the possibility of securing another building north of The Pas. As our Commission was meeting last Friday, I introduced the general subject in a tentative way but fuller consideration was deferred to a later date owing to pressure of business. As I had the opportunity of spending the weekend at Elkhorn, I think it well to give you my personal reaction to your suggestions.

1. I am in full sympathy with the criticisms often made as to the unwisdom of sending "bush children" from the north to such a prairie school as Elkhorn. We have one of our best school farms at this point and there is no doubt that the pupils receive valuable training in it, but this is not worth much to boys who are returning to a hunting and trapping life and will not have the opportunity of using their agricultural knowledge. The more serious objection lies in the undoubted fact that they lose the opportunity of learning the very things needed for the kind of life they will probably live, through being entirely removed from the bush environment in a number of years. It is easy, however, to understand why this is done, in the light of history. I find that the situation only arose after the destruction of the Mackay School at the Pas by fire in March 1933. This school apparently had 84 northern children in residence at the time and 50 of these were afterwards transferred to Elkhorn when the Department decided not to rebuild. I am confident that this was a mistake, has worked a hardship on the bush children, and has overcrowded Elkhorn in a harmful manner. My mind is therefore clear that whenever possible a building should be secured or built north of the Pas. The present American Hospital building might be a good solution, though I am a little doubtful of the wisdom of trying to have both school and hospital at the one spot. I think your files will show that we have on numerous occasions asked for the building of a school up the Hudson's Bay line. The Bishop of Keswatin has been particularly anxious for this, claiming that he has a very large number of children in the direction of Churchill who are without educational privileges. If the present building north of the Pas should be found
suitable it might well serve the area to the north as the pupils could readily be transported by train.

2. In regard to the present building at Elkhorn I cannot feel that it should lightly be abandoned. I find that at present there are roughly 70 children in residence from the south of the province and 60 from the Pas and north. Some of the latter travel 900 miles to the school while from the Pas the distance is 680 miles. In analyzing the attendance from southern reserves, I find that 37 are from Oak River and this number will probably be increased by at least five. About 30 come from the group of reserves in the Interlake area especially Peguis and Fairford. I am told that this number could be considerably increased but for the fact that the school is already overloaded. There are also three from Sintaluta and again it has been said that there should be at least ten from this point. I think it a fair conclusion therefore that Elkhorn could without difficulty have a hundred pupils from the southern part of the province and this is about all the building should be asked to carry. It would take much of the present tension out of the building with a smaller number of pupils, a smaller farm and the unity which could be attained when the pupils are all pretty much of one type. If Elkhorn should be closed and no building substituted in the south we should have the present problem reversed, for our Peguis and Fairford Indians in particular would have to come into Winnipeg before travelling to the Pas and there would be many objections to this.

It is true that the present Elkhorn building is badly run-down and I am expecting a full report from Mr. House, who has naturally been shocked at the contrast with his own splendid building. My personal feeling, however, is that the building has been well constructed and is sound in the main. It could certainly be put in good order at a very small cost compared with the construction of a new school.

It seems to me that our Church has really suffered a good deal since the loss of the Mackay School. Whereas according to the 1939 Census we had a larger number of Indians in the province than either the United or Roman Churches we have only had inadequate provision for 155 pupils at Elkhorn, while the United has been allowed 365 in three schools and the Roman Church 340 in four residential Schools.

I have thought it well to write at length as various matters related to this question are likely to be decided before long. I am giving merely a personal opinion at this moment when I say that I believe the situation calls for the retention of Elkhorn and the provision of another Anglican School north of the Pas. I shall obtain further information regarding the whole question and bring it before our Commission at the earliest opportunity.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. H. Elderwood
Secretary.

Report on Conditions at Elkhorn Indian Residential School

On approaching the school one received the impression that there was lack of organization, supervision and interest. The grounds were very untidy, articles of clothing and other wearing apparel were scattered over the yard, school entrances and steps. Many window panes were broken. The unbroken panes had the appearance of having been treated for a BLACOUT, they were so dirty. Inside the building these impressions were confirmed by findings wherever you went.

At the time of my inspection, April 4th, and 5th, 1944, this school was in charge of Mr. B. Hodgkinson, who had just been appointed acting principal.

143 pupils were registered, 86 of these were girls. Your pupils, two boys and one girl were taking grade 8 and one girl was taking grade 10 in the local High School. Four patients, three girls and one boy were confined to bed in the school infirmary.

1. DORMITORIES

(A) Air Space

The attached chart shows the available air space per pupil in each dormitory. The Saskatchewan Government Public Health Regulations require 800 cu. ft. of air for each hospital patient and at least 400 cu. ft. for each person in any public hotel. In view of these regulations it should not be unreasonable to ask that 600 cu. ft. be provided for each occupant in any room used as a dormitory, for ten months of the year.

If such is the case, this chart shows a definite overcrowding exists.

(B) Ventilation

Small slides at the bottom of some windows were the only source of ventilation. Broken window panes indirectly supplemented this means of ventilation. It certainly was not adequate or satisfactory. A draft passed over the occupants of the beds opposite the open windows.

Provision could be made for all windows in dormitories to open at least six inches from the top.

(C) Beds & Bedding

All that can be said in favor of the beds is that they are of pre-war manufacture. As such they are sturdier built than it is possible to purchase at the present time. Their appearance would be improved by a coat of enamel. The springs are held together by every conceivable means, wire, cord, etc. It should be possible to secure wire links and coils to repair these springs. The springs on every bed will require extensive repairs.

"Filthy" is the only word and even that does not adequately describe the condition of mattresses, pillows, and bedding. The majority of the mattresses have long since served their usefulness.

Only the pillows in the junior girls' dormitory were noticed to have pillow slips. In all other dormitories they were conspicuous by their absence.

2. PLUMBING

(A) Toilets

The attached chart also shows toilet facilities and condition of same in each dormitory.
2. PLUMBING - continued.

(A) Toilets

Three toilet bowls were situated at the south end of the girls' wash room. Two of these were in proper working order. One did contain fecal matter. Another had a bad leak from an over head flushing tank, which flooded the floor surrounding the toilets. This leak could not be of recent origin, as there was a piece of wooden duck walk in front of the bowl, to keep the user's feet out of the water. The door at the entrance of one toilet was off its hinges.

The toilet paper containers were located outside of the toilet on the wall between the doors.

In the boys wash and play room on the south side of the building, there was plumbing for three toilet bowls but only two were installed. There were no urinals.

Not a single toilet bowl in the whole school had a seat. The majority of the bowls were badly stained, and had an uncared for appearance.

I have no recollection of seeing any outside toilets.

The Saskatchewan Provincial Health Regulations require one toilet seat to every 18 pupils.

(B) Wash Basins

The girls' washroom, which is 27' by 14' is located on the ground floor in the west half of northern portion of the building. This room is cold and uninviting, possibly due to its cement floor and poor lighting.

Ten wash basins provided with two taps each, are situated on the west wall of this room. Examination revealed that neither tap on one basin, and only one on three others were in working order. Some of the basins contained dirty water. On investigation it was found that the stoppers were made of toilet paper.

Two roller towels were hanging in this room.

The boys' washroom, which is 26' by 14' is located in the southern portion on the ground floor. It also was cold and uninviting, similar to the girls for the same reason.

Twelve basins provided with two taps each, are situated on the west wall. Neither taps on one, and only one on two other basins were working.

Two roller towels were hanging in this room.

Not a single stopper was found in either wash room. All basins had an uncared for appearance.

(C) Bathing Accommodation

Two tubs for use of the girls were partitioned off in the northern end of their play room. The floor is of cement. It was moist at the time of our visit. There was a wooden duck walk beside each tub. Both of these were in broken condition. There was a shower fixture over one tub, which was leaking. The handle for its control valve was missing. As the tub had a rusted spot, where the shower dripped, one would conclude the leak was not of recent origin.

On the boys' side a small room 9' by 14' adjacent to their play room, contained two tubs as well as a shower. The waste water from the baths and shower flows out over the floor to an open drain in the boys play and wash room.

3. HEATING FACILITIES

Even if the building had been kept in first class repair, difficulty in maintaining a satisfactory temperature would be experienced on account of its age. With the neglect, which is evident in toilets, wash basins and bathrooms, is equally evident in not maintaining the building in good repair. Poorly fitted storm windows,
3. HEATING FACILITIES - continued

Absence of storm doors, and innumerable broken panes of glass, increase the heating difficulties.

The heating plant is a Gurney Hot Water Furnace, equipped with an automatic stoker. One section of the furnace was reported cut off when the stoker was installed a few years ago. The engineer admitted difficulty in maintaining a comfortable temperature in many of the rooms during the cold weather, especially if it was windy. From personal experience, this furnace does not appear to be any more than large enough to satisfactorily heat this building, if all its sections were in perfect working order.

If the welfare of the children had been considered, steps would have been taken to have the defective section repaired and put in order. The inability to maintain the building at a comfortable temperature did not originate during the winter months of 1945-46.

4. FIRE HAZARDS

The fire escapes in the dormitories lead through a window using only the lower half. The steps up to these windows were not solid, with the confusion during a fire they are apt to cause the pupils to fall. Serious consequences could easily result. In the laundry there is an old kitchen range used to heat the sea irons. While it was located adjacent to the chimney it had to be continually operated with all drafts wide open. Clothes on lines and on clothes horses were near this stove. This did constitute a serious fire menace as it was on the basement floor in the center of the building.

Throughout the building were fire extinguishers.

5. CLOTHING & GENERAL APPEARANCE OF THE CHILDREN

No matter where the children were contacted, in the class rooms, in the dining room, about the school, or out of doors on the play ground, they were dirty and their clothes were disgraceful. The clothing was not only dirty but torn and ragged. Their stockings were full of holes. Not a single child was observed to be wearing a good pair of boots. No difference was noticed in the clothing worn at meals, in the class room or outside. Several of the boys took off overalls when they came into the wash room from outside.

Many of the children playing out doors had a half frozen appearance.

There is no doubt about these children being very poorly clad. They certainly were not provided with sufficient clothing to keep warm during the cold winter months, if they did not have on more appropriate clothing than worn the day of this inspection.

There was no evidence of extra clothing having been issued, except what seen in the laundry and sewing room. The quantity observed in these two places did not impress one as being sufficient for a complete change for all pupils.

The provision made, for the care of clothing in use, was not such to induce or teach any child to care for their wearing apparel. For example, in the girls' washroom, along the wall 27' in length was supposed to be sufficient hooks for 88 girls to hang their coats and hats up. Along this same wall was a row of seats, which had open pigeon holes underneath. These were crammed with old boots, rubbers, dirty clothing and everything else. In the boys' washroom exactly the same unsatisfactory and untidy condition existed. Here there was a wall 28' long to provide space for 55 boys to hang outside wearing apparel.

No provision has been made for the children to keep any personal belongings they have or receive. Apparently a few did try to keep them underneath the mattresses. There are good lockers in the small boys', intermediate and junior girls' dormitories, but not a single one was in use.

When a good wind breaker was found in the manure at the cow barn, Rev. C.H. Middleton, stated, although every boy had been issued with a new wind breaker last fall, at Christmas time only five could be accounted for.
5. CLOTHING & GENERAL APPEARANCE OF THE CHILDREN - continued

As regards dental hygiene, a tooth brush rack containing two brushes was noticed above the basins in the girls' wash room. On the boys' side the tooth brush rack was noticed in the linen room. On enquiring why it was located there, the Boys' Supervisor replied, that brushes were given out to be used immediately before going to class. From what was seen, one would conclude that dental hygiene was given very little consideration.

While visiting the laundry, it was observed that the children were getting their clothing and shoes sopping wet, during the process of removing the contents of the washing machine into a tub for rinsing. This work seemed very unnecessary, as the rinsing could have been done in the washing machine. Miss Allison, the Laundry Matron, was asked why this extra work. She replied her instructions were to get two washings from one lot of suds.

6. FOOD

A copy of the menu SUPPOSED to be in use is attached hereto, also a list of weights of all pupils taken on the day of inspection.

It is to be expected that a large percentage of pupils on returning to school, following their summer vacation, will be under weight. Such a condition should not exist a month or so before they are leaving for their summer vacation, if they have been receiving sufficient and proper diet. At the time of inspection 28% of the girls and 69.9% of the boys are underweight in this school.

The dining room was visited for the mid day and evening meals on April 4th, breakfast and mid day meal on April 5th, while these meals were being served and eaten. From observation during these four meals, it was apparent there were more OMISSIONS than SUBSTITUTIONS in the menu.

The meals were not appetizing. Each child received an enamel plate, enamel cup and a spoon. Not a single knife or fork was noticed in the dining room at any of the meals. Beans and bread appeared to constitute the main item of food, the former being the principal and only vegetable observed. The latter was the most abundant item of food on the tables. The bread was baked in the school and was of very good quality.

All food except the bread was placed on the enamel plate. The bread previously to being brought to the table was smeared on one side with warm grease. Bread was served with each meal but only at two meals was it served with lard. Approximately three slices, more properly described as hunks were placed directly on the table beside each pupil's plate.

At no time did the children receive butter.

At the mid day meal the younger children were given milk, the older ones received water. For breakfast and the evening meal all were SUPPOSED to have cocoa made from milk and sweetened with sugar.

7. FOODS AVAILABLE

Mrs D.A.Oakley, Kitchen Matron, informed me they had just been out of potatoes for four or five days. Rev. C.N.Middleton, former principal, also informed me that it would be necessary to buy potatoes and other vegetables from now until the new crop was available.

Vegetables were supposed to be on order.

In the vegetable bins below the kitchen were a few small heads of cabbage and a small number of turnips. Neither here nor in the root cellar beneath the new class rooms, where the vegetables were supposed to have been stored, could a sufficient quantity of one or any combination of vegetables be found, for one meal for this school.
7. FOODS AVAILABLE - continued

The meat is bought at the local butcher store. Apparently they do not buy any particular cuts of meat. On checking the counter slips for meat purchased during the month of February, they bought 40 to 60 lbs. of meat per day. The Matron and Lady in charge of the kitchen, explained that the butcher delivered hamburger very frequently. At no time did the children ever get roast meat.

During my conversation with the Matron, mention was made about securing eggs for Easter. I availed myself of the opportunity to enquire from her, how frequently the children were given an egg for breakfast or any other meal. She replied that since she had been the Matron, not on a single occasion had the children been provided with such a luxury.

Bread pudding constitutes an important item in their noon day meal. On enquiring about the source of the bread used for this purpose, I learned that it was the left over bread gathered up after each meal.

THE FOLLOWING OUTSIDE BUILDINGS WERE INSPECTED

1. PUMPING PLANT - from the septic tank which was in all working order.

2. NEW CLASS ROOMS - in what was formerly the old gymnasium building. They were nearing completion. I understand that this will make available for play rooms the two rooms now being used as class rooms in the main building.

3. HORSE BARN - showed the usual evidence of lack of care. Windows were broken or absent. Doors off hinges. There was an accumulation of manure. Parts of harness were lying about the barn in the manure.

4. FIG PEN - This really was the only building which showed evidence of receiving any attention. The most galling part here was when I enquired, if it was the intention to butcher the three pigs which appeared ready for market, I was told they were not for the school use, but were to be sold to the local butcher.

5. COW BARRS - Two or three of the younger boys were attempting to clean this building. All the cattle were out. The barn had not been cleaned for one week if not longer. It certainly did not have a sanitary appearance to insure a satisfactory milk supply. There was an excellent silo, which was liable to be blown down and destroyed at any time, due to carelessness in not keeping the guy wires in position and tight.

6. POULTRY HOUSE - There was a flock of poultry. The replies to my enquiries led me to believe that they received sufficient eggs to supply the school requirements. Later I learned that it supplied only the requirements of the staff.

7. VEGETABLE STORAGE & FACILITIES - Provision was made for the storage of vegetables adjacent to the furnace room under the new class rooms. The provision made was much too small for the quantity of vegetables required for the school. On the other hand it was too close to the furnace to provide the proper temperature to insure vegetables keeping well. There was an old root house in the yard. Unfortunately I did not have a flash light with me so was unable to examine its interior.

Scattered about the yard was the Machinery and Implements. These should have been under cover. They were being destroyed by the children.

Re: Conditions at Elkhorn Indian Residential School

With further reference to your memorandum of March 7th 1944, I have the honor to submit the following report:

I sincerely regret that this report has not been completed at an earlier date, but it has been rather difficult to accurately describe the findings.

On my return from the East, arrangements were made with Inspector A.G. Hamilton, when passing through Winnipeg, to meet him at Elkhorn at 9 a.m., Tuesday, April 4th, 1944. These arrangements were carried out.

The entire day was spent at the school. Rev. C.N. Middleton, former principal, Mr. B. Hodgkinson, acting principal and Miss H.K. Davies, Matron, accompanied us through the school. As I wished to be present for the serving of a breakfast, dinner and supper, and to recheck some of my findings, I remained in the district over night and revisited the school on April 5th, 1944.

I regret to have to report that I never anticipated finding conditions in any school, as existed in the Elkhorn Residential School. Mr. Cornelius Bigwell's statement, made to Mr. D.J. Allan, sums up the situation perfectly when he says:

"While it was admitted that living conditions in an Indian village were not of a very high standard, they were much less crude, much less insanitary and much more convenient than their children enjoyed in the Elkhorn School."

The Indians have every justification to complain. They are to be congratulated on the gentlemanly manner of action taken to have matters remedied. This lack of supervision and interest in the school and pupils, as well as mismanagement, is not of recent origin. It has been going on for an indefinite period. A climax has been reached, which calls for drastic action, if this school is going to properly serve its pupils and obtain the results which are expected by the Indian Department, in return for their Per Capita Grant.

When the findings are considered from every angle, nothing favorable can be said for the present administration of this institution. To permit present conditions to continue will eventually not only bring severe public criticism on the Indian Affairs Branch, but serve no useful purpose in uplifting or helping the Indians.

A satisfactory school staff no doubt can be obtained.
Can the necessary expenditures to replace worn out equipment and purchase the necessary new not on hand, in addition to repairing and renovating the buildings, to make this school satisfactory for occupancy be justified, when you consider the age, construction, layout and present state of repair of this building.

M.D.
Medical Superintendent
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

Dear Canon Dixon:

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, submitted to this Branch by Dr. A. B. Simes, Medical Superintendent of the Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital.

I may state, by way of explanation, that immediately following this inspection Dr. Simes was called upon to accompany the members of a treaty party into the North Country - hence the delay in sending forward his report.

There are certain sections in this report that are really very disturbing. The Elkhorn school is old and in a somewhat dilapidated condition, and it has been my feeling for a number of years that it should be abandoned, or rather that a school to replace it should be built in the territory immediately north of The Pas. I was not surprised, therefore, to find that the physical condition of the building was somewhat unsatisfactory from the standpoint of sanitation and comfort. What disturbed me most was the fact that 28% of the girls and 69.9% of the boys were under-weight. This supports to some extent the contention made by a group of Indians who interviewed Mr. Allan, Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts, at The Pas, early last spring. These Indians were emphatic in their declaration that children were poorly clad and poorly fed at the institution.

I am well aware, of course, that these are exceptional times in which we are living and I know something of the attempts made by Dr. Alderwood to secure

REPORT ON ELKHORN SCHOOL

The Secretary,
I. R. S. Commission,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I have just come back from a ten days' visit to Elkhorn School, and I would like to give you some of my impressions and to ask that you take up certain matters concerning building and equipment with the Department of Indian Affairs.

At the outset I must confess that I went to the School with an idea of recommending it be closed. Current stories coupled with Inspector Hamilton's report led me to believe that it wasn't fair to keep that number of Indian children under our care when everything suggested our accommodation being inadequate, and the administration poor. After staying a week at the school and trying to investigate all angles of school life I came to the conclusion that my first ideas were all wrong. I found that the school staff was able and efficient. They were working under a great handicap of not having a settled principal nor matron, but they were doing an excellent job. The children were well fed, clothed, and properly cared for. To a certain degree they were quite happy. There were a number of adjustments necessary in routine matters, but these were not of a very serious nature. The school was quite well cared for and clean, but the building is in need of considerable repair.

I find that the most serious difficulties connected with the school concern:

1. Overcrowding with diverse tribes.
2. Lack of co-operation from the Reserves.
3. Unsound general policy.

(1) This school was originally built to take one hundred pupils, but since the Makay school was burned down an attempt has been made to cram in anything up to one hundred and fifty pupils. Some adjustment to the building was made supposedly to allow this. Outside classrooms were built and original classrooms were turned into playrooms. This gave children more floor space for rainy days, but nothing was done to increase washroom, bathroom, toilet or laundry accommodation. That means half the school is capable of handling a hundred and fifty pupils, but the other half is barely sufficient to handle the original one hundred. I found there were two toilets, six wash basins, and only two baths on each side of the building. On the girls side there are eighty children, and you can see how utterly impossible it is for two toilets to accommodate them. On this score alone the children have to be fetched out of bed an hour earlier than necessary. Before meal times it is absolutely impossible for each child to wash or relieve itself. There isn't a chance to have these places as clean as they should be because even the toilet flush system will not operate fast enough to handle the enormous demand. What really surprised me was the efficiency of the Supervisors' organization. This is the only thing that kept the system in operation and possibly sanitary.
I understand Inspector Hamilton and others inspected this building, and complained about the unsanitary conditions, but I am of the opinion that they must have complained without much thought and a thorough investigation. If they had faced the situation with an open mind they would have realized that any criticism they made was really levelled at themselves because it is the Department's responsibility to provide adequate toilet and washroom accommodation. It was their business to get to the root of the thing, and it certainly does not reflect credit on their administration when none of them saw the very thing which made effective sanitation and operation impossible.

(2) Lack of co-operation from Reserves: All Indian Schools are very much affected by conditions on the Reserves from which the children are recruited. I think Elkhorn suffers much more from this than most schools because distances from schools to Reserves are great. Distance just adds that little bit of nervousness in the minds of parents who cannot see their children from one year's end to another. Reserves all over the country are all so infested with this Nationalist propaganda which tends to make the Indian disidentified with anything that is done with him. From the tenor of telephone calls from as far away as Griswold and the Pas, I gathered that parents all over were in a ferment over the welfare of their children. As far as I could find Indian Agents did nothing to alleviate, but rather lent their voices with that of the Indians to criticise and knock everything that was done in the school. Since it is the Department's responsibility to educate these Indian children, and they have made no provision for carrying this out other than by Elkhorn, I would consider it the duty of all Agents to assist the school in every possible way. That they do not do and in consequence parents put their children up to running away from school upon the slightest provocation. This is the secret of Elkhorn's truancy problem.

(3) Unsound general policy: I am of the opinion that our Church made a mistake when it attempted to handle The Pas situation with that of Elkhorn. I think it would have been wiser to have left the Indians up North until a new school was built and made Elkhorn—as it was intended to be the school for Southern Saskatchewan and Manitoba. Hindsight is better than foresight. As things stand today you have a sharp division in this school. There is the Northern group—Bushmen, Fishers and Trappers who are entirely out of their element in Southern surroundings, and there is the Southern group, mostly agriculturists who are at home there. These do not entirely fuse in the school and there is consequently an undercurrent of divisions. From an administrative point of view this is an impossible situation.

There are now 61 children who come from Reserves North of The Pas. The nearest one is 680 miles from Elkhorn, and farthest from 900 to 1000 miles. No wonder these children are discontented, and the parents worried.

My suggestion would be that you face the Government with this situation and urge them to make provision for a school in that Northern area and leave Elkhorn for the South. There are hundreds of Indians in both areas belonging to our church who can have no possibility of educating their children under our present system.
I believe there is some doubt about the Elkhorn building being capable of sufficient replenishment to make a good school. After very careful inspection I have come to the conclusion that the building can be put into excellent shape with some repairs which are enumerated below.

**Floors** - The floors in all five dormitories are worn through. These would need new flooring.

**Hallways** - These are in similar condition and also need flooring.

**Stairs** - There are seven flights of stairs from the dormitories to play rooms, all of these are worn out and in places are quite dangerous. They should be rebuilt.

**Doors** - Two doors need replacing, and 13 others need repainting or rehanging. Outside doors will have to be changed so they will swing outwards.

**Ceilings** - One ceiling needs either replastering or fixing with plaster board, and a few little spots of plaster need repairing.

I got a carpenter named Carl E. Dahl of Elkhorn, to go over these repairs with me and give an estimate of material and labour. You will see that he estimates the cost of material at $1,157.08, and labour $692.00, making a total of $1,849.08. His estimate is attached.

If this repair work was done I would suggest covering the hallway and passageway with battleship linoleum (Brown). This would preserve the floors which are already good and tend to brighten up the appearance of the school. It would require 120 yards of material two yards wide to effect this.

I would also suggest enough paint to brighten up all floors and trimmings inside the building. For this purpose we would need:

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Bathroom Facilities:

There ought to be at least two more toilets, two baths, and four wash basins installed on each side. I cannot tell the cost of this, but no doubt the Department would send its engineer to estimate this for us. In urgency I would say this matter should have priority over all else.

Fire Escape Doors:

In two dormitories fire exit is made through a window. For safety sake doors should be installed here. I understood this was reported to Mr. Hamilton and he promised to do something about it. So far nothing has been done. It might be advisable to jog his memory.

Roof:

The roof leaks in several places. This also was brought to the attention of the Inspector, but nothing has been done. I personally inspected both the school roof and the classroom roof and found them in perfect shape except for some small cracks in the roofing material. I secured the carpenter Mr. Dahl and instructed him to procure roofing cement and stop the cracks. This, I expect, is already done.

Porch for Junior Classroom:

When little children go from the main school to classroom in bad weather they have to take their coats. There is no place for them to hang these inside. I think this matter also was discussed with Mr. Hamilton, but nothing was done. As this is an emergency I have instructed Mr. Dahl to put an 8' x 8' porch at the classroom door with pegs for hanging clothes. It will cost approximately $30.00. I hope the Department can be prevailed upon to pay this bill.

General:

There are some minor repairs which can be effected by the school staff. These I have not bothered to enumerate because they are already being done.

Septic Tank:

I almost forgot this item. The rotary pump for emptying septic tanks needs repair. This also Mr. Hamilton promised to do but nothing has been done.

I should say that the main building at Elkhorn is in very good condition barring the things needing repairs as stated above. It was well built and is quite substantial. I would consider the cost of putting it in first-class condition well worth while. A matter of three or four thousand dollars is nothing compared with the cost of new school buildings which would become inevitable if this one were to go out of business. I would strongly urge you to take this matter up with a view to securing the Department's co-operation immediately.
One hundred and thirty children are in residence and their health and comfort make it imperative that something be done right away.

Yours very sincerely,

(SIGNED) JOHN W. HOUSE
Principal.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I think it well to pass on to you immediately the enclosed report which has come to hand from Mr. House. It is a careful review of the situation by one who is well experienced in school work and who came to Elkhorn with his mind open to receive impressions. I am interested to find that Mr. House is led to stress some of the points I tried to make in writing to you about possible developments north of The Pas.

I feel that the report is scarcely fair to Inspector Hamilton in some of its references, as the writer was not aware of all the facts. My conclusion for some time has been that the Inspector had decided that the school ought to be closed and therefore was not spending money on the building as he felt it would be wasted. He told me some time ago that he was prepared to recommend that considerable repairs should be put in hand but was holding back his requisition until assured that a competent Principal would be appointed. I did not feel that this was altogether unfair, and yet felt that the Inspector scarcely gave us enough credit for our real concern and our repeated efforts to secure the right kind of appointment.

Mr. House advises me that he is returning to Elkhorn in a few days and will remain there until after November first, by which time we trust that Mr. Hiltz will have been able to arrive and take charge. I understand that his appointment as Acting Principal has been recommended to you by our Head Office and I trust soon to receive the approval of the Department. It will be most valuable if he can commence his duties under the direction of Mr. House.

Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

Re Elkhorn-Indian Residential School

I have read Doctor Simes' report dated October 19th of the inspection made by him, in company with Inspector Hamilton, of the conditions existing at the above school, complaints about which had been previously received by the Department.

It is very disturbing to know that such conditions as reported by Doctor Simes should be allowed to exist in any of our residential schools. While Doctor Simes made his inspection early in April, his report is dated October 19th. It is to be regretted that he should have taken this long to have made his report. It is inferred from your memorandum that Inspector Hamilton did not make a separate report and, as a result, the first time the matter was brought to your attention was after you had received Doctor Simes' report. Consequently, no steps were taken to remedy the situation before the end of the school year.

It is difficult to understand how the conditions at this school should have been allowed to get into such a state without them having been brought to your notice, either by Inspector Hamilton or by the School Inspector. Have you asked Inspector Hamilton for an explanation of this?

The report which you received from Doctor Alderwood, enclosed with your memorandum of November 2nd, would appear to indicate that there has been a substantial improvement. However, the report indicates that there are some very major repairs to be made in the school before all of the conditions complained of by Doctor Simes can be remedied. It is assumed that after Mr. Moey has discussed the matter with the Anglican Mission Board he will make some definite recommendations.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have to acknowledge your letter 196-0-1 forwarding copy of report on conditions at Elkhorn School by Dr. A. B. Simes. The entire statement is certainly a dreadful one and makes very painful reading, but I am compelled to ask why seven months should be allowed to elapse after such conditions were reported. If things were really as bad as claimed they should surely have been dealt with immediately, and the pupils not left to suffer for so many months more. If you will kindly refer to my letter of April 10th, it will, I believe, serve to explain many of the statements made in this report. We have ourselves been deeply concerned with conditions in this particular school and regret that an inspection should have to be made when matters in general were probably at their lowest point. I have already pleaded that the personal difficulties of the Principal are responsible for much of this decline at Elkhorn. In the spring of the year he was passing through the painful experience of undertaking divorce proceedings against his wife. We did not realize until later what an effect this was having on all his work. He apparently lost his grip of the situation and the staff became discouraged and depressed, so that the school was at its very worst when the spotlight was turned upon it.

I cannot therefore agree that the poor conditions found at the beginning of April have existed for a long time. Until June 1943, the Head Matron of this school was Nurse R. M. Long, a thoroughly qualified and experienced lady who kept standards of nutrition and health up to a high point. She was most systematic and thorough in caring for the children's well-being. All were regularly weighed and those below par received extra food and care. Her menu was carefully prepared on scientific lines and was accepted by the Commission as a model and commended to all of the schools. A copy of this menu is attached and I may say that it is still the basis of the meals at Elkhorn, though of necessity many items of food are harder to obtain under war conditions. The underweight reported may largely be due to the fact that a very severe epidemic of "flu" had been experienced during the winter, which affected the majority of pupils and staff. The Principal wrote us as late as March 22nd expressing satisfaction that the weighing on that date showed that only three children had failed to show a gain since the previous test.

The report of Dr. Simes contains no recognition of the fact
that we have been at war for over five years and that many difficulties have increased with the passing of time. I have repeatedly been forced to address lately that our work in these schools seems to be slipping to lower standards. Costs are continually rising; many items of food and equipment can not be obtained; workers are harder to secure; changes are too frequent and we have to accept less competent persons than we desire. Since Nurse Long left to assume charge of a T. B. Preventorium we have had three matrons and have failed up to now in our efforts to secure a graduate nurse. The matron in charge at the time of the inspection was a teacher who was acting in a temporary way. The absence of the young people of the nation on active service has crippled us greatly in the matter of athletic and recreational activities. The young men and women who formerly guided the boys and girls in their sports are scarcely to be obtained today. I have been painfully conscious that there is unrest among our pupils because we seem to have lost the ability to give them the interesting Scout and Guide and other programs and to direct them in their play for lack of younger members of our staff.

There is further the labour situation which offers good wages to many Indians so that we can not get their help. Older boys and girls are also being kept at home to earn money and our schools are short of this type of assistance. The milkman of our large herd at Elkhorn has become a serious problem recently on this account. At the present time one man has been trying to keep this large building warm and in good repair and we have only retained his services with difficulty for he has twice been called for military service. The farm instructor has been desperate for lack of help and we have tried in vain to secure this, for we are unable to pay the wages being offered elsewhere.

This leads me to the real cause of many of the things which are undoubtedly wrong or inadequate in this school. In speaking critically of food, clothing and supervision, the critic should surely refer to the question of income. If the Government is responsible for maintaining these schools and for giving the churches which administer them sufficient grants for the purpose then some criticism might well be turned in that direction. For years the churches have pleaded for more help and have demonstrated their inability to maintain adequate standards in the face of steadily rising costs. Even with the $15.00 special grant promised for this year the allowance for each pupil at Elkhorn is only 50¢ per day. Necessary operating costs, even with low salaries and inadequate staff, take three-fourths of this income. Thus out of the Government grant only 12½¢ per day is left to feed the children and nothing at all for clothing. If Missionary funds and the efforts of devoted church workers did not supplement the Government grants the system would long since have broken down. When Dr. Simes speaks strongly over the lack of butter, eggs and roast meat, who is he blaming? The lack of potatoes was due to culpable neglect and is not likely to occur again. Usually this school produces an excellent crop of vegetables but in 1942 the results were very poor owing to lack of moisture. An ample supply was on order at the time and received soon after. I may say that Elkhorn has continued to receive the same quantities of food as in other schools and that there has been no reduction in spite of rising costs.

It is a little discouraging that the investigator should not find anything favourable in the administration except the cleanliness of the pig pens. If he had looked a little more deeply I think he might have found some things that were satisfactory. For example,
the school ought at least to be tested in some measure by its educational results. My impression is that the reports of the Provincial School Inspector will show that we have been able to maintain three efficient teachers whose work was warmly commended. My personal observations have suggested that splendid work has been done in teaching the children to sing, and I have nowhere seen happier faces or heard better singing than in this school. I further believe that if Dr. Simes had visited such a building as that at Brandon before or after being at Elkhorn he would have had more sympathy with our staff in their infinitely more difficult task.

Dr. Simes asks if the necessary expenditures for satisfactory occupancy of the building can be justified. My personal conclusion, which has been recently supported by Principal House, is that it can. I am confident that conditions at this moment are infinitely better than they were seven months ago. We have a new Principal eagerly taking hold of the situation, a new Farm Instructor, and a competent staff of fifteen which will stand comparison. The three new class-rooms which have taken so much of the time and strength of the staff in the past two years are now in use, and two play rooms have at last been made available in the building. I understand that new plumbing equipment has been installed and that repairs are being undertaken through the interest of Inspector Hamilton. In spite of the amount of unfavourable criticism there was no difficulty in securing a full quota of pupils this fall, and I was specially surprised to note an even larger number than usual coming from the Pas area.

I am sorry to have had to write at such length but need scarcely say that we have been deeply disturbed not only at this report but at the continued attitude of defeatism towards this particular school. I cannot help feeling that Dr. Simes went to the school with the conviction in his mind that it ought to be closed. He looked for reasons to support this conviction and had no difficulty in finding them. If it can be decided by all concerned that Elkhorn is necessary and is definitely going to continue, so that effective measures may be taken to bring the building up to a worthy standard, I believe there is every hope of a real advance from this point. We have confidence in our present staff, six having come to us since the spring, and shall do our utmost to support them.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood
Secretary.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 6 and to thank you for the information contained therein.

You will be interested to learn that it is my intention to discuss conditions at Elkhorn and a number of other matters, at Toronto, with Canon Dixon, during the course of the present week. I can assure you that the officials of this Branch appreciate very fully the difficulties confronting the principals of residential schools in the operation of these institutions in recent years and particularly during the war period. In this connection, however, may I remind you of a conversation I had with you about two years ago, a conversation, a broad outline of which was later embodied in a personal letter to you. In that conversation and in that letter I expressed the opinion that our residential schools throughout the Dominion were being subjected to a great deal of unfair criticism and that a great many citizens appeared to be losing their faith in the usefulness of these Indian schools. I suggested to you then that men like Canon Middleton, yourself and others that might be selected should be encouraged to appear before the public - Rotary Clubs, Church Societies, regular Church Congregations, and tell the simple story of what men and women in charge of our schools were attempting to do. I would not be frank with you if I did not state that I have been somewhat disappointed at the apparent unwillingness of the Churches - and in this I include all the churches - to defend publicly our residential schools against a great deal of meaningless criticism.

I was at the Elkhorn Indian School on October 31st and November 1st. Mr. R.E. Hiltz had just arrived the previous afternoon and Mr. House, the Acting Principal, was preparing to return to his school in Alberta.

Mr. House had only been at the school a few weeks; but he is an experienced principal and even in a short time made many improvements. The building throughout was much cleaner. The toilets were all working. The staff appeared more co-operative and the children were more content and happier. The question of discipline appears no problem and I am inclined to think Mr. Hiltz will handle the situation quite well.

Mr. House had a carpenter building a porch at the entrance to one of the classrooms. This porch protected the door and made accommodation for the children's clothing. I understand the total expense for material and labor will not exceed $100.00.

The Farming Instructor, who I feel was a disturbing element on the staff, has resigned and a Mr. Dahl has taken over the position. Mr. Dahl is an experienced farmer and also a first-class carpenter. He is expected to keep the barns and out-buildings in good repair.

Mr. House found the school without vegetables. He immediately purchased a large quantity of potatoes, cabbage, turnips, beets, onions and carrots. All these vegetables are of excellent quality and should last throughout most of the winter; especially the potatoes.

Mr. Gow, of the Dominion Water Power Bureau, purchased the tar necessary to repair the roof of the school and the classroom. I took the material up by car and the repair work was to be done by the engineer and Mr. Dahl.

The fire escape doors had just arrived and Mr. Hiltz writes that they have already been installed.

The children appeared clean, but were none too well clothed. Mr. Hiltz noticed this himself and assures me that this will be corrected as soon as possible.

The meals served were well cooked and there appeared ample for all. Breakfast consisted of porridge with milk, bread with jam, peanut butter or lard; cocoa or milk to drink. Dinner was potatoes, one other vegetable, meat, gravy, bread, milk pudding, and water to drink except for the small ones and they receive milk. Supper consisted of soup, bread with lard, dried fruit or jam, cocoa or milk to drink.

The milk supply at present is eight gallons at night and about the same in the morning. The cook stated that any shortage was supplemented by dry milk.
Now in reference to the plumbing referred to in your letter 106-0-1, dated October 21st, 1944. I found one toilet bowl broken. This, of course, must be renewed. The additional four bowls and four baths are no doubt needed. Mr. Yates from Brantford had men working at Virden and I was able to get his views concerning the proposed installations. He visited both the boys' and girls' side of the building and agreed that the present arrangements were inadequate. He pointed out the work involved in taking up the cement and renewing old pipe which is practically worn our or clogged. He explained that on work of this nature it was difficult to give a definite price; because almost always unforeseen difficulties would arise. He intimated the complete job would cost in the neighborhood of $500.00. The material would be five toilet bowls complete, four bath tubs, 10 pair taps (washbasin), necessary pipes and valve fixtures.

I have already recommended the purchase of a new pump for the septic tank. This is urgently needed because the one in use is practically finished. If it fails to operate the sewerage will back up into the school and make operating impossible. Please advise if the pump has been ordered.

I would recommend that authority be granted at once for the following repairs:

1. The re-treading of four stairways. This entails a lot of work because the underpart of the stairway is plastered and this must all be removed.

2. The renewing of worn treads in two other stairways.

3. Reflooring two hallways first floor in hall at top of stairway.

4. Renewing half the ceiling in boys' playroom by use of plaster board.

5. One door to make and hang.

6. Patch plaster in hall and girls' dormitory.

Dear Mr. Hey:-

Re Elkhorn School

I have to thank you for your letter #106-0-1 of Nov. 13th. As I am looking forward to being in Ottawa on the 23rd and 24th I shall look forward to the chance of discussing a number of matters with you.

May I just say now that I have had many opportunities in the past year of commending the work of our Residential Schools to Church congregations and Societies. I also circularized a number of our Principals and know that many of them have been using whatever opportunities they could. I have also the promise of our Missionary Society to take one Principal each year for a period and allow him to travel around as a missionary deputation. The difficulty about this to date has been that with reduced staffs it has seemed impossible to release any Principal at such a time. The Woman's Auxiliary of our Church has also agreed to use some of our workers in this way but again they desire that they be released in the winter season when it is so hard for us to release any members of the staff.

For my part I have been taking Kodachrome pictures and am now seeking opportunities to show these in various quarters.

I just mention these facts to indicate that I am alive to the need you mention and may say that we are deeply conscious that our work is at present under fire from many quarters and not least from critics within the Church. I shall certainly welcome a thorough going survey of the whole problem of Indian education and believe that this would be most valuable for the sake of all parties concerned.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:-

I think it well at this time to advise you of the progress being made at the above school. Our new Principal, Mr. R.E. Hiltz, has been into the city once or twice to discuss matters with us and we have also had the opportunity of discussing matters with Inspector Hamilton.

We have been delighted with the manner in which Mr. Hiltz has tackled the problem. He came to the school with the experience of Lytton and the example of Rev. C.F. Hives to guide him. Very many of the difficulties pointed out by Dr. Simes were quickly remedied. Mr. Hiltz has engaged extra local help to carry out repair work and to assist in the cleansing and furnishing of the building in certain directions where the work had been too much for the ordinary staff. He seems to have been able to create a new spirit of loyalty and enthusiasm among the staff, and we are confident that the spirit of the school has been changed.

Several staff changes have taken place and we are confident that the new workers secured will do much to raise the tone of the school. The new Farm Instructor has already made changes which have greatly increased the supply of milk and we have confidence that in the coming year he will be able to develop the garden along new lines.

In the matter of food, Mr. Hiltz has declared that in the main supplies were adequate but he has made a number of changes making for greater variety and attractiveness. We have approved of his suggestion that bread should be secured from a bakery at Virden and are well satisfied that this is of high quality. As a result the bakery worker is now acting as an assistant to the Kitchen Matron and fuller supervision can be given to the preparation of the meals. The children are receiving less bread, more milk, more fruit and in general we feel confident that little fault could now be found with the food. The Principal has also introduced a better system in the serving of the meals so that the food is warm and appetizing when received.

In the matter of clothing Mr. Hiltz found that a number
of items were short and this again was a result of bad management, as the Woman's Auxiliary of our Missionary Society freely supplies adequate clothing when it is ordered by the school. Our records show that about $4,200.00 was spent in 1943 and there ought to have been adequate supplies. In the matter of bedding there was a real shortage in some lines and Mr. Hiltz has sent in very heavy requisitions which are now being filled. I understand that the Department has been securing new mattresses and we have on order a large quantity of blankets from the Army surplus supplies.

As for the building, I am delighted to know that various repairs are being undertaken now by the Department. New stairs were being built and I understand that considerable painting will be done in the near future. The Principal has had all the lockers removed from the dormitories and these are being placed in the playrooms. This will serve to increase the air space and we have instructed the Principal to keep his attendance down to 130 so that there may be no complaint of overcrowding.

The Principal has thrown himself enthusiastically into the task of reviving organizations that had been allowed to lapse. Both the Scout troop and Guide Company are now functioning and a choir is being trained to give a candlelight service at Christmas time in the village Church. We have gladly authorized the necessary expenditure to have the children join for choir work, and believe this will help to lift the spirit of the institution. Mr. Hiltz is already working along various lines to have a real graduation at the close of the school year, including a program of sports, drills and other entertainment. It is his desire to have the school in such condition at that time that he may invite Dr. Simes and other representatives of the Department and community, that all may be satisfied that real progress has been attained.

I need scarcely say that it gives me great pleasure to note this change for the better and to assure you that we shall support our staff to the utmost in what they are doing.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.

ACT I

This is a fictional legend of the Pagan days of the Indians of North America, when the early missionaries were trying, sometimes against great odds, to gain a foothold and to bring the tribes out of their ancient superstition and fears of old taboos. The great Goddess of the tribe of Dackou was the Goddess of the Moon, to whom was offered human sacrifices, which constituted the greatest feast of the year.

No, a young brave, who as a youth had been lost from the village, was found by some missionaries, who took him in. In the subsequent years he became wise in the teachings of the great Christian God, Gitchimanitou. When he was a child, he had a friend, Little One, whom he grew to love very much. Now Little One was a Pagan and a great leader under her father the Chief.

One day as the feast was on and the Priestess to the Moon Goddess was in attendance, White Cloud, now a handsome Christian brave, returned to this Pagan scene to claim his love. The tribe are all stunned by his appearance as he stands gazing at Little One. Even the Medicine Man, dancing wildly, is a little afraid.

The Princess Little One recognizes him and runs with outstretched arms to embrace her love. He is indignant and thrusts her from him. She falls to the ground. Rising, she pleads with him. He tells her of Gitchimanitou who can truly make them happy. She is reluctant to forsake her Pagan ways. He leaves her. As he leaves, the Priestess casts an evil spell over him and then turns and goes to the Princess, persuading her to continue with the sacrifice.
ACT II

The Moon Goddess sees from her abode in the starry heights, that Little One has great love for White Club and knows that she would be doomed to destruction should the Princess accept White Cloud's offer of a new life.

Then follows the Dance of the Totems representing the Pagan worship of the tribe, and the Dance of the Little White Spirits, which shows the influx of the new belief into the life of the tribe.

Then appear the attendants of the Moon Goddess, and finally the Moon Goddess herself, in all her splendor, amid the showering of star dust. The Moon Goddess offers the Princess worldly wealth, and failing thus to hold her, tries to force her into submission by threatening that evil powers would descend on her. The Princess collapses sobbing to the ground. The Moon Goddess departs and the White spirits comfort her in her distress. The soft rays of the full moon bathe the scene in a strange tranquility, disturbed only by the glow of a distant campfire.
ACT III

White Cloud is seated by a fire. Little One is standing by the totems. It is twilight. The attendants and the Priestess to the Moon Goddess appear and as they dance, the Moon Goddess enters and condemns White Cloud as evil and taboo. White Cloud is stabbed by a frenzied brave and falls to the ground. Little One runs to him and as she kneels there, the White Spirits enter holding a cross. If the cross touches the spirit of evil, it dies. Knowing this the Moon Goddess tries to escape, but is surrounded. Forced to touch the cross, she dies by the lake. White Cloud revives and all kneel as a light appears reflecting the glory of Gitchimanitou. White Cloud rises and walks off slowly into the light leading Little One by the hand.

THE END

OUR AIM

In producing Moon Goddess it has been our aim to put before the public for their approval, something different in the field of entertainment; but more than that, it has taught these children to whom, often, there comes little opportunity for such things; confidence and independence. They are capable and should have the chance to develop latent talents which are surely here presented.

In one short month this show has been organized, trained, and staged with ordinary children all under the age of sixteen. If this can be accomplished in so short a time, it is proof enough that a show on a Dominion basis, picking talent from all the Indian Schools and bringing them together in one school for six months, training them, then begin a Canadian tour from Coast to Coast. During this time they should also receive schooling in classroom work.

We are sure this would put the Indian in and before the public in a much better standing than many receive them now, and that when possibilities are known and promoted, would raise considerably their own morale to make them better citizens and good Canadians.

We would appreciate any remarks on this subject and suggestions for its continuance to a successful conclusion.
