Re: Conditions at Elkhorn Indian Residential School

With further reference to your memorandum of March 7th, 1944, I have the honor to submit the following report:

I sincerely regret that this report has not been completed at an earlier date, but it has been rather difficult to accurately describe the findings.

On my return from the East, arrangements were made with Inspector A. G. Hamilton, while passing through Winnipeg, to meet him at Elkhorn at 9 a.m., Tuesday, April 4th, 1944. These arrangements were carried out.

The entire day was spent at the school. Rev. C.N. Middleton, former principal, Mr. B. Hodkinson, acting principal and Miss H.K. Davies, Matron, accompanied us through the school. As wished to be present for the serving of a breakfast, dinner and supper, and to recheck some of my findings, I remained in the district over night and revisited the school on April 5th, 1944.

I regret to have to report that I never anticipated finding conditions in any school, as existed in the Elkhorn Residential School. Mr. Cornelius Bigwell's statement, made to Mr. D. J. Allan, sums up the situation perfectly when he says:

"While it was admitted that living conditions in an Indian village were not of a very high standard, they were much less crude, much less insanitary and much more convenient than their children enjoyed in the Elkhorn School."

The Indians have every justification to complain. They are to be congratulated on the gentlemanly manner of action taken to have matters remedied. This lack of supervision and interest in the school and pupils, as well as mismanagement, is not of recent origin. It has been going on for an indefinite period. A climax has been reached, which calls for drastic action, if this school is going to properly serve its pupils and obtain the results which are expected by the Indian Department, in return for their Per Capita Grant.

When the findings are considered from every angle, nothing favorable can be said for the present administration of this institution. To permit present conditions to continue will eventually not only bring severe public criticism on the Indian Affairs Branch, but serve no useful purpose in uplifting or helping the Indians.

A satisfactory school staff no doubt can be obtained.

p.t.o.
On approaching the school one received the impression that there was lack of organization, supervision and interest. The grounds were very untidy; articles of clothing and other wearing apparel were scattered over the yard, school entrances and steps. Many window panes were broken. The unbroken panes had the appearance of having been treated for a BLACKOUT, they were so dirty. Inside the building these impressions were confirmed by findings wherever you went.

At the time of my inspection, April 4th and 5th, 1946, this school was in charge of Mr. B. Hodgkinson, who had just been appointed acting principal.

148 pupils were registered, 86 of these were girls. Four pupils, two boys and one girl, were taking grade 8 and one girl was taking grade 10 in the local High School. Four patients, three girls and one boy, were confined to bed in the school infirmary.

I. DORMITORIES

(A) Air Space

The attached chart shows the available air space per pupil in each dormitory.

The Saskatchewan Government Public Health Regulations require 300 cu. ft. of air for each hospital patient and at least 400 cu. ft. for each person in any public hotel. In view of these regulations it should not be unreasonable to ask that 600 cu. ft. be provided for each occupant in any room used as a dormitory, for ten months of the year.

If such is the case, this chart shows a definite over crowding exists.

(B) Ventilation

Small slides at the bottom of some windows were the only source of ventilation. Broken window panes indirectly supplemented this means of ventilation. It certainly was not adequate or satisfactory. A draft passed over the occupants of the beds opposite the open windows.

Provision could be made for all windows in dormitories to open at least six inches from the top.

(C) Beds & Bedding

All that can be said in favor of the beds is that they are of pre-war manufacture. As such they are sturdier built than it is possible to purchase at the present time. Their appearance would be improved by a coat of enamel. The springs are held together by every conceivable means, wire, cord, etc. It should be possible to secure wire links and coils to repair these springs. The springs on every bed will require extensive repairs.

"Filthy" is the only word and even that does not adequately describe the condition of mattresses, pillows,
and bedding. The majority of the mattresses have long since served their usefulness.

Only the pillows in the junior girls' dormitory were noticed to have pillow slips. In all other dormitories they were conspicuous by their absence.

2. PLUMBING

(A) Toilets

The attached chart also shows toilet facilities and condition of same in each dormitory.

Three toilet bowls were situated at the south end of the girls' wash room. Two of these were in proper working order. One did contain fecal matter. Another had a bad leak from an over half flushing tank, which flooded the floor surrounding the toilets. This leak could not be of recent origin, as there was a piece of wooden duck walk in front of the bowl, to keep the user's feet out of the water. The door at the entrance of one toilet was off its hinges.

The toilet paper containers were located outside of the toilet on the wall between the doors.

In the boys wash and play room on the south side of the building, there was plumbing for three toilet bowls but only two were installed. There were no urinals.

Not a single toilet bowl in the whole school had a seat. The majority of the bowls were badly stained, and had an uncared for appearance.

I have no recollection of seeing any outside toilets.

The Saskatchewan Provincial Health Regulations require one toilet seat to every 18 pupils.

(B) Wash Basins

The girls' washroom, which is 27' by 14' is located on the ground floor in the west half of northern portion of the building. This room is cold and uninviting, possibly due to its cement floor and poor lighting.

Ten wash basins provided with two taps each, are situated on the west wall of this room. Examination revealed that neither tap on one basin, and only one on three others were in working order. Some of the basins contained dirty water. On investigation it was found that the stoppers were made of toilet paper.

Two roller towels were hanging in this room.

The boys' washroom, which is 26' by 14' is located in the southern portion on the ground floor. It also was cold and uninviting, similar to the girls for the same reason.

Twelve basins provided with two taps each, are situated on the west wall. Neither taps on one, and only one on two other basins were working.

Two roller towels were hanging in this room.
Not a single stopper was found in either wash room. All basins had an uncared for appearance.

(C) Bathing Accommodation

Two tubs for use of the girls were partitioned off in the northern end of their play room. The floor is of cement. It was moist at the time of our visit. There was a wooden duck talk beside each tub. Both of these were in broken condition. There was a shower fixture over one tub, which was leaking. The handle for its control valve was missing. As the tub had a rusted spot, where the shower dripped, one would conclude the leak was not of recent origin.

On the boys' side a small room 9' by 14' adjacent to their play rooms, contained two tubs as well as a shower. The waste water from the baths and shower flows out over the floor to an open drain in the boys play and wash room.

3. HEATING FACILITIES

Even if the building had been kept in first class repair, difficulty in maintaining a satisfactory temperature would be experienced on account of its age. With the neglect, which is evident in toilets, wash basins and bathrooms, is equally evident in not maintaining the building in good repair. Poorly fitted storm windows, absence of storm doors, and innumerable broken panes of glass, increase the heating difficulties.

The heating plant is a Gurney Hot Water Furnace, equipped with an automatic stoker. One section of the furnace was reported cut off when the stoker was installed a few years ago. The engineer admitted difficulty in maintaining a comfortable temperature in many of the rooms during the cold weather, especially if it was windy. From personal experience, this furnace does not appear to be any more than large enough to satisfactorily heat this building, if all its sections were in perfect working order.

If the welfare of the children had been considered, steps would have been taken to have the defective section repaired and put in order. The inability to maintain the building at a comfortable temperature did not originate during the winter months of 1943-44.

4. FIRE HAZARDS

The fire escapes in the dormitories lead through a window using only the lower half. The steps up to these windows were not solid; with the confusion during a fire, they are apt to cause the pupils to fall. Serious consequences could easily result. In the laundry there is an old kitchen range used to heat the sad irons. While it was located adjacent to the chimney it had to be continually operated with all drafts wide open. Clothes on lines and on clothes horses were near this stove. This did constitute a serious fire menace as it was on the basement floor in the center of the building.

Throughout the building were fire extinguishers.

5. CLOTHING & GENERAL
5. CLOTHING & GENERAL APPEARANCE OF THE CHILDREN

No matter where the children were contacted, in the class rooms, in the dining room, about the school, or out of doors on the playground, they were dirty and their clothes were disgraceful. The clothing was not only dirty but torn and ragged. Their stockings were full of holes. Not a single child was observed to be wearing a good pair of boots. No difference was noticed in the clothing worn at meals, in the class room or outside. Several of the boys took off overalls when they came into the wash room from outside.

Many of the children playing out doors had a half frozen appearance.

There is no doubt about these children being very poorly clad. They certainly were not provided with sufficient clothing to keep warm during the cold winter months, if they did not have on more appropriate clothing than worn the day of this inspection.

There was no evidence of extra clothing having been issued, except what seen in the laundry and sewing room. The quantity observed in these two places did not impress one as being sufficient for a complete change for all pupils.

The provision made, for the care of clothing in use, was not such to induce or teach any child to care for their wearing apparel. For example, in the girls' washroom, along the wall 27' in length was supposed to be sufficient hooks for 88 girls to hang their coats and hats up. Along this same wall was a row of seats which had open pigeon holes underneath. These were crammed with old boots, rubbers, dirty clothing and everything else. In the boys' washroom exactly the same unsatisfactory and untidy condition existed. Here there was a wall 26' long to provide space for 55 boys to hang outside wearing apparel.

No provision has been made for the children to keep any personal belongings they have or receive. Apparently a few did try to keep them underneath the mattresses. There are good lockers in the small boys', intermediate and junior girls' dormitories, but not a single one was in use.

When a good wind breaker was found in the manure at the cow barn, Rev. C.H. Middleton, stated, although every boy had been issued with a new wind breaker last fall, at Christmas time only five could be accounted for.

As regards dental hygiene, a tooth brush rack containing two brushes was noticed above the basins in the girls' wash room. On the boys' side the tooth brush rack was noticed in the linen room. On enquiring why it was located there, the Boys' Supervisor replied that brushes were given out to be used immediately before going to class. From what was seen, one would conclude that dental hygiene was given very little consideration.

While visiting the laundry, it was observed that the children were getting their clothing and shoes soaking wet, during the process of removing the contents of the washing machine into a tub for rinsing. This work seemed very
unnecessary, as the rinsing could have been done in the washing machine. Miss Allison, the Laundry Matron, was asked why this extra work. She replied her instructions were to get two washings from one lot of suds.

6. FOOD

A copy of the menu SUPPOSED to be in use is attached hereto, also a list of weights of all pupils taken on the day of inspection.

It is to be expected that a large percentage of pupils on returning to school, following their summer vacation, will be under weight. Such a condition should not exist a month or so before they are leaving for their summer vacation, if they have been receiving sufficient and proper diet. At the time of inspection 28% of the girls and 69.3% of the boys are underweight in this school.

The dining room was visited for the mid day and evening meals on April 4th, breakfast and mid day meal on April 5th, while these meals were being served and eaten. From observation during these four meals, it was apparent there were more OMISSIONS than SUBSTITUTIONS in the menu.

The meals were not appetizing. Each child received an enamel plate, enamel cup and a spoon. Not a single knife or fork was noticed in the dining room at any of the meals. Bean and bread appeared to constitute the main item of food, the former being the principal and only vegetable observed. The latter was the most abundant item of food on the tables. The bread was baked in the school and was of very good quality.

All food except the bread was placed on the enamel plates. The bread previously to being brought to the table was smeared on one side with warm grease. Bread was served with each meal but only at two meals was it served with lard. Approximately three slices, more properly described as hunks, were placed directly on the table beside each pupil's plate.

At no time did the children receive butter.

At the mid day meal the younger children were given milk; the older ones received water. For breakfast and the evening meal all were SUPPOSED to have cocoa made from milk and sweetened with sugar.

7. FOODS AVAILABLE

Mrs. D. A. Oakley, Kitchen Matron, informed me they had just been out of potatoes for four or five days. Rev. C. N. Middleton, former principal, also informed me that it would be necessary to buy potatoes and other vegetables from now until the new crop was available.

Vegetables were supposed to be on order.

In the vegetable bins below the kitchen were a few small heads of cabbage and a small number of turnips. Neither here nor in the root cellar beneath the new class
rooms, where the vegetables were supposed to have been stored, could a sufficient quantity of one or any combination of vegetables be found, for one meal for this school.

The meat is bought at the local butcher store. Apparently they do not buy any particular cuts of meat. On checking the counter slips for meat purchased during the month of February, they bought 40 to 60 lbs. of meat per day. The Matron and Lady in charge of the kitchen explained that the butcher delivered hamburger very frequently. At no time did the children ever get roast meat.

During my conversation with the Matron, mention was made about securing eggs for Easter. I availed myself of the opportunity to enquire from her how frequently the children were given an egg for breakfast or any other meal. She replied that since she had been the Matron not on a single occasion had the children been provided with such a luxury.

Bread pudding constitutes an important item in their noon day meal. On enquiring about the source of the bread used for this purpose, I learned that it was left over bread gathered up after each meal.

THE FOLLOWING OUTSIDE BUILDINGS WERE INSPECTED

1. PUMPING PLANT - from the septic tank which was in working order.

2. NEW CLASS ROOMS - in what was formerly the old gymnasium building. They were nearing completion. I understand that this will make available for play rooms the two rooms now being used as class rooms in the main building.

3. HORSE BARN - showed the usual evidence of lack of care. Windows were broken or absent. Doors off hinges. There was an accumulation of manure. Parts of harness were lying about the barn in the manure.

4. PIG PEN - This really was the only building which showed evidence of receiving any attention. The most galling part here was when I enquired if it was the intention to butcher the three pigs which appeared ready for market, I was told they were not for the school use, but were to be sold to the local butcher.

5. COW BARN - Two or three of the younger boys were attempting to clean this building. All the cattle were out. The barn had not been cleaned for one week if not longer. It certainly did not have a sanitary appearance to insure a satisfactory milk supply. There was an excellent silo, which was liable to be blown down and destroyed at any time, due to carelessness in not keeping the guy wires in position and tight.

6. POULTRY HOUSE - There was a flock of poultry. The replies to my enquiries led me to believe that they received sufficient eggs to supply the school requirements. Later I learned that it supplied only the requirements of the staff.

7. VEGETABLE STORAGE & FACILITIES - Provision was made for the storage of vegetables adjacent to the furnace room under the new class rooms. The provision made was much too small.

ACT I

This is a fictional legend of the Pagan days of the Indians of North America, when the early missionaries were trying, sometimes against great odds, to gain a foothold and to bring the tribes out of their ancient superstition and fears of old taboos. The great Goddess of the tribe of Dackou was the Goddess of the Moon, to whom was offered human sacrifices, which constituted the greatest feast of the year.

No, a young brave, who as a youth had been lost from the village, was found by some missionaries, who took him in. In the subsequent years he became wise in the teachings of the great Christian God, Gitchimanitou. When he was a child, he had a friend, Little One, whom he grew to love very much. Now Little One was a Pagan and a great leader under her father the Chief.

One day as the feast was on and the Priestess to the Moon Goddess was in attendance, White Cloud, now a handsome Christian brave, returned to this Pagan scene to claim his love. The tribe are all stunned by his appearance as he stands gazing at Little One. Even the Medicine Man, dancing wildly, is a little afraid.

The Princess Little One recognizes him and runs with outstretched arms to embrace her love. He is indignant and thrusts her from him. She falls to the ground. Rising, she pleads with him. He tells her of Gitchimanitou who can truly make them happy. She is reluctant to forsake her Pagan ways. He leaves her. As he leaves, the Priestess casts an evil spell over him and then turns and goes to the Princess, persuading her to continue with the sacrifice.
ACT II

The Moon Goddess sees from her abode in the starry heights, that Little One has great love for White Club and knows that she would be doomed to destruction should the Princess accept White Cloud's offer of a new life.

Then follows the Dance of the Totems representing the Pagan worship of the tribe, and the Dance of the Little White Spirits, which shows the influx of the new belief into the life of the tribe.

Then appear the attendants of the Moon Goddess, and finally the Moon Goddess herself, in all her splendor, amid the showering of star dust. The Moon Goddess offers the Princess worldly wealth, and failing thus to hold her, tries to force her into submission by threatening that evil powers would descend on her. The Princess collapses sobbing to the ground. The Moon Goddess departs and the White spirits comfort her in her distress. The soft rays of the full moon bathe the scene in a strange tranquility, disturbed only by the glow of a distant campfire.

ACT III

White Cloud is seated by a fire. Little One is standing by the totems. It is twilight. The attendants and the Priestess to the Moon Goddess appear and as they dance, the Moon Goddess enters and condemns White Cloud as evil and taboo. White Cloud is stabbed by a frenzied brave and falls to the ground. Little One runs to him and as she kneels there, the White Spirits enter holding a cross. If the cross touches the spirit of evil, it dies. Knowing this the Moon Goddess tries to escape, but is surrounded. Forced to touch the cross, she dies by the lake. White Cloud revives and all kneel as a light appears reflecting the glory of Gitchimanitou. White Cloud rises and walks off slowly into the light leading Little One by the hand.

THE END

A striking scene of light and music featuring the singing of Gounod's "Ave Maria" by Miss Margaret Gibney accompanied by the Chapel Choir, followed by an unaccompanied arrangement of Malotte's "The Lord's Prayer."

Appealing to the eye and ear, it is a solemn moment which speaks of peace to come.

OUR AIM

In producing Moon Goddess it has been our aim to put before the public for their approval, something different in the field of entertainment; but more than that, it has taught these children to whom, often, there comes little opportunity for such things; confidence and independence. They are capable and should have the chance to develop latent talents which are surely here presented.

In one short month this show has been organized, trained and staged with ordinary children all under the age of sixteen. If this can be accomplished in so short a time, it is proof enough that a show on a Dominion basis, picking talent from all the Indian Schools and bringing them together in one school for six months, training them, then begin a Canadian tour from Coast to Coast. During this time they should also receive schooling in classroom work.

We are sure this would put the Indian in and before the public in a much better standing than many receive them now, and that when possibilities are known and promoted, would raise considerably their own morale to make them better citizens and good Canadians.

We would appreciate any remarks on this subject and suggestions for its continuance to a successful conclusion.

Sincerely,

I submit the following report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, inspected May 3rd, 1946.

There are 108 children in residence and they are accommodated in three classrooms. The work seen was good and I consider that they are making fair progress.

The dormitories were well aired and tidy. The beds were neatly made and the bedding clean. All plumbing was in good working order.

The toilets and washrooms are well kept, tidy and clean. Towels are provided for each child and these are numbered, and hung on hooks. The walls are painted a light colour and I found the place well aired. There is a marked improvement in the care and appearance of these rooms.

The food is well cooked and the children have ample at each meal. Mr. Dixon, the Principal, provides the same food for staff and children and he and the staff eat in the same room as the children, in fact there is one staff member at the head of each table. I believe this change is good because the children are well supervised during meal time. The staff member knows that each child gets plenty of food and also can give some instruction in table manners.

There was no sickness and the children appeared contented and happy.

The roof of the school building still leaks in places. The roof is covered with a metal material and the nails work loose allowing driving rain to leak through. A heavy covering of tar and sand might eliminate the trouble. The outside walls of the top storey of the school are metal like the roof. This at one time was painted red. The paint has gradually disappeared and the metal is badly rusting. I would strongly recommend that it receive a coat of red paint. The school is very high and this work would need to be done by experienced painters.

Repair work is required on the horse barn, granary and cow barn. The foundations need re-enforcing and considerable new lumber will be required to do the repair work. I suggested to Mr. Dixon that he get someone to give an estimate on the work and material, and forward it to his...
Commission. This quotation will then go forward for the Department's approval.

The new septic tank pump has given excellent service and is in good condition. The new farming instructor, Mr. Thomas, is doing good work. He has the garden ground in excellent condition for seeding and is determined there will be no shortage of potatoes or vegetables. He has also rebuilt a considerable length of fence, and has greatly improved generally the outside appearance of the yards. I am convinced that this man will do good work.

I would also recommend that a quantity of paint be provided for the barns. After the buildings are repaired paint will be required. It will take about two five gallon tins of red barn paint and four gallons of outside white. If green is available two gallons (outside green) should also be provided.

Mr. Dixon, the Principal, appears greatly interested in his work. He apparently is well liked by the children and discipline appears now to be no great problem. I am confident one can look forward to a marked improvement at Elkhorn School under the new management.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
for Manitoba.

Dear Sir;

Regarding your letter of the 29 ultimo, concerning vacations in this School, may I state that I was unaware of the regulations on this count, applying to residential schools, and have been doing the same as was done last year, i.e., having only the minimum of holidays observed throughout the term.

The reasons for this policy are manifold. First of all we have not adequate playroom space, no gymnasium, not even a reading room, hence no indoor sports equipment to speak of. This of course works a hardship on the Staff, which are, at this season of the year, and as it is the case this year short handed, over worked to say the least. Leaving scarcely any option in the matter, unless one wishes to be left with an even shorter Staff due to illness. (I have one such case on my hands now and consider I am more or less fortunate at that.) And as it is so hard to obtain people to work in these schools, I can see no other way to deal with the situation, than to have them in the Classrooms as much as possible.

As for outdoor sports we have an open air rink, which as a rule takes more time to keep the snow off than the Children get to skate on it. And as I understand neither the Church nor your Dept. make any allowance for the equipment for this form of sport, or as far as I know any outdoor winter sport.

We have a 16mm. sound projection machine but other than the National Film Board and Dept. of Education we cannot afford films and these are not exactly entertaining.

Then again the classrooms are so difficult to heat if there is a wind that often one or another of the classes return to the Children's dinning room, which interferes with their schooling actually. The Engineer is working on a forced circulation idea that we hope will alleviate the situation to some extent and perhaps carry us over till Spring without a general exodus of the teaching Staff.
This, Col. Neary, exemplifies what I understand you are quite aware of; that this place has been neglected for so many years, as regards improvements that it is almost imperative that something be done this year to improve matters in general, if it is to carry on in its present capacity, for the well being of both Children and Staff.

I hope I have given you ample justification for what I have done in this matter I remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Some of the parents of The Pas Band, who have children attending the Elkhorn Residential School visited their children during the Xmas holidays at Elkhorn. Many complaints were brought back by them and reported to me and the Chief and Councillors of The Pas Band. These complaints were recorded and I immediately got in touch with Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg, and gave him all the details I had. The Chief and one Indian that had four children attending this school made a trip to Elkhorn to verify conditions. They reported similar complaints which I forwarded to Mr. Hamilton.

Mr. Hamilton has made an inspection of the conditions at this school and will be submitting a report to you. Although it is not as bad as reported, conditions are far from satisfactory, and many of the parents of The Pas Band intend to bring their children home unless some improvement is made.

I have now informed the Chief that a report has been submitted to Ottawa, and he may rest assured that the children will be given better food, clothing, and a general clean-up of conditions is anticipated. Mr. Hamilton's report will give in detail, I am sure, the complaints submitted, and suggestions for improvements.

Chief Bignell has stated that the children will remain there at present to see if the changes asked for are made. Only four children have returned to The Pas, those of Charlie Constant, and they are now attending the Pas Day School. I am submitting this to let you know that I am doing all I can to encourage the parents to leave their children at Elkhorn, as conditions will be improved.

At a meeting held this morning with Education Division officials and Canon Cook of the M.M.C.C., the future role of the above three Residential Schools was thoroughly discussed.

It was decided to advance the following proposals for consideration by the Regional Supervisors of Manitoba and of Saskatchewan. Therefore, this letter is addressed jointly to these officials and the Department is anxious to have your frank expression of opinion concerning these suggestions:

(a) That the pupilage of the Elkhorn Residential School be reduced to 60 pupils.

Mr. Denney has just returned from a thorough inspection visit to this school and he is convinced that the present classroom block is entirely unsuitable for future use as classrooms. He feels that with a reduced pupilage, the present dormitory or sewing room or pump-house building can be used to provide a second classroom without using the old classroom block. This would mean that only two classrooms would function at this school.

It is then proposed to have the other 60 children from this school sent to the new Lac la Bonge Residential School.
School at present situated in the army camp at Prince Albert. It will be necessary to make a careful check of the home reserves of the children involved but it is felt that in some instances it will actually be cheaper to send these children to Prince Albert rather than to Elkhorn. It is also understood that rail facilities are better to Prince Albert from certain points (for example, the sea).

(b) That the authorized pupilage at the Lac la Ronge School (presently situated in the army camp at Prince Albert) be raised from 120 to 160 pupils.

It will of course be necessary to provide additional beds, etc., for the accommodation of these extra children.

(c) That the lease on the St. Albert's School be renewed and that its pupilage be kept at the present rate of 100.

The future of this school can be decided when definite agreement has been reached with the Province of Saskatchewan with regard to the operation of a hostel at Lac la Ronge.

| Lac la Ronge | 120 | 160 |

Colonel Neary:

Elkhorn Indian Residential School:

I visited this school briefly on November 18.

Activities, including two classrooms, are restricted to the main building which looks cleaner and brighter than heretofore. Some improvements are still to be made in the boys' washroom and the laundry but no substantial outlay of money seems necessary or is recommended.

The pupilage has not yet been filled and seems unlikely to be unless we take the view that the efficiency of certain day schools would be improved by reducing the enrolment thereat. This step might be combined with a tightening of the restrictions governing absence of day school pupils.

Now that the school has been operating for three months it might be well to suggest to the school authorities that they estimate what the cost for the whole year is going to be and whether it might be advantageous to combine this school with another at the earliest opportunity. "CHEF" HOTEL RANGE

The accompanying cut serves to illustrate the exceptionally heavy construction of the Chef Hotel Range. It will be observed on close examination that all parts of the Range are fully protected from the wasting process of extreme heat, and wherever wear is the greater additional strength has been added. The thick lining of specially-manufactured firebrick cannot be equaled for service, apart from the important consideration of easy and economical replacement. The three thicknesses, viz., asbestos, steel, shown clearly on the oven doors, typical of how thoroughly the Chef is made to note the heavy grates, the roomy space under for accommodating the ashes, and the protection top of oven where heat is intense when passing off. The flue construction is shown, from which it will seen that the heat passes freely around the oven thus heating all sides evenly.

Interior Construction of Chef Range

Fig. No. 2
Showing Simple Method of Attaching Extra Ovens to Range

Here we have the three Ovens separated to demonstrate how the Range can be readily equipped with any number of Ovens. The entire right side of the Range can be instantly removed, and connection with the Ovens made with a strip of metal running down front and back of the Range. With the removal of the end of the Range the flues are left free for the pass along the top and around the additional Ovens with ease. Fig. shows the construction of the flues.

CONSTRUCTION:

Body: The Body is of 10-Gauge Highest-grade Steel, 1/8" thick, riveted, bolted and lined with pure firebrick. Ends and back of Range braced with heavy angle iron.

Top: The Top is of heavy cast-iron, burnished to a smooth finish by a special process. Outside frame 3/4" thick, with flanges to support French plates, which are 1 3/4" thick.

Walls: Walls of Heavy Steel Plate, with sides and top of each piece—steel-plate bottom strengthened with cast-iron stiffeners. Top is covered with asbestos and protected by heavy cast-iron grating. Outside and top edges protected by cast-iron shields.

Oven Door: Doors of Heavy Gauge Steel Plate, with 1 1/2x3/4" wrought-iron frames with reinforced corners. Door panels made of 3/4" wrought-iron bars.

Catch, permitting door to be slightly open if desired.

Firebox Linings: Of Firebrick—manufactured for this purpose by special process.

Firebox lined in front with 6" firebrick; other three sides with 1" firebrick.

Bottom with 1" firebrick.

Bottom of Ovens with 1" firebrick.

Back of Oven, 6" solid firebrick.

Brick over top of Oven Door, 3" brick.

All bricks are standard size and replaced by any bricks available locally.

Grate: Heavy, Semicircular, Cast-iron Grate.

Connection: Of Cast-iron with hinged cleaning door at underside.

FEATURES:

The "CHEF" Hotel Range is constructed to give unlimited cooking and baking results to satisfy requirements of the most exacting nature. Built of the finest materials available, it undergoes rigid tests before use. Only the most skilled craftsmen are permitted to assist in the building up of the entire fabric of the "Chef" Range enabling it to withstand the heaviest strain to which it may be subjected.

The Burnished Top: Clean and sanitary—Toasting, Frying and Broiling can readily be done on its smooth surface.

The Cooking Surface: A clear cooking surface without impediments to hinder operations.

Sectional Ring Cover over Fire: Permits pots of any size to come into direct contact with the heat.

Smoke Pipe: May be attached to top or at the back—under certain conditions down draft flues may be arranged for.

Grates: Heavy semicircular grates readily cut out clinkers and ashes by gently rocking shaker to and fro. Entire contents of firebox may be dumped into ash-pan by turning Grate completely over.

The Grate is easily removed by loosening four nuts on the outside, the grate-plate falling away, permitting grates to be taken out without further trouble.

Ovens: Have holes near top of back for ventilating purposes; these are protected by a shield.

Control and Heating handled from the front of the Range by dampers for each oven and direct damper when lighting fire.

With the sheet-flue construction each Oven can be handled and heated separately so that the temperature of each Oven can be regulated independently.

HOT BLAST FOR SOFT COAL

The requirements for burning soft coal are adequately met by the air passing up to the top of the fire from the lower side at the back of the firebox. During its passage through the space at the back of the firebox, the cold air comes in contact with the hot surface and becomes intensely heated. This gives a supply of fresh, superheated air to the top of the fire providing complete combustion and carrying the flame and the heat the full length of the three ovens. By this method more heat is obtained without added use of fuel, and all ovens are satisfactorily heated.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I am enclosing two pages from The McClary Company's catalogue illustrating a range, which appears to me to be servicable for a School such as this. However, of course, this is merely a suggestion and I am quite satisfied in leaving this matter in your hands.

Sir:

With reference to the telegram signed by Dr. Westgate, of March 25th, I have the honor to report as follows.

For some time past we have experienced difficulty with the Jacket Heater, which supplies hot water for bathing, laundry and general purposes. While away with Mr. Inspector Christianson on a trip to the Reserves North of Fairford last January one section of the heater cracked right above the fire-bed. A new section was ordered by Dr. Westgate of Winnipeg from the Crane people and upon my arrival at the School this had been installed by the Engineer.

Last Saturday the next section cracked in the same place. I at once telephoned to Crane Ltd., of Winnipeg, also notified The Rev.T.B.R.Westgate,D.D. The Crane Ltd. informed me that they had not a spare section in stock and were doubtful whether they could procure one. If so it would have to come from Buffalo, U.S.A. Their expert suggested that we try to seal the crack and set down, by Express, on the evening train two cans of Se-Lent-Ol. The directions were carefully carried out under my personal supervision and we tried everything possible up to twelve o'clock midnight. Sunday morning the section was leaking just as bad as ever.

On Monday morning we telephoned Crane Ltd. again and after a long consultation with their expert he suggested we try another form of cement, X Liquid. We received two cans of X Liquid on the evening train and again the instructions were
carefully carried out under my supervision. We even tried to seal up the crack in the section that was taken out last January and after working till past twelve o'clock midnight everything proved unsuccessful.

Tuesday morning the section in the Jacket Heater was still leaking. Upon examining the interior of the sections we found them to be coated with an eighth to a quarter of an inch of lime deposit, undoubtedly due to the hardness of the water.

Yesterday I was in Winnipeg and spent the whole morning in consultation with Mr. Inspector T.H. Dunn, who at once agreed that the trouble was due to the hard water existing in Elkhorn. He at once advised that we send a wire to the Department stating our trouble and recommending that the most economical way would be to purchase a new Jacket Heater as soon as possible. The danger existing under present circumstances being due to the fact that we have on various occasions been troubled with steam in the Hot Water line leading from the Jacket Heater. Should the lime deposit at any time block the circulation of the water we would be subject to an explosion.

In the afternoon of Friday I interviewed Dr. Nestgate with regard to this matter and the telegram was sent.

So far we have not experienced any trouble with the Hot Water Furnace, which heats the building, no doubt due to the fact that the water in this system is in circulation and used over and over again. Therefore there cannot be anything like so much lime deposit in the sections but from time to time water has to be run into the expansion tank to keep up the water level in the radiators and sections of the Boiler. However, should anything like this happen to the Hot Water Boiler during the winter months, it would be impossible to secure sections within two or three weeks, which would mean considerable damage to the building even though the water be drained off.

In order to overcome the purchasing or replacing of Jacket Heaters and to eliminate any sections of the Hot Water Section Furnace from future trouble it might be advisable to have the water analyzed to ascertain the real nature of the water and if advisable install a soft water plant.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,
The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th instant with reference to circular letter No. 87 regarding question of fire fighting equipment etc. at this School.

I have the honor to report as follows:

1. With reference to the fire fighting equipment:
   (a) An additional number of large fire extinguishers should be supplied, not only for the Main Building, but for the two other houses on the plant and would suggest having six extra 2½ gallon fire extinguishers.
   (b) In case of fire our water supply would be inadequate and I would suggest that we had a reserve water tower or reservoir.
   (c) At the present time we have 700 feet of 2" Flax Hose in the building, some of which is not in very good condition.

2. With reference to Exits and Fire Escapes:
   The exits from all five dormitories are certainly unsatisfactory as these are just plain iron ladders, which cannot be used in ordinary fire drill without loss of life. They are reached by ordinary push up windows, too high for the average child to get out, covered by storm windows, without a red exit light over same.

   I would suggest that an extra fire escape be placed in the center of the building, somewhere on the north side and that the fire escape from the hospital be a form of shoot.

   The locks on the classification doors and dormitory doors are all in very poor condition and in case of emergency keys would be jammed in them, thus causing trouble.

   We have fire drill at regular intervals and can clear the School in 2 minutes by using the ordinary stairways inside the building, but in the actual case of fire more lives would be lost by using the present fire escapes than by the fire itself.

This afternoon Mr. Indian Agent Launby visited the School with Mr. Inspector Hurison who was on his way to Birtle and I took the opportunity of discussing and pointing out the above to the Inspector. You think it wise when the Inspector returns from Birtle, I shall be grateful if he could stay at the School for a short time in order that I might obtain his advice and suggestions regarding the above matter.

Thanking you, Sir, for your kindness and interest.

I have the honor to be,

W.M. Graham, Sec.,
The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter that I received from the Rev. Principal of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, with reference to the fire fighting equipment at his institution, and making a request for additional fire protection.

I think that half a dozen 2½ gallon fire extinguishers might be furnished for this school. I doubt whether anything more can be done with regard to putting in an additional supply of water. The supply here is as great as it is at any of our other schools; the thing is to keep the engine going if a fire should occur. The additional hose should be supplied.

You will note what the Principal says regarding fire escapes; these do appear to be risky. Iron ladders leading from windows are not satisfactory, and I quite agree that these children could not come down these ladders in the event of a panic. I am not very much taken with even iron tread: fire escapes - the ordinary steps, but would be more in favour of a chute. I believe this is what we should have at all schools. I was at the Qu'Appelle Industrial School the other day and they were afraid to bring the children down the steps, but at the Convent close to our school they have an iron chute and the children come down this in a very short time. There is no reason why we should not have these. With reference to the Principal's remark regarding locks on inside doors being in poor condition, I think we might replace these locks.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, No. 289-11A A.C.B., with reference to accounts submitted for material and work on root cellar.

In July last Mr. E.A. Parsons looked over the situation and stated then that it was difficult to figure on such work until the tearing down had been completed in order that a very thorough examination might be made to ascertain just what would be required to make the building absolutely frost-proof. However, he gave an approximate cost of $400.00, but after the work had been started felt convinced that unless the walls were lined with lumber, then papered and lined again, also that unless the roof was lined and papered and a ceiling put in, it certainly could not be frost-proof.

Last Fall we covered the old roof and ends of the root cellar with approximately 5' of manure and even then the frost went through leaving us, this Spring, with hundreds of bushels of frozen potatoes.

I, therefore, pointed out very clearly to Mr. Parsons that unless he could make the cellar frost-proof, he might just as well leave it alone and in order to make this secure, more lumber and work was put on than he had figured in the first place.

The work is well done and I feel certain cannot be anything but frost-proof.

Trusting the above will meet with your approval, and thanking you for your kindness in this matter.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Fred Bley

ELKHORN, MAN. February 6th., 1929.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to report that our batteries in connection with the School lighting plant are absolutely dead. When the engine is shut down in the evening around ten o'clock, there is hardly enough light for one to see to get into bed. The exit lights, naturally, are practically useless. Last year I reported this state of affairs to the Globeelite Battery Company, Limited, of Winnipeg, who shortly afterwards sent out their representative to inspect the batteries. At that time, he told us that the batteries were practically dead, and would cease to give light at almost any time. However, with careful handling, we have been able to carry on up to the present time.

As I arrived back last night with forty-four children from the Gordon's School, (according to instructions received from the Indian Commissioner) we have now a total of one hundred and sixty-four children in residence in this School, and I feel it my duty to report this matter of the batteries and to suggest that a new set be installed, in order that we may run no risks from lack of light.

I might also mention that the Reverend Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C., visited us last week, saw the condition of the batteries, and instructed me to write you on the subject.

The present batteries were installed in 1925.

There is some talk of the town of Elkhorn being supplied with electric light by the Manitoba Power Commission, who would run a pole line from the town of Virden, situated some twenty-two miles east of Elkhorn. When talking to the Mayor of Elkhorn the other day...
about this matter, he told me that nothing definite had been arranged, and he could not say when a decision would be made. If they do finally arrange to secure this light, the very earliest that this could be supplied would be some time next Fall. However, in the meantime we are sadly in need of light.

Trusting that you will give this matter your kind consideration,

I have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Rev. Fred Eley)

Recommendations re Vocational work for the Anglican Indian Residential School, Elkhorn, Manitoba.

After having the privilege of looking over this splendidly conducted institution by Rev. Mr. Eley, I spent considerable time in looking into the possibilities of providing a greater measure of vocational training.

1. In order that the boy who will return to the reserve may be a greater asset to his people in that he will be able to plan and build houses, stables, poultry and such other buildings as are needed and to repair those already built.

2. For the increasing number of boys, who, because they have considerable mechanical aptitude are anxious to find a place in the industrial world, as workers in country garages, operators of farm tractors and possibly have their own repair shop for the automobile is finding its way even to the Reserves.

In looking over the plant I noticed one two story frame building about 33' x 60' which has been sturdily built and is in pretty fair shape and well suited to the purpose for which it was probably built. It might be possible to fix the lower story of this building for a woodworking shop but it is just a question whether it would warrant the expenditure that would be needed to put it into shape for use during the winter months which in a school like this is the logical time, since there is so much work to be done on the farm and in the garden during the summer months.

I would think that the minimum amount of work that would be required to put it in shape would be about as follows:

1. The old floor would have to be taken out and a new cement floor put in its place. The old floor having sunk in several places and is unfit for use.

2. One side of the lower story would have to be re-modelled in order to get the necessary light.

3. Some system of heating would have to be installed and this would be somewhat difficult as the building does not appear to have been built with that end in view.

4. The walls would need to be plaster in order to retain the heat.

5. A new ceiling would be needed.

This building is well built and if wide doors were placed at intervals along the sides it would make a very fine implement shed and storage warehouse. It is the right distance away from the other buildings for this purpose.
Since additional class room accommodation and dormitory space is badly needed, it would appear to me that if some additional funds were provided to add to what it would take to put this building in shape a separate building to house all the educational departments of the institution would be a good investment. The class rooms vacated could be converted into dormitories and an assembly room could be provided and would help to correct the natural stolid characteristic of the Indian boys and girls. Such a building could be very compactly built.

Owing to the high water table in this district it would not be necessary to have a basement. In fact basement rooms are not desirable in a building where shops are provided for vocational work because of the difficulty of bringing in machines, etc., for repairs or for demonstration purposes.

The attached plan will give a fair general idea of the accommodation which such a building would provide.

1. On the ground floor would be a vocational woodworking shop 35' x 50'
   A metal working, auto mechanics shop 36' x 50'
   One class room for related instruction 34' x 35'
   One class room for general work 34' x 35'

2. On the second floor would be a Senior Classroom 35' x 44'
   A Junior Classroom 34' x 35'
   Teachers room 10' x 14'
   Auditorium 35' x 90'

I have not shown the elevation and the windows, doors, stairs, etc., are only approximately located. If the height of the first story is 14 feet it will make provision for a mezzanine floor at the end of both shops which will be found very convenient for storage and as a location for dismantled engines, etc.

I would not recommend the establishment of Manual Training in this institution but is near relative vocational training which means that the objective would be training for making a living whereas Manual Training work supplements the other school subjects and its aim is cultural rather than vocational.

In choosing a teacher for building construction a good all round mechanic with a good general education will be the safest yet for in addition to teaching how to build houses, etc., he should teach the boys how to lath and plaster, how to do cement work, how to build a chimney, how to shingle, how to glaze windows and how to paint.

The benches should be similar to those used by carpenters and can be built by the pupils. If the lumber used is sent dressed it will not be necessary to provide any woodworking machines.
As the tools will receive bad usage it will be cheaper in the end to purchase tools of good quality.

Dear Sir:-

Re:- Vocational training etc., at Elkhorn School.

With further reference to my letter of Dec. 11th last, addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General, and his reply on Dec. 19th, re the development of vocational training in our Society's Indian Residential Schools, and more particularly with regard to the development of that branch of education in our Elkhorn School, I beg to state that our Commission were fortunate enough to secure the services of Mr. S. T. Newton, Director of Technical Education in the Province of Manitoba, to visit the Elkhorn School and to submit a report and recommendations in this connection. Dear Mr. Scott:

With further reference to my letter of December 11 last, and your reply to the same on December 19, relative to the development of manual training in the Indian Schools administered by our Society, and more particularly with regard to the development of this branch of education at our Elkhorn School, you will have before you the recommendations prepared in this connection by the Director of Technical Education in the Province of Manitoba, and submitted to your Department in my letter of the 16th ultimo.

The Acting Assistant Deputy & Secretary when acknowledging the receipt of these recommendations in his letter of March 22, #105-0-11, stated that no funds were available to provide a building at the Elkhorn School for educational training and classroom purposes, but requested an estimate of the cost of fitting up one of the present buildings for manual training purposes.

Immediately after receiving this request, I applied to the Principal of the Elkhorn School for an estimate of the cost of fitting up the building which was used, I believe, as a gymnasium by the School Management, before this institution passed under our Society's control. In his reply, dated the 9th inst., he states, in part, as follows:

"This building is a very old one, and originally was the Main Hall and Boys' Dormitory of the old School, when situated in the town of Elkhorn, some three quarters of a mile from the present site. It was then moved from the town, and placed where it now stands. Without hesitation, I firmly state that it would be an absolute waste of money to fix up this building for either class rooms or manual training purposes. The foundation..."
"has completely gone, the flooring is badly sunk in the middle, and the building is practically held together by rods running down from the ventilators. It would have to be removed from the present foundations, and absolutely reconditioned to give the lighting necessary for the work to be carried on there. Furthermore, the building is so old that the lumber in it is of the old style, and would not fit in with lumber used at the present time, such as "tongue and groove", the nails are also of the older style, which would greatly increase the difficulty in reconstructing the place."

The information contained in the above statement, appears to me to fully support the suggestion made by the Director of Technical Education in his recommendations that this building might be made to serve as an implement shed and storage warehouse, and that it would be, as the Principal states, a waste of money to attempt to fix it up for either classroom or manual training purposes. Even to fix it up as an implement shed, etc., would it seems to me, cost more than it would be worth. The Principal himself hesitates to name any amount which will be required for this purpose, but states that he does not believe that the work could be done for an expenditure of less than $576 or $6,000.00.

As our Commission and the School Management have felt keenly for some years, the need of additional classroom space at this School, and have included in their list of requirements submitted to your Department for the last three years, the sum of $15,000.00 each year for this purpose, it seems to me and to our Commission, who sat very carefully into this matter at their last meeting, that the only satisfactory way to provide the additional classroom space required, would be to erect a new building in close proximity to the main school building. As the School has no assembly room, and no chapel large enough to accommodate the staff and pupils, our Commission felt that the additional classroom space could be provided in such a way that it would serve as an assembly room and chapel as well. They also felt that when providing this classroom space, provision might be included in the plan for the development of vocational training. This would mean a two storied building, and they still consider that the classroom and vocational training facilities which this School requires cannot be supplied in any cheaper or more satisfactory way. They are of the opinion, and they instructed me to lay this recommendation before you, that if funds are not available this year to erect the two storied building, that a one storied building be erected at once and fitted up temporarily and used as classrooms until a further appropriation has been secured next year to complete the second storey.
As the main school building is only provided with two classrooms at present, and these are by no means sufficient for 120 pupils, you will understand how difficult it is for the School Management to carry on the classroom work with an enrolment of 164 pupils, such as they have at present.

Our Commission greatly hope that you may be able to give this matter your own personal attention and take steps immediately to provide the additional classroom space which is so urgently required.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th ultimo, 106-0-5, and my reply of the 24th April, I beg to inform you that I visited the Elkhorn School a couple of days ago and went thoroughly into the question of additional classroom space at that institution, and I am quite convinced that the present accommodation is quite adequate for the school requirements, and that the Department should not be called on to provide additional space.

With regard to the chapel, this is not needed. The chapel adjoins the dining room and the two rooms can be thrown into one, which answers the purpose quite well.

I note in your letter you state that the Department is anxious to commence a course in manual training at this school, and in this connection I may say that I have not found the manual training taught at our schools in the past to be of very great benefit to the pupils, and I am of the opinion that we would get much better results if this money were spent in giving them a proper equipment to farm with and teaching them how to handle it at the schools. In the past we have equipped hundreds of Indians with outfits of tools and fitted them up as carpenters and not one per cent of them are working at their trade on the reserve, and I do not know that the boy who has had manual training is any better fitted to go out on the farm and make a living than the fellow who has not.

The general training that a boy receives at the school fits him for handling machinery and doing any repair work that might have to be done around the farm, and I think our efforts should be along the lines of agriculture, and agriculture only. We found this out long ago. At one time at the Qu'Appelle School we had a carpenter shop, tin shop, shoe shop, and so on, and the boys received a thorough training in these lines of work, but this has all been done away with and I do not think we should start it up again. I am stressing this point, because I would hate to see any expenditure on this particular line of work, as I know we have not obtained results from it in the past.

The old building referred to in your letter of the 17th April can be put in shape and should be used as a manual training room and gymnasium. The upstairs could be used as a storeroom for the paints, tools, etc., that are necessary around an institution of this kind. It would take $1200.00 to put the building in shape and I am of the opinion that this should be done at once. It would be of great assistance to the Principal to have a place that the boys could use as a recreation room, and also a place to keep tools and do repair work in. The building is an old one, but with an expenditure of $1200.00 it could be made as good as new.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Re Elkhorn Indian School and Hydro -

Hon. D.G. McKenzie has forwarded me a copy of a letter from Hon. T.A. Crerar to whom he had written in connection with the above, and from whose letter it would appear that your Department has been waiting for further information from the Village of Elkhorn.

I regret that your letter of October 28th, last has remained unanswered but our Council were hoping to receive advice from Dr. Scott that the rates for current as quoted in our letter of Oct. 21st, were satisfactory.

As there appears to be some misunderstanding in connection with this service may I explain that the line from the Provincial Hydro station at Virden was built at the cost of the ratepayers of the Village of Elkhorn. That some half mile or more of line was extended through the School grounds to the buildings and all that is now necessary is for the school to hook on. There should be no costs as regards installation, the school being already wired. The current would be metered through Elkhorn Municipal meter and the amount used by the school read from their meters and charged to them monthly in like manner as other users of current at Elkhorn.

Our rates, as approved by the Commission, are - Light 20¢ per K.W. and Power 8¢ per K.W. The rates to the school, hereby submitted for your approval are:

First 3000 K.W. consumed, 20¢ per K.W., next 2000 K.W. consumed 16¢ per K.W., all in excess of 5000 K.W. 12¢ for Light.

For Power 8¢ per K.W. No discounts.

Trusting that this is the information that you require,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

12¢ per K.W.H. for the balance

Power -

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 24th, 1930, No. 106-0-5, with reference to connecting this School with the Provincial Hydro System.

I beg to report that the line was extended to the School buildings, but with reference to cost in connection with the installation, I beg to state first of all, there would be cost of the transformers, secondly, that of running extra wires for the purpose of using power, and thirdly, the advisability of having a thorough inspection of our outside wiring system.

I also have the honour to report, that when the Hydro was turned on, the Village of Elkhorn, the rate given by the Village of Elkhorn was somewhat excessive, and from a financial point of view it was impossible to take advantage of the light and power. However, I am in receipt of a letter dated May 1st, 1930, from the Village Council, and enclose copy herewith for your information. You will see by this that we have been offered a special rate, and I am now of the opinion, that we should take advantage of this, providing the Department would be willing to provide us with Motors to take the place of the various gas engines we now have in use. This would lessen the danger of fire, and the cost of many repairs for the various engines. We would approximately require the following:

1. Four or five H.P. Motor for Septic Tank Pump.
2. Six H.P. Motor for pumping water and laundry.
3. Two and half H.P. Motor for Bread Mixer.
4. Movable ten H.P. Motor for driving Farm Chopper, Ensilage Cutter, and Circular Saw.

I also wish to report the necessity of having continuous service, especially with reference to light in a School where there are so many children. It appears that the majority of light consumers in the Village of Elkhorn, are somewhat dissatisfied with the service as given by the Hydro, as many times the power has been turned off.
when most required. This of course would be most unsatisfactory and dangerous in a building such as this with so many children. Therefore, we shall be pleased if the Department would look into this matter before we link up with the Hydro, so that there may be a guarantee of continuous service.

Thanking you Sir, for your kindness, and interest in our welfare, and waiting instructions,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

(Rev. Fred Eley.)
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

P.S. Our present lighting plant was turned on during January 1924, and we have never once failed with light.

Dr. Scott,

With reference to a portable electric motor for the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, I have to report that department officials consider it would be a source of danger to the children that are running around the buildings at all hours of the day. Captain The Rev. Fred Eley-2. June 25, 1930.

It will be necessary in this last item to install six new poles complete with necessary anchors and guy wires. There will be approximately one thousand feet of #8 wire used in order to change the present system to a 3-wire system, and 260 feet of No. 1/0 wire to feed the main building.

The following is for new work that will be necessary to make the change for the new services:

The service as we understand it will enter the power house and from there will be connected through a double throw switch so that the present plant can be operated in case of emergency. In the power house will be the necessary fuses and distribution to take care of the other buildings.

The service will consist of a 200 ampere 3 pole service switch, service and feeder wires to be 3 - 3/0 wires in 2" conduit, this to be fed from the double throw switch which will be mounted behind present switchboard, and terminate on the outside of the wall nearest the school building. This will cost Three hundred and Sixty-one Dollars, ($361.00).

In addition to this it will be necessary to change the present feeder in the school building from a 2-wire to 3-wire system, and to change the present service switch from a 2-wire to a 3-wire. This will cost One Hundred and Seventy Dollars, ($170.00).

For wiring and connecting up one 5 HP septic tank motor; 1 - 7½ HP pump motor in the laundry; and one 2 HP motor in the bakery from the service point to the motor terminal, building concrete base for motors, erecting the necessary counter shafting, pulleys and bolts, all complete and in complete operation - Four Hundred and Eighty Dollars, ($480.00).

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. A. G. HAMILTON, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN AGENCIES, DATED DECEMBER 18TH, 1930, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE ELKHORN INDIAN RES. SCHOOL.

In all the dormitories the electric light switch is inside the dormitory and locked with a key. In cases of fire, this would be a poor arrangement as it takes too long to get the lights on. This switch should be in the hall on the opposite side of the wall, then it would not need to be locked and could be easily reached as the hall light is kept burning. The change should not incur any great expense.

Fire drill is observed and was carried out during my inspection. The drill was given after all the children had retired, and without any excitement they were able to get out in seven minutes.

The fire escape on the west wing of the building is only a ladder hanging against the wall and very unsuitable for children. The infirmary, as well as a small dormitory, is at this end of the building and a proper fire escape should be provided. The present ladder is not used for drill and the children are obliged to go the length of the building and into another dormitory in order to reach the fire escapes. Fire extinguishers are placed throughout the building in convenient places and all the fire hose appeared to be in good condition.

A small dressing room adjoining the infirmary should be provided with a radiator. Last year, the radiator froze and broke and, at present, the only heat obtainable is from the hall. This room is provided with running water and wash basin and, unless a radiator is provided, further trouble is likely to arise from freezing.

The stairs to the boys' washroom are badly worn and the treads should be renewed. The floors in the classrooms and staff rooms are badly in need of paint, as are also the front stairs and the wood work in the bathrooms. In many places, the paint is entirely gone, while in other places, small patches remain. The floors are scrubbed each week and were clean throughout the building.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF INDIAN COMMISSIONER GRAHAM, DATED JANUARY 6th, 1931, ENCLOSING ABOVE REPORT.

The Inspector comments on the fire escape on the west wing of the building, which is only a ladder hanging against the wall. This matter has been brought to your attention before. I do not think it is a satisfactory escape.

Mr. Hamilton mentions the need for a small radiator in the dressing room adjoining the infirmary. I think this will have to rest in abeyance for the present year. Some slight repairs to the flooring are required. I think this work should be done and it can be gone on with at any time provided the necessary authority is given. I am not in favor of painting the Principal's residence this year, owing to the financial conditions existing.
Ottawa, January 17, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his inspection of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School.

Relative to his recommendation that the electric light switches in the dormitories be changed from their present position on the wall inside the dormitories where they could be easily reached, I have to say that the suggestion of the Inspector should be carried out. You may, therefore, arrange to have the switches changed to the outside wall of the dormitories, where they could be easily reached by a member of the staff. If this were done, it is considered that it would not be necessary to keep the switches locked.

Relative to the providing of a fire escape of a satisfactory type on the outside west wall of the building, to replace the present hanging ladder, I shall be pleased if you will furnish your recommendation as to the type of escape you would recommend and the approximate cost of supplying and installing same.

Regarding the installing of a radiator in the dressing room adjoining the infirmary, and the renewing of the treads of the stairs to the boys' washroom, and the painting of the floors in the classrooms and staff rooms, also front stairs and woodwork in the bathrooms, I have to say that this work will have to stand over until a later date, as we have no funds at the present time to provide the expenditure required for the purpose.

It is noted that you are not in favour of painting the Principal's residence this year, and this work will also have to stand over.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector Hamilton's Report on the Elkhorn Residential School

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, inspected on November 9th and 10th, 1931.

The senior class room is in charge of Mr. Bradley, who also acts as assistant to the Principal. There are thirty-eight children on the roll and the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 3     | 7      |
| 4     | 20     |
| 5     | 6      |
| 6     | 4      |
| 7     | 1      |

The register was marked to date and the attendance regular. The children were well dressed, neat, and clean. The class room was well aired and tidy.

The children speak out clearly and are well mannered. They read with understanding and I found their book work well done and neatly set down. I would judge Mr. Bradley is rendering good service as a teacher.

The junior room is in charge of Miss Field. The roll calls for forty-five and the grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 29     |
| 2     | 10     |
| 3     | 6      |

These children make excellent response to Miss Field, and speak out well. They are well mannered, bright, and -

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
bright, and attentive.

The room was tidy. The children well clothed and clean.

The dormitories were clean, and well aired. The beds were all neatly made, and the bedding clean. The girls are provided with night gowns and the boys' pyjamas.

Miss Shaw is in charge of the laundry. This department is well equipped with machinery, and the work is well done. Miss Shaw, aside from the use of the power machinery, instructs the girls in the use of small washing machines and teaches them how to do properly a family size washing. When not in the laundry, Miss Shaw instructs the girls in the mending of their clothes and this requires the balance of her time. No sewing teacher is provided; consequently the children do not receive instruction in the making of new garments, at least not to any extent. This, I feel, is a great mistake, as every girl on leaving school should know how to make her own clothes and do the necessary sewing for children.

Miss Palmer is in charge of the bakery and dairy and renders good service. In this department more of the senior girls should be given a chance to become bread makers. A baking of the proper size for a family could perhaps be made each day by some girl. At present the work is carried on by one or two girls and very little of the individual instruction has been given.

Miss Howe is kitchen matron and I found the food well prepared and wholesome. The kitchen is large, bright and well equipped.

Miss Lindsay, the matron, appears to keep close supervision over the school, and the halls, dining room, and staff-rooms were all tidy and showed care and good housekeeping.
keeping.

The fire equipment is in splendid condition and the fire escape added last year has made a wonderful improvement. Fire drill was observed and the children were able to get out in less than three minutes. I might say the children had all retired and in some cases were asleep when the fire alarm was sounded. No member of the staff was aware that fire drill was to be observed. The doors leading from the dormitories to the fire escapes are all pad-locked. The engineer, who is a graduate of Toronto University in electrical engineering, offered to connect these doors with the fire alarm so that if opened the alarm would be sounded. This would do away with the locks and would entail very little expense.

The dormitory lights can only be put on from a switch in the dormitory and this switch is operated by a key. This is an awkward arrangement and the switches would be much handier if placed outside the dormitory door and the ordinary switch used. Again this work could be properly carried out by the engineer if proper switches and a small amount of wire were provided.

The food served on the day of my visit was as follows:

Breakfast: porridge, bread, lard and tea
Dinner: meat, dumplings, potatoes, gravy, bread, tea, and pudding
Supper: bread spread with peanut butter and tea.

At all meals the children appeared to receive plenty, but no waste is allowed.

- The yards -
The yards about the school were clean, and, I believe, are well looked after.

The garden yielded a fair return and the potato crop was excellent.

Poultry is kept, but this year, due to disease, the flock went back and the Principal informed me that he intended killing off the present birds. The premises will then be thoroughly cleaned and made ready for next year.

At present sixteen cows are being milked, but a number of the cows will soon be dry. Hay is scarce and they have no feed grain for the stock. The grain crop was cut for green feed, but yielded very light.

The horse barn was clean and all tools and harness neatly put away. Six horses are kept, and they were in fair condition.

I noticed one side of the barn roof is only partly stained. A few gallons of stain would complete the work and greatly add to the appearance of the buildings.

The children in this school receive a good training. They are obedient and respectful and progress is being made in the various departments. The Reverend Mr. Eley keeps in close touch with the work and is respected by the staff and pupils.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

REGINA, SASK., December 1st, 1931.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Inspector Hamilton's report on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, which he inspected during the month of November.

You will note that conditions at this school are good. The children are well fed, the classroom work is good, and everything about the institution is as it should be. The stock is well cared for, and the boys receive a good training in farm work. The girls at this school milk cows during certain periods of the year - chickens are also kept. In fact, the Department hear very little from this school, simply because we have a competent Principal in charge. All schools could be managed in the same way if we had the right type of man in charge.

There is one matter, however, which required attention. The Inspector found the doors leading from the dormitories to the fire escapes padlocked. This is absolutely wrong. If there were a fire and a panic occurred, there would probably be a great loss of life. I have instructed the Principal by telephone to have the locks removed at once.

With regard to the light switches, the change suggested should certainly be made. They should not be operated by a key. I have been talking to the Principal over the telephone, and he informs me that the switches have now been changed, at a cost of $12.00. He stated that he hopes the Department will re-imburse him for this.
