Dear Sir,

I have already received enquiries about the installation of the new boiler in this School and the visit of one expert prompts me to lay before you the opinion he expressed.

There are 97 radiators containing 6390 sq. feet of radiation. Mains and risers would add 20% to this making a heating load of 7668 sq. feet. Changing from water to steam would be reduction in number of these radiators and some change in those retained.

The expert in question, who by the way dubs the present boiler "a freak," was the engineer who scrapped the mate to it from the old Brandon School. He believes that a hot water boiler might be installed to burn Souris Coal and so avoid the expense of alteration to the radiators.

I do not know how far the Department has gone in the whole matter but the fact that Engineers are already asking for information suggests that we may in 1934 anticipate the much needed new heating system.

The above information and the fact that the boiler is a Gurney Offord Smoke Consuming No K 1867 W with a catalogue capacity of 12000 sq. feet, fire and water grates 15x14 may be of value to you.

Thanking you for your interest in our problems,

I am,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

For apartment houses and other large installations no other boiler will give such care free satisfaction as this New Bright Idea Boiler. It has all the well known advantages of cast iron construction plus rapid heating and the utmost fuel economy. It is built in seven sizes for either steam or hot water.

Note in this illustration the slender horizontal water heating surfaces and the generous vertical tubes for quick water circulation.

The large smoke hood and twin balanced check dampers are clearly shown. Also note the cleanout door for the secondary combustion chamber.

Water Tube Design

In the sectional view it will be noted that the slim water tubes present a large heating surface in comparison to the amount of water they contain. This design means quick response and economy in operation.

Three Crown Heating Surfaces

A distinctive feature of this boiler is that the double gallery flue design provides three separate and distinct crown heating surfaces—this is the most effective heating surface in any boiler. The fire travel is from the front to the back of the firebox, then to the front through the first flue level and to the back of the boiler through the upper gallery. The fire travel is the same in all sizes of this boiler.
Auxiliary Air
At a suitable point at the rear of the firebox auxiliary air is introduced ensuring complete combustion of any gases that pass out of the firebox, making the operation of the boiler practically smokeless. The amount of air is readily controlled by the ratchet doors at the side of the boiler.

Secondary Combustion Chamber
In the six larger sizes a bridgewall section is placed at the back of the firebox forming a secondary combustion chamber where the gases burn when mixed with the auxiliary air. (See table of arrangement of sections on the back cover of this catalogue.)

Large Cleanout Doors
Large cleanout doors at the front of the boiler make it simple to clean all the flues. In addition there is a cleanout door at the back of the base through which the secondary combustion chamber may be cleaned.

The Grates
The grate bars are so designed that even small sizes of coal may be used. They are easy to operate for either shaking or dumping. The entire grate assembly can be removed from the front of the boiler by first removing the front base panel.

Oil Burning
Due to the all cast iron construction and the long fire travel it is an excellent boiler for use with any oil burning equipment.

Easy to Erect
It will be found that this New Bright Idea Boiler is easy to erect due to accurate machining and a simplified method of pulling up the sections. And when installed its clean pleasing lines and generous proportions give this boiler a smart appearance. It looks, and is capable of doing a first class heating job.

VULCA BOILERS

The Vulca Fire Tube Steel Heating Boiler is a low priced heating boiler designed for efficient and economical operation. It is built up in a compact unit of all-steel construction electrically welded. Some of the outstanding features that have been built into this boiler are: Unrestricted circulation of water; Low water line; Large amount of direct heating surface; Long three pass fire travel and a combustion chamber large enough to burn our low grade Western coals.

Vulca Boilers have a manhole on the top of the boiler for sizes VS and over and a hand-hole in the front head for smaller sizes. The boiler is equipped with sufficient watertight plugs to properly inspect and clean the boiler. Soot doors are also placed where required so that the boiler may be given a thorough cleaning whenever it may be found necessary.

Vulca Boilers are built to comply with the Canadian Inter-Provincial Regulations for the construction and inspection of boilers. Although they are Government registered for 15 lbs. per square inch working pressure, they are designed for 30 lbs. per square inch working pressure and are tested in our shops to a pressure of 60 lbs. per square inch. Such rigid tests insure the customer against faulty construction.

Vulca Boilers are constructed of Flange Quality Plate 55,000-65,000 lbs. per square inch tensile strength. All castings, including grates, are of good quality grey iron and are of rugged construction.

Vulca Boilers are furnished with the following: Base, Grates, Safety Valve, Water Column piped to Boiler, Pressure Gauge, Gauge Cocks, Balanced Damper in Ash Pit Door with automatic regulator, Damper in rear Smoke Outlet, Firing Tools and Bridge Wall Fire Bricks.

Dear Sir:

As requested in your letter of January 30th, I have made an inspection of the boilers at the Elkhorn Indian School. Reports for same are attached.

The school is heated by a hot water system. The boiler is a Gurney cast section size 5 x 11 x 10 sections with top and lower fire grates. I was informed by the Superintendent of the School that they have been having a little trouble in heating the building. On several occasions during the winter the water pipes have been frozen. The present system is not very satisfactory and far from being economical. With the top and lower grates there is no room for burning all the gases before going up the chimney. I believe that if there was a good fire box type boiler installed say about 54 inches in diameter and 12 feet long with plenty fire box height that it would pay for itself in fuel in two years, and they would have no trouble in heating the school. On checking up the radiators I find there are ninety-seven and I believe there is some 6390 square feet of radiation. The present system has no circulating pumps and I believe that if there was two three inch circulating pumps installed it would make a considerable difference in heating the building with the system that they now have.

Personally I would strongly recommend that some change be made in the heating system before next winter comes around.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) E. Moodie
Inspector

WINNIPEG, MAN. November 29th, 1934.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to submit the following report in connection with the Elkhorn Indian Residential School which I inspected between November 13th and 16th, 1934.

The senior classroom is in charge of Mr. Crampton who, I understand, holds his Grade 12 certificate. He is greatly interested in the work and the children are making steady progress. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| IV    | 20     |
| V     | 17     |
| VI    | 14     |
| VII   | 8      |

I consider the pupils well along in their various grades. Their articulation is much improved and they read with understanding. They write well and are fairly accurate in arithmetic and spelling. The work in English and composition is much improved.

The junior room is in charge of Miss Fryer who holds her Manitoba certificate. There are 88 on the roll, arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 48     |
| II    | 18     |
| III   | 22     |

Miss Fryer is quite young but a born teacher and is doing excellent work. The children are alert and, through good management, always kept busy. The lessons are made attractive and interesting.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The number enrolled will, of course, only permit of the half day system. The Reverend Principal would like most of the children in class all day as many are too young to work and there is really little for them to do. Now that the enrolment has reached almost 150, an outside classroom should be provided. I understand this has been asked for by the church authorities and, with the present large enrolment, is much needed.

Since last spring a large amount of interior painting has been done, which work has improved the building and added greatly to its brightness. The girls' dormitory was being painted at the time of my visit. The work was being done by one of the staff and two boys.

I visited the various departments and found a competent person in charge. The girls receive a good training in cooking, butter making, sewing, and general housekeeping. The boys are taught all general farm work and gardening.

Fire drill was held at 6 A.M. and the children and staff were out of the building in five minutes. The staff were not aware that the alarm would be given. I also tested the fire hose and checked the various fire extinguishers. All were filled and in good condition. Under separate cover, I reported that one fire alarm bell did not ring and asked for authority to have same repaired.

This school is of frame construction and every precaution should be taken against fire. The water pressure could be improved by changing the system and pumping direct
pumping direct to the main water pipe which feeds the fire hose. This would give a better flow of water and would not be effected should a break occur in the plumbing throughout the building. To change this would entail a small expense of perhaps thirty to forty dollars as several feet of 1½" pipe and two valves would be required. The engineer claims he can do the necessary work.

In view of the enrolment and the frame construction of the building, I feel a night watchman should be provided and a punch clock installed with at least eight stations. No doubt a reliable man could be obtained from the town of Elkhorn for $25. or $30. per month. His services would perhaps not be needed for more than six months and would be the best protection we could give against fire hazard. The Rev. Canon Wickens would appreciate this added safeguard, but pointed out that the school was not in a financial position to pay the extra salary. I would be glad if the Department could see fit to incur the added expense.

The farm crop was practically nil and already feed is being purchased for the stock. The garden was also a failure, as well as the potato crop. These extra demands on the grant have been a heavy drain and made financing very difficult.

The cows are in fair condition, but at present most of them are dry. There are twenty-five head, some of which will soon freshen.

The horses are thin, but receiving good care.

The school
The school is badly in need of two wagons. There is at present one wagon belonging to the school and that is only in fair condition. It is necessary to continually borrow, which is unsatisfactory at an institution of this kind. A lot of teaming is done in connection with the hauling of coal and feed and extra equipment should be provided.

The children appear well fed and attached is the menu followed during the week of my visit. The menu is quite varied and I believe carefully followed. The children, I understand, receive all the bread they desire and the supervisor in charge of the bakery stated she baked an average of 150 loaves per day. The Matron, Nurse Morrice, prepares the menu and sees that same is followed.

The dormitories were clean and well aired. The toilets were all in good repair, the bedding clean, and the beds neatly made. One dormitory could be greatly improved by cutting two or three more windows on the one side. This would allow for more light and better ventilation. The dormitory is on the third floor and the wall is frame, sheeted outside with tin.

The Rev. Canon Wickens was new to the Indian work when he took charge of the Elkhorn School. He is greatly interested and desirous of making his school rank among the best.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 17th inst. respecting the fire alarm bells of this School, I beg to recommend that the advice of the expert be adopted.

The present situation finds us just as we were last year. The hall bell does not ring and the experiment of deadening the bakery bell to release power for the hall bell did not prove to be satisfactory.

I believe that we should change the present transformer to the 100 watt size and get the Virden expert to make the necessary resistor.

It looks as if the total price should not be more than $15.00 and if our own engineer can install there should be no other costs. Our engineer, I might say is a very capable man, and I have confidence in his ability to handle the job.

I am,

Yours truly,

Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 106-0-14 dated July 25th, I wish to refer to the amount of $500 allowed for painting and general repairs.

I discussed this matter with Canon Wickens, Principal of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School and, as a result, purchased the two wagons and boxes, at a cost of $259.70. This leaves a balance of $240.30.

The jacket heater has been leaking badly for some weeks and the fire pot should be renewed. Canon Wickens states the heater was purchased from the Peace Western Foundry, of Winnipeg, and that the cost of the necessary repair will be approximately $75.00. This further reduces our amount to approximately $165.30.

The machine shed doors should be re-hung, and the track and hangers necessary will cost approximately $65.00.

The balance of the $500 should be used in the purchase of paint, most of which will be used on the outside buildings. When the barns were painted some years ago, there was apparently a shortage of shingle stain and the roof of the main barn was never completed. A quantity of red paint is also needed for the walls.

If these expenditures meet with the Department's approval, I would like to have authority by wire in order that the work may be carried out at once, especially in connection with the jacket heater.

Sir:

The Department is informed that there is surplus to requirements in the powerhouse at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, a 25 h.p. Fairbanks-Morse "Y" horizontal engine. The Anglican School at Onion Lake, Sask., is in need of a new engine to operate the lighting plant, and it has occurred to the Department that the engine at Elkhorn would be satisfactory for the purpose. I would request that, at your early convenience, you will have the engine referred to, at the Elkhorn School, examined, and, if you consider it is in fair condition, you might have any necessary repairs made and arrange to ship the engine, addressed to Rev. Henry Ellis, Lloydminster, Sask.

Any expense, in connection with overhauling and placing the engine in good condition, and also the transportation charges will be paid, upon receipt of vouchers, in triplicate, properly certified.

Mr. Inspector Murison, who visited the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School, has drawn the Department's attention to the need of a new engine, and he is being informed of the engine that is surplus to requirements at Elkhorn. I would request that, after examination of the engine at Elkhorn, if you consider it satisfactory, that you will inform Mr. Murison. The Department will leave the matter in your hands, in the hope that it will be possible to utilize the engine at Elkhorn at the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I wish to refer to Department Letter 106-0-5 dated November 5th, and to say that I visited the Elkhorn Indian Residential School in company with Mr. Moore from the Manitoba Power Commission Station at Virden. Mr. Moore checked over the engine and stated that it needed a thorough overhauling and new piston rings. He recommended that, if possible, I secure the services of Mr. Jim Read, of Virden. He stated Mr. Read thoroughly understood that particular type of engine and was a reliable man.

I interviewed Mr. Read on my return to Virden and he agreed to do the work. Mr. Read requested 50¢ per hour for his own time and 25¢ per hour for his helper. The repair work will perhaps require two or three days and it will take about the same length of time to load the engine. This is a very heavy engine and a lot of work is required in removing it from its present location. The generator will need to be moved, as well as a large cement slab on which it rests. The door casings and also a portion of the wall will have to be taken out. It will be necessary to procure proper skids and securely fasten the engine to them.

The Rev. Canon Wickens will more or less supervise the work and I have the assurance of all that the expense will be kept as low as possible. I have already ordered the piston rings, which will be in Elkhorn today, and, if all goes well, the engine should be loaded by the end of the week.

When the work is completed, the vouchers will be forwarded immediately.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Since the McKay Indian Residential School was burned down, the pupilage at the Elkhorn School has increased. The junior classroom is greatly overcrowded and Canon Wickens states it is practically impossible to carry on the work with the two classrooms now in use. He states in a letter that the Church of England Commission is ready to send a third teacher as soon as a classroom can be made ready.

The old power house is well located. It is of brick construction and Canon Wickens estimates that it will cost approximately $345.00 to equip and remodel the building to make a suitable classroom. Of the $345. estimated, $100. of this is for remodelling and decorating the room. The balance is to provide the necessary equipment, including desks.

This additional classroom is certainly needed and I know of no cheaper way of providing the necessary space. I would like to be advised if funds are available to carry out the suggested alterations.

I have received your letter of the 10th instant and deeply regret that the Department has no funds available during the present fiscal year to provide the extra class-room at our Alkorn School.

In view of the urgency of this need, which is, I believe, very well known to you, I have been authorized to say that our Commission will advance the money required to fix up the power house for class-room purposes, from January 1st next, if the Department will undertake to refund the amount thus spent, as soon as their appropriation for the fiscal year 1936-37 is available. Sir:

I wish to refer to Department Letter No. 106-0-5 dated December 5th, and now enclose herewith copy of a letter received from Dr. Westgate.

There is no doubt that the classroom work at the Elkhorn School is made very difficult, due to overcrowding. The Church authorities are apparently willing to finance the necessary improvements, providing they have definite assurance that they will be re-imburied during the coming fiscal year.

The estimate of $345.00, as submitted by the Rev. S. J. Wickens, is, I consider, low. I am quite sure the cost will be in the neighbourhood of at least $450.

I do not know if the Department are prepared to assume this responsibility, but would like to be advised in order that I may reply to Dr. Westgate's letter.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, December 17, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I have your 209-11A C.E. of the 11th instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from Rev. Dr. Westgate, Field Secretary, M. S. C. C., requesting that an additional classroom be fitted up in the old powerhouse at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School and giving an estimate of the cost of the repairs required and the furnishings.

In this connection I would say the Department finds that it will be possible to provide funds, to an amount not exceeding $460, in remodelling and equipping the building for classroom purposes. I have therefore to request that you will arrange for the purchase, from the proper source of supply, of any materials required and for any labour other than that which can be carried out by the staff of the school.

You should have the Principal prepare a list, stating the desks that will be required and the size and the number of each size. It would be advisable to arrange the desks in rows of the same size desk and request that a front and rear seat be supplied. Purchase of the equipment will be arranged from here. The length and width of the blackboard required and any classroom material should also be given.

After the work in remodelling and placing the classroom in readiness for the furnishings is completed, you should forward itemized accounts in triplicate properly certified, covering the cost. These accounts should reach the Department not later than the end of March, next, in order that payment can be made from our Appropriation for the present fiscal year.

In fitting up this additional classroom, it is distinctly understood that the church authorities will arrange for a qualified teacher and for payment of salary. The entire expense in the fitting up and furnishing of the classroom is not to exceed the sum of $460.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir—

I wish to refer to Department Letter No. 106-0-5 dated December 17th, 1935, and to advise the Department that on January 11th, I visited the Elkhorn Indian Residential School and arranged with the Principal, the Rev. Canon Wickens, to have the necessary work done in connection with the classroom.

On January 31st, I received a letter from Canon Wickens, enclosing a list of equipment required. He stated that, owing to the severe cold weather, they had not been able to do any work in connection with the classroom. It was necessary to remodel the door of this building and transfer the electrical fixtures to another building. This called for considerable outside work, which it was impossible to do when the thermometer registered from 20 to 40 below zero.

In his last letter, Canon Wickens was of the opinion that the expense could be kept within the amount suggested and requested that the list be forwarded. I have just had a phone call today from Canon Wickens, and as the weather has now become milder, he expected to have the work completed within the next eight or ten days.

Sir:

I have received a letter from the Rev. Canon Wickens, in which he states that the runway for the water of the septic tank at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School is badly perished and most of the liquid is deposited between the new classroom and the waste ground. He states he has had the trough patched at various times with some old eavetroughing, but the whole frame work should be re-built.

I was at the school last week and agree with Canon Wickens that this work should be carried out and, indeed, as soon as possible. In his letter, he suggests using open galvanized troughing. However, in discussing this with Mr. Yates, of Brandon, he is of the opinion that the liquid may have some acid effect and the trough would probably rust through quickly. I would recommend that we continue to use the wood. The runway is 320 ft. in length and even the posts will need to be renewed. The cost for the material and labour will be approximately $125.

I would appreciate having the necessary instructions in order that the work may be carried out at once.

Ottawa, May 23, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 209-11A C.E. of the 19th instant, regarding the repairs required to the runway for the water of the septic tank at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School and giving an estimate of the cost.

The Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $125.00 for material and labour in repairing the runway, using a wood trough. You may arrange for the purchase of the material and labour and have the septic tank placed in a satisfactory condition. The Department agrees with you that galvanized troughing would rust through in a short time and that wood troughing would be more serviceable and lasting.

After the work has been completed, please forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the material and for the labour that it is necessary to employ, over and above what the school staff can perform. EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR A. G. HAMILTON DATED DECEMBER 8, 1937, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE ELKHORN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The fire escapes are all in good condition and extinguishers are placed in convenient places throughout the building. The doors leading to the escapes were locked and there was considerable delay in securing a key to fit. The Principal is much concerned and wishes this changed. He is willing to have the engineer install a bell system, but requests the Department to provide the material. I would recommend that this request be granted. The material will cost approximately $50.

The building throughout was clean, and I consider the school well managed. The staff sitting room should be refurnished. The rug is worn out and unfit for further use and the chairs will hardly hold together; in fact, the chair which looks most inviting should be discarded as the springs rest on the floor. A chesterfield, six chairs, and a rug are needed. The staff spend their spare time in the sitting room, which is as it should be. It creates a good spirit and tends to prevent the forming of groups. I would recommend that authority be granted to make the necessary purchases, at an approximate cost of $150.

Dear Sir:

I was in Elkhorn last week and, while there, examined the pump in connection with the Indian Residential School.

The pump was made by the Economy Pumping Machinery Co., Chicago, and is called "Economy". It is a triple plunger type and I am unable to get any information here with regard to repairs. The pump has been in use many years and the repairs required, I am told, will cost at least $100.00. The crank shaft should be removed and sent in to be machined and this will involve added expense. This pump weighs from 1,000 to 1,200 lbs. and undoubtedly is out of date, which fact makes it more expensive to keep in repair.

Fairbanks-Morse state a new pump will cost very little more and they quote on 1 - 2500 gal. per hour Fairbanks-Morse self-oiling Typhoon Pump with 16" pulley for flat belt drive, suction tapped for 2½" pipe - discharge for 2" pipe; speed of pump 215 RPM - weight 306 lbs. Price F.O.B. Winnipeg $174.00 less 15% = $147.90.

The vertical shaft in the septic tank will break any day and should be renewed. This will cost approximately $15.00.

An immediate reply in connection with these matters will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton

Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

I received a letter from Mr. Minchin, principal of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School, in which he reports that one of the large compression tanks started to leak badly and consequently had to be shut off. One of the seams running lengthwise along the tank is also opened and there is evidence of considerable rusting. Although the second tank is now in use, it also shows signs of rusting and it is doubtful how long it will last. The tanks are approximately 4 ft. x 16 ft.

It is, of course, difficult to know how badly these tanks are pitted and I would suggest that Mr. Yates of Brandon be sent to investigate and submit a report. It may be possible to repair the tank but on the other hand, the only solution may be a new one. The situation should receive immediate attention and I think expert advice should be obtained.

I would be glad to know the Department's wishes in the matter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Acting on your letter of Feb 15/38, I proceeded to Elkhorn Residential School, to inspect the Pressure Tank, and beg to report as follows:

There are two 48" x 16 foot Pressure Tanks installed with 5/16 shell, 3/8 heads, longitudinal seams double riveted, Heads single riveted with 72 rivets in each Head. No Manholes.

Just when these Tanks were installed, I was not able to ascertain, but it can be assumed they were put in about 1915.

They have not been kept painted, because it would be impossible to get under them, due to the position in which they are placed, and Tanks used for this purpose usually sweat badly, but damage caused by rust, and age, do not show to any great extent on the outside.

The trouble here is a concave head, reversed to a convex, by excess pressure, and a leak along one longitudinal seam.

The Head was reversed about Feb 3rd, in the afternoon, while the Pump was running. When this happened it ruptured the caulking, and badly strained the rivets on that end, causing it to leak.

I inspected the Safety Valve and found it stuck tight, and altogether too small for the size of the Pump, so even if it had been working it would not be large enough. In any case it is not the proper type for this kind of work.

A new Pump was installed about Jan 1st this year, and is connected up properly as far as the piping is concerned.

It is a Fairbanks twin cylinder Pump of 2500 gall capacity per hour, 2½" suction and 2" discharge.

This Pump is provided only with a tight Pully, this means that the Pump is running any time the Laundry is
operating unless the belt is off. Had this Pump been provided with a tight and loose Pully, it would not have to have the belt thrown off. This of course can be explained by the fact that it was originally run by a Gasoline Engine, which was discontinued in favor of Electric current supplied by the Manitoba Power Commission. The whole plant now being run by a 5 H.P Electric Motor.

When the Pump only is operating, this Motor is large for the Pump, but provides the power necessary to produce excess pressure without warming up the Motor. Pressure has been noted up to 100 lbs, but must have been over that to reverse the Head.

Only one pressure Gauge is installed, and it has not been tested in three years. There really should be two Gauges where so much depends on it.

You could, perhaps, carry on here till Summer with one Tank, but the Fire protection is decreased just that much, and pumping has to be done twice as often.

They are operating now on a single Tank, but the Pump must be watched carefully. Had this Pump been supplied with a separate Motor and Automatic Control, the trouble would not have happened, even now you could carry on indefinitely with the one Tank if this new Pump had been supplied that way.

The Tank can be repaired by Electric Welding, the caulking, and also any rivets that may be sprung, also the side seam, at a cost of;-

ONE HUNDRED & FIFTEEN DOLLARS..........................$115.00

It would be necessary to send heavy welding equipment from Brandon. The Tank would have to be disconnected, raised, and moved ahead, over the Pump, in order to get room to work at it.

This could possibly be done for less if the roads were open so that a truck could be used.

If this Tank is repaired, pressure would have to be reduced to 75 lbs to conform to Provincial regulations respecting Air Tanks, but this pressure would be adequate for the Schools requirements.

A new Tank installed with Manhole would cost;-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6262, file 578-5, part 8)
FIVE HUNDRED & FORTY EIGHT DOLLARS & FIFTY CENTS....$548.50

To put in a new Head would cost approximately:

ONE HUNDRED & NINETY FIVE DOLLARS..................$195.00

Would also recommend that a Mueller Diaphragm 2" Relief Valve could be installed at a cost of;.................................$48.00

Or an 1½" Relief Valve for..............................$30.00

And an extra Gauge (Pressure) be supplied at a cost of $8.00.

Automatic Pressure Control on the present Motor, Control (5. H.P.) could be installed for..........................$45.00

Yours very truly,

Yates, Neale & Co.

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter 106-0-5 dated February 11th, and enclose herewith letter from Mr. Yates, dealing with the pressure tank at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School.

The Department will note that Mr. Yates states the trouble is 'there is a concave head reversed to convex, by excess pressure, and a leak along one longitudinal seam'. It is also pointed out that the safety valve was found to be stuck tight and altogether too small for the size of the pump.

Mr. Yates gives several options and, taking the lowest, it will cost approximately $200.00 to repair the pressure tank and fit it with a relief valve, pressure gauge and pressure control.

I would appreciate your returning Mr. Yates' letter together with your instructions as I have forwarded the original, in order to avoid any delay.

Voucher will be forwarded to the Department concerning expense and charges made by Mr. Yates in connection with this investigation.

I would be pleased to be advised of the Department's wish in connection with the above tank.

Dear Sir,

I have just received a letter from Mr. Minchin, principal of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School in which he again points out the necessity for a bath tub in connection with the infirmary. He states a 5ft.6in. tub is required and that if the connections and tub are supplied, the school engineer will install the bath.

There is also a further need for thirty-five mattresses (6 ft. length). This school has been short of mattresses for some years and at times have been obliged to substitute straw filled ticks. There is also a shortage of beds, and if a child is sick, it is necessary to bring both the child and the bed to the infirmary. Mr. Minchin requests that he be supplied with a half dozen institutional beds, size 36 x 72.

These requests are all quite reasonable and supplies mentioned are badly needed.

I would recommend, if funds are available, that the purchase be made. I would be pleased to know what action the Department takes in this matter.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Thank you for your letter of the 11th instant re suggestion of a swimming pool. We are planning for a pool 50 ft. long and 25 ft. wide. The depth to graduate from 5 ft. in the deep end to 2 ft. in the shallow. The location to be behind the south wing of the main building and parallel to the dining hall. It will thus be enclosed on these two sides, and leave a space of about 22 ft. between the south wing and the end of the pool and about ten ft. between the side of the pool and the building running east and west.

Many of our children come from reserves situated on the banks of a river or the shores of a lake where they can swim during the summer months. Here there is no suitable swimming place within reach; and as so many of our children cannot get home for the holidays, I feel that they should have some safe place where they can swim.

I do hope the Department will sanction this pool and that they will make us a grant towards the cost of material.

Yours very sincerely,

Arthur E. Minchin (signed)

Ottawa,
April 24, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant enclosing copy of letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Elkhorn Indian residential school with reference to his idea of building a swimming pool.

It is considered that a pool of the kind suggested by the Principal would be a constant source of worry. In addition it is extremely doubtful if such a pool should be built owing to the probability that it would be difficult to prevent contamination. Besides, if the water were changed at frequent intervals a very large volume of water would be used. Taking everything into consideration the Department feels that it would be undesirable for the Principal of the Elkhorn school to construct a swimming pool.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Just what condition the rest of the other fourteen water grates were in was not ascertained, but they must be partly filled up and all should be replaced if this boiler is continued in use. We cannot conscientiously recommend the repairing for use of this boiler as it is entirely inadequate for this job and even if in good condition would not do the work required of it economically.

A stoker of a size to suit the requirements of the building, not sized according to the size of the boiler, would add about 20% to the power of the boiler and during most of the year would enable the use of cheaper coal.

If it is your desire to repair this boiler and add a stoker, you could add about 20% to the efficiency of the boiler and would make a saving in fuel and make more heat for the building. We would strongly recommend installing a new steel locomotive return flue type of boiler with 600 square feet of heating surface. This installation would result in a saving of at least 50% in the cost of fuel used to heat the building. This boiler to be provided with special openings to take the present mains. The most of the heating surface in these boilers is above the fire and is contained in the flue surface. With this type of boiler there is 54 inches of combustion space above the grates. This provides space for complete combustion of the coal before leaving the fire box.

The locomotive return flue type we recommend as being a better boiler because where this boiler has 54 inches of space above the grates, the Simplex Type has but 34 inches and cast iron boilers built for Pennsylvania hard coal have but 24 to 28 inches.

Any hot water system can be improved, both in efficiency of operation and consumption of coal by the addition of mechanical circulation, that is, installing in the return line an electrical driven propeller type of circulating pump. This applies both to the present boiler installation and also to any new boiler installation.

We have found that it is as important to keep the cold out as it is to supply heat to the building, and in our survey of this building we find that there is considerable heat loss due to the construction of the mansard roof - this should be insulated. We also noted that on the first two floors all ventilators are open from the ceiling only, this of course should be from the floor in order to reduce heat loss.

We estimate that the repairs required on the present boiler would cost - $350.00. Make up of $200.00 (Material) and $150.00 (Labour).

A guaranteed stoker for this heating system to burn Lignite or any coal would cost - $1,300.00.

To install complete a 54" x 11-7 Steel Locomotive Return Flue Hot Water Boiler fitted with special openings to suit present piping, the cost would be - $2,125.00. Built to steam specification, less trimmings.

On this particular system, two 3" Circulating Pumps would be installed with By Passes and all Electric Wiring complete, for the sum of $450.00.

WINNIPEG, August 14, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School,
Electoral District of Brandon.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 1st asking that an inspection be made of the heating system at the above mentioned school and a report submitted as to the condition of the same and giving an estimate of the cost of the work which should be done to overcome the present unsatisfactory heating situation.

As it was realized that only a specialist on heating could adequately outline the present heating situation at the school and advise as to what was necessary, we arranged with Mr. Yates of Yates, Neale and Company, Brandon, to accompany an engineer from this office on the inspection trip. The services of Mr. Yates were voluntary and gratis to the Government.

I am enclosing a memorandum from Mr. Rose of this office, who accompanied Mr. Yates to the site, and I am also enclosing a report by Mr. Yates regarding the heating situation at the school. You will observe that Mr. Yates estimates that it will cost $350.00 to repair the present boiler. This repair job would enable the institution to carry on for a few years under the unsatisfactory heating that they have experienced.

Mr. Yates also estimates that a guaranteed stoker to be used in conjunction with the repaired boiler would add $1,300.00 to the cost of the work and would enable the school to utilize a much cheaper grade of coal, namely, Souris Lignite, and the result would be a considerable saving on the fuel bill.

Both Mr. Rose and Mr. Yates and the District Boiler Inspector consider that the present boiler should be replaced by a unit more suitable for the heating of this institution. The particular boiler recommended by Mr. Yates would cost $2,125.00 and he recommends that more satisfactory results could be obtained with this new unit if circulating pumps were installed at an additional cost of $450.00. Should it be considered advisable to proceed with the installation of the new boiler with circulating pumps, it would also be very advisable to install either a mechanical stoker or a blower system. If I can remember correctly, a stoker is not provided at the Brandon Indian School but a blower was installed at small cost and added greatly to the efficiency of the heating system at Brandon.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
You say in your letter that expensive repairs are required to the heating system at the above school and that an amount of $1,500.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation of the Indian Affairs Branch for that purpose. You will, of course, realize that the Indian Affairs Branch were fully aware of the condition at this institution and must have also realized that an amount of $1,500.00 would be entirely inadequate to place the heating system in a satisfactory condition. I think it would be advisable to refer the situation back to the Indian Affairs Branch to determine as to whether or not an additional advance could be obtained so as to provide this school with an adequate heating system. A new boiler with circulating pumps would cost in the vicinity of $2,500.00. Whether or not a mechanical stoker would be necessary, the writer is not prepared at present to say but if a stoker is not installed it would be necessary to have installed a blower so that low grades of Souris Lignite Coal could be utilized.

It is my intention to make inquiries with respect to the operation of the heating system at Brandon School and also to make inquiries of individuals familiar with heating equipment, and at a later date will advise as to the necessity of the installation of a mechanical stoker. I hope to have this additional information available in about a week's time, but in the meantime I would appreciate learning whether or not the Indian Affairs Branch can find the necessary funds to install a new heating unit.

Should the Indian Affairs Branch not be able to raise the necessary additional funds, you have the recommendation of Messrs. Yates and Neale, that the present boiler be repaired and a mechanical stoker installed. This could probably be done at a cost somewhat higher than the money which is said to be available. It might be pointed out, however, that this outlay would not provide an adequate heating system for this school and would probably enable them to carry on for a few years under the present existing unsatisfactory heating situation.

Yours truly,

(sgd) D.B. Gow

D.B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer.

Encs.
MEMORANDUM:

MR. GOW:

Re: Elkhorn Indian Residential School - Heating System.

On August 9th the writer, accompanied by Mr. J.E. Yates, Heating Specialist of the firm of Yates, Neale & Company of Brandon, visited the Elkhorn Indian Residential School for the purpose of obtaining information for a report on the heating system.

The school is a three-storey T-shaped structure with the facade or top of T facing southeast. The basement has masonry walls and its floor is only about two feet below ground level. Most of the three-storey superstructure is faced with a veneer of brick except for the third storey. On the sides of the main section of the mansard roofed third storey, the exterior is shingled. The plan shows the area to be 7,027 square feet. The walls show no sign of cracking and except for some looseness of mortar in the foundation, the walls are in good condition. However, the building is exposed to the sweep of winds of the prairie, only partly broken by low tree growths to the northwest. The heating plant is located in the southeast corner of the building.

It was found that radiation and piping of the hot water system was adequate for this type of heating but the present type of boiler was considered unsuitable and not adapted for economical burning of Western coals. The boiler was also in need of repair. The cold weather heating was reported by the Resident Engineer as very difficult in windy weather, when the boiler had to be forced and even then comfortable conditions could not be maintained in the most exposed sections of the building. The engineer reported as much as ten carloads or about $5,800.00 worth of Drumheller coal had been used in a season. Mr. Yates considered this most excessive.

Two main alternatives were considered. Firstly, the boiler could be repaired and a stoker installed to provide for use of cheaper coal and better combustion. Secondly, a new boiler of greater capacity and better efficiency was considered. In addition to these alternatives, Mr. Yates recommends adding circulatory pumps which would provide for better control of distribution of heat and secure better economy. Furthermore, insulation, particularly in the top storey and slight remodelling of the ventilation system, would greatly assist in securing economy.

Mr. Yates estimated the cost as follows:

(1) Repair to present boiler ........... 350.00
Stoker Installation .................. 1300.00 $1,650.00

(2) Install Steel Locomotive Boiler... $2,128.00

D.B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water & Power Bureau,
538 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
(1A) or (11A) Install two circulating pumps .......... $450.00.

The proposal to install circulatory pumps is in line with best practice and economy of operation of the hot water system. While this feature is not essential in this plant, it provides for better control of the hot water flow which is reported as needed in greater volume on the windward side of the building during stormy weather.

The district boiler inspector was consulted and from him it was learned that the present boiler installation was markedly inadequate and on account of its condition he would consider replacement advisable.

The estimate of such economy in fuel as expected should result in a saving in two or three years which would be equivalent to the cost of the new boiler and this is sufficient to warrant the recommendation for its installation. For this reason, besides the additional long life capacity for heating provided for, the installation of the new boiler is recommended by the writer.

(sgd) J.T. Rose

Water & Power Engineer, Grade II.
August 10, 1939.

Mr. D.B. Gow,
District Chief Engineer,
588 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir: Re: - Heating Elkhorn Indian Boarding School.

We have gone carefully over the heating of this school and beg to report the following.

Radiation.

The Radiation consists of 4 column radiators with some box coils and ceiling radiation in basement of a pattern used generally about thirty years ago. This radiation is of sufficient amount and apparently in good condition. There is installed a total of ninety-seven (97) radiators containing 6,890 square feet of direct radiation.

We estimate that the mains would contain about 1,800 square feet of radiation which is partly covered - some of this covering may have to be removed to help heat the basement. We would estimate the complete heating load at 9,000 feet (Hot Water) or a steam load of 5,000.

Piping.

The piping is a good job and shows no sign of deterioration.

Boiler.

This boiler is a cast iron sectional, with headers on top and sides, connected with 2" nipples to each section. All sections except front and back are split in the middle. Made by the Gurney Foundry Company of Toronto - No. 1287-W. Installed we think about twenty to twenty-two years ago and the manufacture of this type discontinued immediately after.

The rating of this boiler is catalogued at 12,000 feet, but in our opinion should not be rated at more than 6,000 feet, because the heating surface is not available. In proof of this, the Engineer informed us that he is unable to raise the temperature above 120 degrees, even when using Drumheller Coal. He also informed us that they use ten cars of this coal during the season, which means 350 tons of coal.

The fact of the matter is that this boiler is not burning the coal but roasting it and sending the gasses to the chimney unburned.

Another factor is the condition of the boiler. The cast iron base is partly eaten through and weakened by the action of smoke condensation, due to the low operating temperature of the diving flues in the rear end of the boiler.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Attached herewith, for your information, are copies of reports covering the present heating system at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School in the Brandon district.

You will note that while the existing boiler could be repaired to function, at an estimated cost of $350, our Chief Engineer does not consider its age and general condition warrants this expenditure.

Dear Sir:

I have just returned from the Elkhorn School and would like to say that the work on the furnace is well under way and will be completed in a few days. In view of the large amount of water to be heated and the distance this must be forced, Mr. Yates is still of the opinion that circulating pumps may be required.

The school has 157 pupils enrolled—every bed is filled. There are no beds in the infirmary and if a child is sick it must be moved with its bed to the infirmary. Six complete hospital beds should be provided. The Department is aware that Dr. Johnson submits no bills for his work and therefore receives no pay. I would, however, point out he is most kind and considerate to the children. If necessary he takes them to the Virden hospital, operates and brings them back as soon as they can be moved. Some of the operations are for bone conditions—yet no bill is submitted. I think we should at least equip the school infirmary with proper beds and tables.

The school is well operated. The sewing room work has greatly increased and the girls are receiving splendid training. One new sewing machine is needed. If funds are available I hope this will be purchased at once.

The children appeared in good health and were settling down to the regular school work. The three teachers, I understand, are all qualified for the work.

The other departments, both inside and out, are well operated and the children appeared interested in their work and happy.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Elkhorn Indian residential school.

With reference to your memorandum of the 14th ultimo, the following specification has been supplied by our Engineers for a motor to drive a pump at the above school:

1 - 3 H.P. 3 phase, 60 cycle 220 volt motor complete with pulley, starter, and base arranged for tightening belt.

The motor will drive a 2,500 gallon per hour Fairbanks Morse Self-oiling Typhoon Pump and its speed shall be such that the pump will be driven at 215 R.P.M. This was formerly accomplished by an 1,800 R.P.M. motor with a pulley 3 inches in diameter and a 6 inch face.

Tenders shall state the speed and make of the motor offered.

Dear Sir:

On Monday last June 10, I reported to Inspector Hamilton that our jacket heater upon which we depend for our hot water supply has been leaking for some time and gradually getting worse. We have disconnected the jacket twice in order that the leak might if possible be repaired by welding but without effect. It is now quite impossible to use the heater. Inspector Hamilton has instructed me to write to you direct explaining the circumstances and requesting the Department to authorize replacement of the jacket. If the same type of jacket heater can be secured it would only be necessary to replace the jacket itself as the base is still in good condition.

The present heater is described as follows -

Ideal Junior, No. 09. Series 18-2-C made by Dominion Radiator and Boiler Company Ltd., Brantford, Ontario

Inspector Hamilton asked me to send a clipping showing the design, which I am enclosing herewith. He also told me to explain that we are in the meantime without hot water for all domestic purposes.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Re: Elkhorn School Boiler.

We got in touch with the Gurney Foundry Co. and today we received the enclosed letter, which tells us that they cannot supply a new Section.

The present section is cracked, but it has been cracked for some time.

It is possible to close up a crack of this kind by using a compound called X Liquid. It would take about $15.00 worth of this and the Boiler would have to be run as a steam job for at least 2 days.

A total cost of approximately ...............$65.00

And we cannot guarantee that it will be a 100% job.

We can, however, cut this half section out and plug the Headers, this we have been prepared to do ever since we knew that the Boiler was leaking.

It would lower the Heating Surface of the Boiler about 4 per cent, but the Boiler is still large enough to take care of the Building.

A job of this kind could be done in a comparatively short time, most of the time being taken up in cutting the section loose of Boiler cement and replacing the covering, so as to allow for expansion when the section heats up, which it will do, due to not having water in it.

The total cost of this job would be approximately $75.00.

We might add that there are several of these Boilers in the Country with sections cut out. We carry special Plugs in stock for this purpose all the time.

Yours very truly,
Yates, Neale & Co.,
per Jas.E. Yates.

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report dated Nov. 12, 1940, on the Elkhorn Indian Residential School:

The tables in the children's dining room need recovering with battleship linoleum. Rev. Minchin had the tables rebuilt and rebolted this summer, and they are now in good condition. I would recommend the purchase of new battleship linoleum (medium quality). Rev. Minchin will arrange for putting it on. Angle metal should also be supplied. There are ten tables, each 3 feet x 12 feet. The total amount of linoleum required is 120 feet in length, 3 feet wide.

The girls were busy in the laundry, and the work in this department is heavy. The ironing of sheets, pillow cases, towels and other flat pieces is a big task, and many of the children are small. I would recommend the purchase of an electric mangle. The J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company can supply one which should be suitable for approximately $75.00, f.o.b. Winnipeg.

The water pipes are filling up, especially the small ones, and giving a lot of trouble. The engineer believes this is due to the accumulation of sand in the pressure tanks. There are no manholes in these tanks. Yates, Neale & Company, of Brandon, have offered to install two manholes for $98.00. I am advised that in Winnipeg the usual charge is $50.00 for each manhole. If funds are available this work should be done before some serious damage occurs.

Dear Sir:

On Saturday November 9th, the Motor running our furnace stoker began to give trouble and we had to switch it off. I got in touch with Yates Neale & Co. of Brandon who had installed the stoker and they sent down an Electrician with another Motor to take its place. The Electrician found that coal dust must have in some way been drawn in to the motor. The bearing at one end was cut away through an accumulation of coal dust. This was the pulley end. The bearing at the other end was in good condition and well supplied with oil. The electrician took the damaged motor away and I have a report from Yates Neale & Co. saying that the cost of reconditioning the motor would be almost as great as the purchase of a new one. They sent down a new one which our engineer installed, and we have returned to them the supply motor brought down on November 9th.

I reported my action to Inspector Hamilton on Monday Nov. 11 explaining the urgency of the matter as the heating of the building depends upon the stoker and the furnace cannot be run without it. Inspector Hamilton advised that I should give you all the above particulars when forwarding the vouchers. As you can understand we had to act immediately.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

Re Grant of $650.00 for Repairs

After making a careful survey of our buildings and equipment, I have come to the conclusion that this money could best be used by spending it on the remodelling and repairing of the building formerly used as a gymnasium. I understand that the building has not been used for some years, with the result that it is falling into a state of disrepair.

My proposal is to have a basement put under the building, and remodel the building itself to make three class-rooms 36' x 18'. The benefits that the School would derive from this plan are numerous.

1. Our present root-cellar is not satisfactory, and a new one will have to be built. Part of the proposed basement could be made into a root-cellar, thus eliminating the expense of building a new one.

2. We have no recreation room apart from the staff sitting room. The children have to spend their free time either in the class rooms or the dormitories and on the stair-ways. One of our most urgent needs is the provision of recreation rooms for the children. This need would be met quite adequately if the old gymnasium were remodelled to make class-rooms, as the two class-rooms in the main building could then be used as recreation rooms.

3. The building now used as the intermediate class-room could be put to good use as a warehouse.

4. The old gymnasium has been a first class building, but if it is not repaired and put to some use it will soon become worthless.
Inspector Hamilton.

Unfortunately our grant will be insufficient to meet the cost of the proposed alterations; however our need of a new root-dellar and recreation rooms is urgent, and I am hoping that the Department will consider the plan sufficiently worth-while to warrant an increased grant.

I am enclosing herewith an estimate of the cost of the proposed alterations.

Yours sincerely,

C. N. Middleton
Principal.
Dear Sir,

The enclosed letter has just been received from the Reverend Mr. Middleton, Principal of the Elkhorn School.

The building referred to as the gymnasium is too good a building to leave neglected. A similar building could not be erected for less than $3,000.00. Remodelled as suggested, it would serve a worth-while purpose.

A root cellar is needed and this could be provided for in part of the basement.

The children at this school have no place to play except as suggested by the Principal, or in a dark and ill-smelling basement.

If this work can be done at the figure given I would urge that the extra $458.00 be provided and that Mr. Middleton be allowed to proceed at once with the work.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian agencies for Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 9th instant and also letter relating to the marginally noted subject received by you from the Principal.

It so happens that the sum of $650.00 was included in the estimates of this year for repairs at the Elkhorn Residential School, and it is extremely difficult to exceed this amount, for the simple reason that repair bills at the majority of our schools this year have been in excess of the appropriations voted for such work. I am disposed to agree with the Principal, however, that the gymnasium building should be rebuilt. In undertaking this construction, the Principal should keep in mind the fact that provision should be made for vocational instruction for boys and perhaps for girls. Our residential schools are constantly under criticism for their failure to provide practical courses for the pupils, and in view of the acute shortage of skilled labour in the Dominion at the present time, this condition should be remedied at every opportunity. It is our intention, therefore, to have Mr. Doucet make a survey of the residential schools in Manitoba toward the end of this calendar year or the beginning of the next.

I am sending forward to the Purchasing Division a list of the supplies requested by the Principal. I have been wondering if you would suggest to him that the item of $150.00 for labour be, if at all possible, borne either by the school or by the Anglican Commission.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

With regard to the grant of $650.00 available for repairs, improvements etc., this year at our Elkhorn School, as set forth in your letter of June 30th last, #160-2, I beg to state that I have received a copy of the letter forwarded by the Principal of this School to your Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg, and in which he offers suggestions as to how this money may be expended to the best advantage.

You will know from previous correspondence that our Commission have keenly desired for some time to have detached class-rooms supplied at this school as well as at some of our other schools, especially those at Onion Lake and Lac la Ronge. Principal Middleton's suggestion that the building originally used as a gymnasium be fitted up and used as class-rooms, with a full-sized basement, part of which could be used as a root cellar, has our Commission's approval as a temporary measure. They have found that, as a general rule, buildings erected for one specific purpose cannot be satisfactorily reconditioned for other purposes, and while in this case the gymnasium building might be made to serve temporarily in the way suggested it could not be considered as a permanently satisfactory arrangement.

Dear Sir:

We have begun work on re-modelling the gymnasium and are at present digging out the basement. I have just learned that the carpenter who made the estimate did not include cement and timbers for the basement. The following will be required:

- Cement, 125 sacks $125.00
- Lumber - 14' 8" x 6" x 7' $35.00
- Lumber - 3' 8" x 6" x 18' $15.00

$175.00

If it is impossible to procure 8" timbers, 4 boards 2" x 8" might be substituted for each timber.

I suppose it will be necessary to get approval for this expenditure from the Indian Department and to have the supplies ordered through the purchasing agent. However, it would be quicker and easier to obtain these supplies locally, if permission can be obtained to do so.

These materials are essential and we would like to have them as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

"C.N. Middleton"

I inspected the Elkhorn Indian Residential School on May 18th and wish to report as follows.

There are 134 pupils enrolled: boys - 55; and girls - 79. There are three teachers and the pupils appear to be making fair progress in their respective grades. All were neatly dressed and clean in appearance.

The dining-room has been painted and now is much brighter. The floors are hardwood, but have no filler or finish. I would recommend that these floors be treated with two coats of Tremco penetrain. It will require about five gallons to do this; but the floors will have a good finish and be much easier to keep clean.

The dormitories were well aired and clean. Two have been painted and the walls and ceiling are now bright and clean.

The new class-rooms are not in use yet, but should be ready for the fall term in September. This change will provide a nice playroom and reading-room for both the girls and boys. In digging the basement under the proposed new classrooms provision has been made for a large root cellar. The Principal found to his disappointment that some water appeared so it will now be necessary to fill in the excavation at least one foot, after which a cement floor may be required. This cement floor will involve extra expense and he requested that the Department pay for the cement. In view of the circumstances I think this should be allowed.

The children appear well fed and attached is a copy of the menu followed. You will note the quantities used for one meal are inserted in red. The children receive all the bread...
they desire and I found the brown bread very wholesome. Miss Long is a graduate nurse and is the matron. She is greatly interested in the children and gives careful consideration to their food requirements.

The cattle number thirty head and a fair supply of milk is provided. The milk is served to the children to drink or on porridge or in milk puddings.

The sewing-room, laundry, kitchen and bakery are well supervised and the girls receive a good training in the work of these departments.

The Principal's house needs interior decoration badly. To my knowledge no cleaning or decoration has been done for years and the house is dark and dismal. The following is the approximate cost required to do the necessary work:

- 3 gals Satin finish Ivory Enamel $16.50
- 1 " Gloss White Enamel 5.50
- 2 gals Semi-gloss White Enamel 11.00
- Sanding Floors 15.00
- Floor Filler - 3 gallons 12.00
- Wall Paper 45.00
- Gold-dust for Putty Coat - 2 sacks 2.00
- Cost of Paper Hanging and Pasteering 75.00

Total $182.00

The Rev. Middleton supplied the above figures which I understand he obtained locally. I would recommend that Mr. Middleton be authorized to proceed with the work.

The farm seeding was well along and they also expect to have a large garden in addition to several acres of potatoes.

The Rev. Mr. Middleton has been at Elkhorn for less than one year. He appears greatly interested in his work and I find him willing and anxious to co-operate in every respect.

I hope funds will be made available to carry out the enclosed recommendations.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, reporting on your recent inspection of the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. The Department approves having the floor in the dining room treated with two coats of Tremco penetrant. It is noted that 5 gallons will be required. It is understood that the work will be done by the school staff, without cost to the Department.

With reference to the new classrooms, please let me know the amount of cement required. In connection with these classrooms it is regretted that no mention was made in your report regarding manual training activities at this school. If you refer to my letter of September 14, 1942, you will note that an amount of $650.00 was provided in the appropriation for the last fiscal year for repairs and improvements at this school and the major portion of this amount was authorized for rebuilding the gymnasium building. In giving this authority it was distinctly provided that provision should be made for vocational instruction for boys and perhaps for girls. Under these circumstances you will realize our disappointment when you made no mention of any provision having been made as directed. For your information I may also say that on March 4 last we wrote a letter to the Principal of the Elkhorn School requesting a report regarding manual training work covered during the past year. As yet he has not replied to our letter.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Cement for Basement Floor -
Silkhorn Residential School.

I acknowledge Departmental letter 106-9-5, dated June 7th. The cement required is estimated at one hundred bags. Mr. Middleton states this can be purchased locally for $1.00 per bag.

In view of the fact that the classrooms had not been completed no manual training classroom was available and so no special course of work has been started. Mr. Middleton hopes to have the new classrooms ready by September 1st, at which time a building will be available for manual training. He has no qualified instructor; but will endeavour to get one. I understand he has written Ottawa direct concerning this matter. If a teacher can be secured some tools will be required.

The re-modelling of the gymnasium entailed much more work than was anticipated and so was not completed last fall. The boys have assisted in all the work and this has been excellent training and will prove helpful. It's a type of work they enjoy. They have also done most of the interior painting in the school - a further worthwhile training.

I find Mr. Middleton most anxious to co-operate and if he can secure a suitable staff I am sure he will carry out a worthwhile program of work.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.

Mr. E. Moodie, Inspector, Fire Prevention Branch, Department of Labour, 328 Legislative Building, Winnipeg, has inspected the Elkhorn Indian School, and in closing his report made the following recommendations.

"Life Safety Recommendations"

(1) Exit doors from children's dormitories are kept locked. It is herewith recommended that the use of padlocks be discontinued, and if it is necessary to keep exits locked, same to be controlled by master keys in possession of all members of staff.

(2) Exit to fire escapes from girls and boys dormitories on second floor are by push-up windows; these windows to be changed to open on their vertical axis in one piece. If exit windows are covered with storm windows, same to open outward on their vertical axis, and the inside windows to open inward on their vertical axis.

(3) The children's ages in the dormitories on the third floor are from 6 to 11 years of age, and the ages of the children on the second floor are from 12 to 17. Would recommend that the older children be moved to the top floor and the younger ones moved from the top floor to the second floor.
